PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Funding of Children's Services
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That funding in the area of childrens services, which has been reduced by almost 40 per cent in real terms over the last five years, should be restored forthwith to at least the real value of funding allocated in the 1975-76 Budget. And further, that annual Budget allocations in the area of childrens services should be spent in full for the purposes designated.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beazley,Mr Robert Brown,Mrs Child,Mr Cunningham,Mr Free,Mr Charles Jones,Mr Les McMahon,Mr Milton,Mr Mountford and Mr Wallis.

PETITION.TITLE: Service Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

(1) That merchant seamen have in the past served in theatres of war; they have been decorated for valour following war action; they have been prisoners of war and should therefore be entitled to similar pension rights and medical benefits as regular servicemen.
(2) That by being denied the entitlements, such as pension and medical benefits, which other war veterans receive, they are thereby being discriminated against.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government amend the Repatriation Act (1920) Section 100 (d) (iv) to take account of war-related service by merchant seamen during World War 2.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Humphreys and Mr Kent.

PETITION.TITLE: Travelling Post Office Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we protest most strongly against the Australian Postal Commission's decision to phase out the Travelling Post Office (TPO) in NSW.

The PTO service has given the country people of NSW a reliable and efficient service for many years. To replace this service with a road system would be a backward step which we believe would result in long delays in mail going to and from country centres.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will look favourably on our petition to retain the TPO service in NSW.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
That parents with dependent children bear a disproportionate share of the tax burden;
That the recent substantial increase in the dependent spouse rebate does not go to all parents;
That family allowances do benefit all parents with dependent children.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That family allowances be increased immediately, and
That family allowances be indexed but not taxed.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Kelly and Mr Morris.

PETITION.TITLE: Abortion
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that we support your efforts to strengthen our family and community life.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will:
1. Cease paying out taxpayers money for unlawful abortion procedures.
2. Eliminate subsidies for abortion referral centres.
3. Ensure that Australia's Human Rights Charter will include rights for unborn Australians, primarily the right to life.
4. Introduce further benefits for pregnant women to assist them in continuing with their pregnancy.
5. Obtain each year from each of the State Attorneys General:
(a) written details as to the reasons for which procedures were carried out under item 6469 of the Medical Benefits Schedule,
(b) Declaration that no procedures in respect of which a claim is made within the Health Insurance Act are unlawful abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Child Care Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of Parliament assembled in the House of Representatives. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Taxpayers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other taxpayers can deduct business expenses from their assessable income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights in Romania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Romanian Government is committing genocide against the three million strong native born Hungarian population in Romania, as defined in Articles II. and III. of the United Nations Convention on the Crime of Genocide, which facts are well documented in the reports of the Amnesty International, the Minority Rights Group, the International League of Jurists, etc.

That the Article IV. of the Convention states that: 'Persons committing genocide or any other acts enumerated in Article III. shall be punished, whether they are constitutionally responsible rulers, public officials or private individuals.'

That the Article VIII. of the Convention states: 'Any contracting party may call upon the competent organs of the United Nations to take such actions under the Charter of the United Nations as they consider appropriate for the prevention and suppression of acts of genocide or any of the other acts enumerated in Article III.'

As Australia is a Contracting Party to the Convention on the Crime of Genocide, and that the Joint Committee for Foreign Affairs and Defence has already established precedents by having investigated Human Rights violations in other countries.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

1. That the Joint Committee for Foreign Affairs and Defence take up an investigation into the alleged genocide activities of the Romanian Government against its three million native born Hungarians in Romania; and

2. That if such investigation should establish that Romania has been engaged in acts of genocide against its Hungarian minorities to call upon the competent organs of the United Nations to take such action under the Charter of the United Nations as they consider appropriate for the prevention and suppression of acts of genocide or any other acts enumerated in the United Nations Convention on the Crime of Genocide.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Unemployment Benefit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully calls for:
The immediate and unconditional withdrawal of any proposals to deny unemployment benefits to unemployed people under 18 years old.
That the level of benefits for all unemployed people, and including people receiving sickness benefits and pensions, be raised to at least 120 per cent of the poverty line.

That future employment policies be devoted to job creation and the restoration of full employment rather than the evasion of this responsibility by hiding the unemployed in short term training and education schemes.
Public acknowledgement of the fact that unemployment is the result of insufficient jobs and not the fault of any minority group, the education system or the unemployed themselves.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Unemployment Benefit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the Federal Parliament in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
That, as concerned citizens we wish to lodge the strongest possible objection to the Governments intention to cease paying unemployment benefits to people under the age of 18 years.
We believe that this decision if carried out will:
(a) cause extreme hardship to the living standards of people under 18 years of age, especially those who do not live at home.
(b) create severe hardship on parents and families who will be forced to support people placed in this situation, and also add a further burden on community aid.
(c) Will not force the majority of young people back to school, due to lack of finance and confidence in the Education System.
(d) Cause young people to morally deteriorate by entering a life of crime, prostitution, drug abuse etc.
We therefore call on the Federal Government not to go ahead with this policy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Labelling of Cosmetics
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.

That the Industries Assistance Commission, because of the Commission's terms of reference, seems unable to impose any regulation or recommend any regulation which might restrict the activities of cosmetic companies which produce cosmetics in which animal ingredients have been used, or for which animals were subjected to research.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will:
Legislate to require comprehensive labelling of perfumes, cosmetics and toilet preparations to indicate:
(1) whether a product contains any animal derivative. If so, the ingredient and source should be indicated.
(2) whether the research and development of that product or any of its ingredients involved experimentation on animals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Mineral Sand Products
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That sandmining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology or environment.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the interim list of the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, take into consideration the protection of the island.
3. That the Queensland Government has recently renewed a further mining lease against the advice of conservationists.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to refuse requests for export permits covering mineral sand products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Breeders' Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. there is lack of public information about the content and intention of the proposed legislation on Plant Variety Rights;
2. there is concern that the ethical and moral issues of granting private proprietorial rights over genetic resources have not been properly and publicly considered;
3. there is evidence to suggest that such legislation may lead to a reduction in the existing plant diversity;
4. there is reason to fear that farmers may be restricted in their activities due to the controls placed on the use and propagation of seed stocks;
5. evidence suggests that Plant Varietal Rights legislation will lead to higher costs for the farmer, the consumer, the plant-breeder and the taxpayer, and
6. evidence suggests that Plant Varietal Rights legislation will lead to a further increase in foreign control of Australian resources.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament defer introducing the legislation until full and informed public discussion of the issues involved has taken place.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. Present income tax laws discriminate against single-income families.
2. It is unfair that families should pay more tax, the more unequally their total income is divided between spouses.
3. All marriages should be recognised as partnerships by allowing spouses to divide their joint income for taxation purposes.
4. The family, which is the natural and fundamental unit of society, should be an economic unit in tax laws.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament will reform income tax laws to allow the joint income of husband and wife to be equally divided between them for taxation purposes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Airline Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:
That we protest most strongly against the present two airline domestic policy of the Commonwealth Government.
That this policy has resulted in expensive airfares and poor service and discourages tourists from the Eastern States visiting WA and vice versa.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will look favourably on our petition and formulate an airline policy providing for greater competition so that prices and service are determined by free market forces.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beazley,Mr Campbell,Mr Carlton and Mr McLean.

PETITION.TITLE: South Australia Railway Service
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Hallett in the electorate of Grey respectfully showeth:
That the Australian National Railways commission intends to cease all local passenger services on the Adelaide to Burra and Peterborough line as from 31st December 1980.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the existing passenger services be retained.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that it is my intention to issue a writ on Tuesday, 3 March 1981, for the election of a member to serve for the electoral division of Wentworth in the State of New South Wales in the place of the Honourable Robert James Ellicott, Q.C. The dates in connection with the election will be fixed as follows:

INTERJECT.PARA: Date of return of writ-On or before Tuesday, 12 May 1981.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on General Business Thursday No. 1, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House is of the opinion that the National Health Act 1953 and the Health Insurance Act 1973 should be amended to provide pensioner health fringe benefits for those on the unemployment benefit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) notes the expressed concern of the independent public inquiry into domestic air fares over the lack of time made available to it to consider fully item 2 (iii) of its terms of reference, namely, the degree of cross- subsidisation, due to the unexpected time constraints imposed upon it by the Government;

(2) expresses its concern at the inquiry's complaint concerning the general inadequacy of data available for a full and detailed consideration of item 3(ii) of the terms of reference, namely, Government domestic aviation policy including the objective of increasing competition, and

(3) calls for the establishment of a select committee to consider both references with particular reference to the problems of the costs of travel to Western Australia and any other related matter which the committee considers to be relevant.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In view of the great need for food aid to be provided to developing countries, as well as in Australia's interests as a food exporting nation, noting the Minister's keen interest in improving our relations with developed and developing countries and noting also that the immediate past President of the World Bank, Mr McNamara, and the Governor of the International Monetary Fund support the establishment of a food import financing facility by the wealthier countries, can the Minister explain why the Australian officials present at recent meetings of the international financial institutions failed to support and, indeed, actively opposed the establishment of a proposed food import finance facility?

—As is well known, for many years Australia has developed an extensive aid program, in relation not only to food but also to technical assistance and in many other areas. Equally, our aid program has to be considered in the Budget context, along with all other demands on Government resources. Within those resource constraints, Australia will continue to play its constructive part in aid programs.

—Has the attention of the Prime Minister been drawn to reports that the date of the Premiers Conference was set in order to prevent one of the Premiers being present at a function for the Prince of Wales? Is there any substance in those reports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen those reports. I hope it is wrong, but I have been advised that the reports came from Mr Wran's office. Of course, the reports are a total absurdity. Honourable members might be interested in the history of this matter. In the middle of last year the Premiers indicated that they wanted to hold meetings amongst themselves to discuss tax sharing arrangements to apply from 30 June this year. They held a meeting in September. I thought we would receive a submission from the Premiers very shortly after that which could be put to study by my colleagues before a meeting with the Premiers was held. In the event, the Premiers were not able to give us an agreed submission before 12 February this year. It took them from September to some time in February to agree to a submission to put to us. I think that even the Premiers would understand that we need some little time to examine a document which took them so much time to put together.

ANSWER.PARA: On 20 February I telexed Premiers suggesting 15 and 16 April as the dates for holding a conference to discuss their submission. I think it is worth noting that 15 April is only one of the dates on which His Royal Highness is to be in Sydney. On 16 April His Royal Highness is to be in Melbourne, Victoria. In that sense, the meeting, if held on those dates, would cut across His Royal Highness's visit to both New South Wales and Victoria. But the telex stated also:
I should be grateful for your early advice on whether these dates are acceptable to you.

At this stage only three Premiers have responded. One of them finds the dates difficult. As a result, the Government is looking at alternative dates. I have not heard from Mr Wran; I have only seen what has appeared in the newspapers. Apparently, he prefers to communicate by that means rather than by telex. The conference is unlikely to be held earlier than those dates because Mr Tonkin is going overseas and will be overseas for a large part of March and April. I do not think it would be possible to hold the meeting before he is due to leave in March. I am looking at dates beyond 15 and 16 April. If it is possible to accommodate the Premiers on dates which are more acceptable to them, the Treasurer and I will be very happy to do so. I really think that Mr Wran's suggestion, if it is his suggestion, is childish and absurd. I am disappointed that he should seek to play politics in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Foreign Affairs advise the House, in the light of recent contributions by the United States and Western European governments, what the Australian contribution will be to the Kampuchean relief program for 1981? Will he assure the House that Australia's official contribution-I repeat the word 'official'-to Kampuchea this year will be at least as generous as that of the tens of thousands of ordinary Australian citizens, including school children, who have responded to appeals and have given some $10m to aid that shattered country?

—Australia has been a major donor of aid to Kampuchea both officially and, as the honourable member has said, privately. Very large amounts of money were raised. I think from memory the official amount of aid to Kampuchea last year was about $14m. The Government currently has under consideration the level of aid it will provide to Kampuchea--
—How much did the Government give and how much will it give this year?
—I said: I think from memory the amount that was given last year was $14m. I say that subject to correction. The Government currently has under consideration the amount it will give this year.

—Considering the current industrial unrest throughout Australia, can the Minister for Industrial Relations inform the House what is the procedure for deregistration of a union? What is the present situation regarding the Builders Labourers Federation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The procedure for deregis- tration of a union is covered by both section 143 and section 143A of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. I stated previously that the Government will be acting under the provisions of section 143 of that Act. In essence, the first step is to obtain an order calling on the union to show cause why its registration should not be cancelled. The Government is determined that this legal process should be undertaken. We are confident that our application will be successful. We are confident that in that climate of success it will be a significant step towards achieving a long term improvement in industrial relations in the building industry.

ANSWER.PARA: We are taking the action because of the continuing and blatant denial of the normal industrial processes by this union. The nature and frequency of the challenges to governments, State and Federal, industry and workers by the Builders Labourers Federation will not be tolerated by this Government. The nature and frequency of the violence, stoppages, bans, pickets and various forms of intimidation will not be tolerated. The industrial guerrilla tactics of the type employed by the Builders Labourers Federation are outside the law. That can be said firmly and unequivocally. No union or anybody in this land is above the law. The Government will ensure that the flagrant abuses by the Builders Labourers Federation simply do not continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs to his speech at the National Press Club on 3 February 1981 when he stated that a free flow of information about Asia is important to Australian foreign policy. In view of these admirable sentiments, I ask the Minister why he is reluctant to reject specifically the actions of the Indonesian Government in killing and, more recently, expelling Australian journalists. Does he regard the low key measure of issuing a statement of regret about the expulsion of Mr Peter Rodgers as sufficient response for this calculated attempt to manipulate the Australian media? Will he at least summon the Indonesian Ambassador and deliver the strongest protest, making clear that good relations cannot flourish in an atmosphere of censorship and intimidation against Australian journalists?

—As I have already said, I agree with the honourable member that a free flow of information between countries is to the benefit always of both. I hope that Indonesian journalists will come here to report freely to their countrymen on events in Australia. As I have already indicated, I very much regret that the same attitude is not taken by the Indonesian Government. The honourable member is not correct in identifying the sort of response that I gave to that Government on the expulsion of Mr Rodgers. It did not amount merely to the issuing of a statement. I did that, but also I gave instructions to our Embassy in Jakarta to make my concerns known and to ask the Indonesian Government to reconsider its decision. I further made the point, and I think it does need to be made, that every country has the sovereign right to decide who resides therein, but it remains my view that a free interchange of media representatives between all countries, including Indonesia, is desirable.

—Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs assure the House that, in the current nuclear safeguards negotiations with Japan, there will be no watering down of Australia's safeguard policy requirements, particularly for commercial reasons?

—The proposed agreement was one of the matters discussed at the recent Australia-Japan Ministerial Committee meeting in Tokyo. Both sides agreed on the need to work quickly to conclude the negotiations in order to allow the agreement to be signed and ratified. Both the Deputy Prime Minister and I made clear to Japanese Ministers that under Australia's nuclear safeguards policy the agreement must be in force before shipments of Australian uranium, under new contracts, could be delivered to Japan. I can assure the House that this remains the position of the Australian Government and that Australia's safeguards policy is not being weakened in any way for commercial reasons in any of our nuclear safeguards agreements, including that with Japan. I understand that consultations with Japan on the proposed agreement will recommence early in March, prior to the settling of dates for a further round of negotiations.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the Minister to his appearance at the National Press Club on 3 February 1981, when he spoke of the Government's agreement to exchange defence attaches with China. In order to avoid the appearance of tilting even further towards China in its long-standing ideological, territorial and security disputes with Moscow, will Australia also exchange defence attaches with the Soviet Union, as do all North Atlantic Treaty Organisation countries? Do the shared strategic perceptions to which the Minister referred at the National Press Club extend to supporting the Chinese view that a third world war is inevitable? Is this exchange of defence attaches part of the dream of a grand anti-Soviet military alliance, which the Prime Minister so embarrassingly proposed in 1976?
—Order! The honourable gentleman has asked his question. I call the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

—As I have already made clear, the defence attache exchange between ourselves and China is a natural extension of the increased breadth of the relationships between our two countries. It is also true that we share certain strategic perceptions of the regions in which we live, and the exchange of defence attaches will ensure that the two countries remain aware of each other's views in this area. It is equally true, and I acknowledge this, that our views do not coincide in all respects. That applies to many countries with which we have relations. The recent actions of the Soviet Union do not--

—Mr Speaker, I wish to raise a point of order. This is not an answer to a question; the Minister is reading from a brief from the Department of Foreign Affairs. There is a very real danger that he may make the same mistake in misreading, or reading a typographical error, as he made at the Press Club.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.
—Mr Speaker, I am not reading from a brief. I am referring to a couple of notes on a sheet of paper.

—Order! The Minister will resume his seat. I indicate to the Leader of the Opposition that he ought not to stand and claim a point of order when in fact what he chooses to do is make a statement, short though it may be. I ask him to confine himself to a genuine point of order. If he wishes to ask the Minister under the Standing Orders whether he is reading from a document, I will be prepared to put that question to the Minister. Depending on the reply of the Minister, I will then put the subsequent question whether the material is confidential.
—I merely wanted to draw to the House's attention that he does not know his portfolio.
—Does the Leader of the Opposition wish to ask whether the Minister was reading? I ask him the simple question: Does he wish to make the point to establish whether the Minister was reading?
—I think it has been made.
—I ask the Leader of the Opposition not to take points of order which have no substance. I call the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

—I said that one of the reasons why we are exchanging defence attaches with China is that our two countries share certain perceptions of the strategic issues facing this region. We do not share the perceptions held by the Soviet Union of the strategic issues facing this region. The recent actions of the Soviet Union in its invasion of Afghanistan and its invasion by proxy through Vietnam of Kampuchea illustrate that point clearly.
—I call the honourable member for Mitchell.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to raise a point of order. I ask the Minister to table the document from which he was reading.
—Was the Minister reading from a document?
—No, I was not. The document on which I had some notes in fact referred to aid to Kampuchea.
—Well, why did the Minister--

—Order! The honourable member for Reid will resume his seat. The Minister has indicated that he was not reading from a document. That puts that issue at an end. The honourable member for Reid has asked whether the Minister would be prepared--
—Will he table the document he was not reading from?

—The honourable member for Melbourne Ports will remain silent. The honourable member for Reid has made a subsequent point. He asked whether the Minister would table the document that he had in his hand. Is the Minister prepared to table the document?
—Mr Speaker, I will. It has nothing to do with the question.
—The document is tabled.

—I ask the Minister for Transport: What is the current financial status of Qantas Airways Ltd? What effect are the current industrial disputes having on ticket sales and the reputation of Australia's flag carrier, in the national market and foreign markets? Is Qantas facing a financial crisis or possible sale due to the actions of a small group of trade unionists?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The current financial position of Qantas has deteriorated considerably as a result of the irresponsible dispute which has been aided and abetted by the Australian Council of Trade Unions. In fact, the last estimate is that this strike has cost Qantas no less than $9m. Qantas is a company owned by the people of Australia; they are the shareholders of this national airline. I think it is an outrageous state of affairs that Qantas should be singled out by the ACTU in spite of the fact that the stewards have been able to resolve their difficulties with the Qantas board in an orderly manner. The situation of Qantas at present is very bad indeed. There is no way that this Government will sell Qantas but there is every possibility that, if this strike continues, Qantas will have no alternative but to close down. I think the Australian people and the 13,000 employees of Qantas need to know that, because there is no way that this airline can limp around the way it is expected to at the present time. I compliment the Chairman and the staff of Qantas who have worked around the clock trying to keep Australia's national carrier flying to and from Australia. It is Australia's national carrier. The name Qantas is synonymous--

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister will resume his seat.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Chairman of Qantas was reported in the media yesterday-
—The honourable gentleman will resume his seat.
—Of making a statement--
—The honourable member for Burke will resume his seat.
—He was reported as saying that Qantas was partly responsible for the strike.

—I warn the honourable member for Burke that if he continues that behaviour he will set something of a record of being suspended from the service of the House before making a maiden speech. I call the Minister for Transport.

—I think the problems need to be put in their proper perspective. One of the reasons Qantas had to use staff labour on 19 occasions over the last two years was to ensure that passengers entering and leaving this country were able to get off and on the aircraft. There have been no fewer than 82 wildcat stoppages in the last two years. Unless staff had volunteered on those 19 occasions to assist the travelling public, there is no way that the stoppages would have caused anything but a chaotic situation for people visiting and leaving this country.

ANSWER.PARA: I call upon the parties concerned to meet again in the interests of this great airline and in the interests of responsibility. There is still time for a sensible and responsible settlement of this dispute.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Prime Minister. Does he believe that the Builders Labourers Federation should have abided by the umpire's decision given twice in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in its dispute over the building of the Omega navigational station? If so, why does he not believe that the same principle should be accepted by his Government as a public employer in respect of the umpire's decision handed down by the acting Public Service Arbitrator as Determination No. 503 of 1980?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman misunderstands the nature of that determination. We know quite well that the honourable member for Wills was the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions during a period of an Australian Labor Party Government when there were more industrial disputes and when there was more time lost than ever before in the history of Australia.
—Do not chicken out on this one; answer it.

—If the honourable gentleman wants an answer I suggest that he try to control his own front bench to start with. The honourable gentleman will get his answer. I challenge him to sit through the answer and to do so quietly because he knows quite well that his own record as President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, in terms of industrial disputes-especially when there was a Labor Government-was a totally disastrous one. There are some things which this Commonwealth Government, any Commonwealth government, must do as an employer. There are some management prerogatives that any employer must take to itself. In those particular matters the Parliament is the ultimate umpire of what must be done. It has always been an accepted part of the operations of the Commonwealth Public Service that determinations can be disallowed in the Parliament itself. In that instance the Parliament is the umpire. It is quite plain that in that particular determination there are some matters which the Public Service Board and the Government believe should be the prerogative of management. Therefore, we made the decision to move for the disallowance of that particular determination.
—That is a double standard.
—Order! I ask the honourable member for Wills to remain silent.

—I did not think that the honourable member for Wills would have the courage to listen to the answer in silence. Quite plainly he cannot and quite plainly he does not like the answer. There is a very real difference between a decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission--
—When will you bring on the debate.

—Order! The Prime Minister will resume his seat. I ask the honourable member for Wills to understand that he is entitled to ask a question when he receives the call. The Minister to whom that question is directed equally is entitled to answer the question in silence. I ask the honourable member for Wills to cease interjecting.

—There is a great deal of difference between a determination in relation to wages or hours, which are properly the matters of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, and a determination which affected a piece of legislation which was imaginative and far-reaching and which offered significant benefits to Commonwealth public servants in relation to early retirement and very significant benefits in relation to accessibility to a very generous superannuation scheme even in addition to those early retirement provisions. Matters of this kind plainly are utterly different from determinations in relation to wages and other conditions of work.

ANSWER.PARA: If the Commonwealth Government is prepared to introduce into this Parliament legislation which offers very real inducements and benefits to Commonwealth employees by way of early retirement, at their own choice and discretion, it is fair enough that management should have some additional capacity to redeploy and to improve the efficiency of the Service by management-initiated early retirement. Indeed the provisions that are in the Act are already so circumscribed by appeals provisions and processes designed to protect the rights of individual public servants that I doubt that they will be used very much. The voluntary early retirement provisions probably will be used quite considerably by members of the Service. That is a very real benefit for them.

But when we are making decisions about the prerogatives of management, of the Public Service Board-matters that need to be decided by government-we then clearly need to have in mind also the privileged position of the Public Service in comparison to other employees around this country. We know quite well that in relation to superannuation, permanency of employment and safeguard provisions affecting the rights of individual members, Commonwealth public servants are treated in a way which is second to none throughout the Commonwealth. The honourable member for Wills does his own reputation no good at all by sitting on the front bench of the Australian Labor Party Opposition and making the kind of noise that he sought to make today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Opposition. I preface it--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman is not entitled to direct a question other than to a Minister except for a matter for which that honourable member is responsible to the House. I will listen to the question before ruling on it.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Katter proceeding to address a question to the Leader of the Opposition-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's question is out of order.

—My question which is directed to the Prime Minister relates to his earlier answer about the proposed disallowance of a determination. When will the Government announce to the Parliament when it proposes to disallow that determination because this week we have been told that the matter could have been up for debate every day. Because it is a matter of major importance-the Prime Minister adverted to that in his earlier answer-can he please indicate on what day this Parliament will be able to debate that matter?
—I understand that the Minister will give notice of the matter today.

—Can the Treasurer provide any information which would indicate the cost to Federal revenue resulting from allowable business deductions through the tax system for charges levied by State governments, local government and community organisations? Further, is the Treasurer aware of a recent decision by the Sydney City Council to levy developers for a compulsory contribution to low cost city housing for low income earners? Such contributions would be tax deductible from the incomes of those developers, which would result in the Federal Government actually paying half of the cost of that housing without having any input into the Council's decision.
—I rise to order. The honourable member just told an untruth. It is not a compulsory levy; it is a voluntary levy.
—Order! There is no point of order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot tell the honourable member for Barton offhand what the cost is. I will try to have some calculation made of that.
—Give some money to public housing yourself instead of cutting back on the States.
—Just hold on a moment.
—Order! The honourable member for Reid will remain silent.
—That is what you want to do. You are starving the States of housing money.
—Order! I ask the honourable member for Reid not to interject.
—Why are they so miserable?
—Order! The honourable member for Reid will resume his seat.
—Why won't they give money to the States for housing?
—I warn the honourable member for Reid.

—I will try to get some figures on the first part of the honourable gentleman's question and provide them to him. I should say to the honourable gentleman that the levy-I will not make any observation at this stage as to the circumstances surrounding whether it has to be paid by individual developers in Sydney-is, as I understand it, something that could be properly deductible by developers under section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. The question of whether there would be any ultimate cost to the revenue would depend in very large measure on whether the cost of the levy was passed on by the individual developers and there was thus some recoupment of it insofar as their own income is concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: I make the general observation to the honourable gentleman that it has long been a fact that the Commonwealth has no control over the extent to which its revenues are affected in respect of business deductions incurred by companies in earning their assessable income. Obviously the situation could never be anything other than that because, provided a deduction or an expenditure comes within the concept of earning assessable income, provided it is an outgoing earning assessable income, it is something that can be deductible. I think the honourable gentleman's question raises a number of interesting considerations. I will try to provide to him and the House some estimate of what is involved and generally to assist his inquiries.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the latest Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. As the previous Minister for Science and the Environment stated last year that the Cairns section of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park would be declared by December 1980, can the Minister tell the House why this was not done? Will the Minister and the Government now revert to the previous policy of complete capitulation to the Queensland Premier now that the McPherson by-election is over?

—The Government's view in relation to the establishment of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park remains absolutely clear. My recollection is that a meeting is coming up within the next couple of months at which this question to which the honourable member addressed himself will be discussed.

—Has the Minister for Communications been made aware of changes in the staffing position of the Australian Broadcasting Commission in Darwin since Cyclone Tracy? Has the Australian Broadcasting Commission investigated the staffing needs of the region? Will the Minister give an assurance that the people of the Northern Territory will not be disadvantaged by any staff changes?

—It is true that after Cyclone Tracy, the Australian Broadcasting Commission provided programs for the whole of the Northern Territory virtually on a relay basis from Brisbane as a result of the lack of facilities available in Darwin. However, it has recently investigated the availability of the broadcast services throughout the Territory and currently, as a result of that investigation, a study is being made by the top management of the ABC as to how the broadcasting facilities in the Northern Territory, particularly in Darwin, can be improved. I assure the honourable member that his concern for the maintenance of an adequate broadcast range and quality and identity with the Territory is recognised by the ABC. I will ensure that his question and his concern are brought to the attention of the management of the ABC when it is considering the report on future staff requirements.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. He will recall stating on the Monday morning Eleven AM program on ATN Channel 7 that the best way of establishing lower taxes is 'By restraint in Government expenditure'. In view of the fact that the total tax bill at national government level is the highest ever, however one calculates it, and that four out of five taxpayers are paying more tax than they did five years ago relatively speaking, is his statement by implication a clear confession that the Government has failed to establish its fiercely declared objective of restraint in national government expenditure? If he disputes this, why has there not been a substantial lowering of taxes, especially income taxes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman knows quite well that under the tax scales that he introduced--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable gentlemen opposite do not like to hear the figures. But I will quote them. Taxation was 45c in the dollar at $10,000 and 55c in the dollar at $15,000. The tax levels now are 32c in the dollar up to just over $17,000. If people are earning more money, obviously they will be paying more tax. In addition to that, the Australian Labor Party--
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. The Prime Minister is thoroughly misrepresenting the facts.
—Order! The honourable gentleman is not making a point of order.
—But, with respect, I am.
—The honourable gentleman is making a contradiction.
—He is misrepresenting the situation by claiming--
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.
—The honourable gentleman should have been looking at the face of the honourable member for Blaxland when he was making that kind of intervention.
—I ask the right honourable gentleman to proceed with his answer and not to make any reference to--
—And the honourable member for Wills--
—I call the Leader of the Government.

—There have been considerable reductions in the actual rates paid at any level of income. If people are earning more income, obviously they will pay more tax. The honourable gentleman knows quite well that income taxes rose 125 per cent in the three years of the last Labor Government. The Labor Government financed a very large part of its expenditures by a deficit. This was highly inflationary and that deficit for which Australians had to pay by high inflation certainly ought to be added to the taxes of Mr Hayden and the Labor Party.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Jarman having addressed a question to the Minister for Health-

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that this is a circumstance which I think I have not encountered before. Under the Standing Orders a question which reflects on any named person must be put on the Notice Paper. From the preface to the question I discover that the person named is now deceased. However, I think I should honour the intention of the Standing Orders and ask the honourable gentleman to put his question on the Notice Paper.

—I ask the Prime Minister a question which is supplementary to the question I asked him a few seconds ago. Is it a fact that today someone on average weekly earnings supporting a spouse and two children is paying $158 a year more in tax than he or she was paying in 1975-76? Is it also a fact that today someone on the sort of income that the Prime Minister enjoys-in excess of $82,000 a year-is paying $2,950 less tax than he or she was paying in 1975-76? In what circumstances then can the Prime Minister claim that there has been a substantial reduction in the tax burden for the bulk of taxpayers? Why has he brought about a change in the tax burden distribution which benefits the wealthy, like himself, and disadvantages four out of five taxpayers, who are now paying more tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman glossed over the fact that somebody on average weekly earnings today is earning very much more than he would have been earning five years ago. That obviously has an implication for the tax that would be payable. People on high levels of income, as the honourable gentleman would know, pay about 60 cents in the dollar. Many expert inquiries have believed that the highest level of tax that ought to be payable by any person is about 50 cents in the dollar. In Australia the highest level is 60 cents in the dollar. Quite plainly, that is a very significant tax level and a much higher level of tax than for people on lower levels of income. It seems quite clear from the thrust of the honourable gentleman's question that basically he is in favour of higher taxes, and that point was made yesterday.
—Basically in favour of lower taxes for people on lower incomes. You are getting a reduction at their expense.

—The honourable gentleman would know quite well that when we altered the method of support for families by moving to family allowances as opposed to child rebates, it was done quite deliberately to assist low income families, unlike the previous system-

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The right honourable gentleman will resume his seat. I ask honourable gentlemen on my left to remain silent. The Leader of the Opposition asked his question in silence. I ask honourable gentlemen to hear the answer in silence.

—I think there is not very much more to add, except a slight exhortation to you, Mr Speaker. Would it again be possible in Question Time to have all the microphones turned on so that the people who are listening in can really hear what happens in this place?

—I direct my question to the Treasurer on the subject of the 1981 census. Whose decision was it to abandon the system of counting based on where people spend the night on 30 June? Was there any consultation about the night of 30 June?

—This is a futuristic question. Was there any consultation with State Premiers or Treasurers on the proposed change of procedure? If not, why not? Have those people been told yet? Is the Treasurer aware that this new system will cause Queensland's population to short read at least between the 60,000 and 100,000 persons who are always present as tourists? Is the Minister aware that this will mean that Queensland will be deprived of millions upon millions of dollars disbursed by the Commonwealth?
—The honourable gentleman is now providing information. I call the Treasurer.
—I have not quite finished, Mr Speaker.
—Order! I have called the Treasurer.

—My understanding is that, so far as place of residence is concerned, the 1981 census will be conducted upon the same basis as the previous census was conducted. In other words, one will be obliged to complete details of where one spent the night of 30 June, as has been the case in earlier censuses. Statistics will be collected also on the basis of residence. I also inform the honourable gentleman that the Australian Bureau of Statistics, through me, published last year a fairly lengthy document which set out how the census was to be conducted. That document was tabled in this Parliament. For the first time a very considerable effort was made to expand the area of public debate so that people would know the basis on which the census was to be conducted. I also inform the honourable gentleman-this might have been raised in the last part of his question, I am not sure; but I know he has great interest in these matters-that the number of questions asked this year will be significantly fewer than has been the case on two or three previous occasions.

—I take a point of order, Mr Speaker. May I request that both you and the Prime Minister cease referring to 'honourable gentlemen'? It is becoming a bit embarrassing. 'Honourable members' would be much better.
—The point is well made. I apologise deeply and profusely.
