DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government induced confusion over nursing home benefits reflecting as it does the general incoherence of its policy towards the aged.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate has been prompted by the emerging fiasco in the payment of nursing home benefits. The source of that problem lies in the Medi-muddle that has characterised the Fraser Government's policies in health care over the last five years. There is no need to repeat here the innumerable changes in insurance but they are at the source of the fiasco that is now emerging. It is interesting to note that in the rather soft nosed and fuzzy Jamison report even the Commissioners could make the following comment about the changes of the last five years:

SPEECH.PARA: However, the Commission does not agree that the changes have been beneficial, indeed they have done nothing to improve the efficiency of the health system.

In many ways that is a rather pathetic understatement of the position. The Commission said that the changes have done nothing to improve the efficiency of the health care system. I much prefer the response of the West Australian to the same set of problems. That newspaper called the comment by the Jamison Committee a gross understatement. On the changes to which I have referred the West Australian stated:

It would be more accurate to say that practically every piece of surgery performed on the system since the Fraser Government came to office (with a promise to maintain the Medibank scheme) has weakened it and compounded public confusion.

Although it has never been admitted by the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) this public confusion is at the heart of the problem of nursing home benefit payments. This problem comes a year after the overpayment of $235m to pharmacists. That, of course, was blamed on a computer. Apparently some computer kept on regurgitating a false formula for five years. Now we are seeing the revelations of the Health Department's audit into nursing homes. The audit has been completed in South Australia. We have to try to draw national conclusions from the South Australian data.

The first of these revelations is that over the past four years in South Australia alone $1.9m has been paid incorrectly by the Government in nursing home benefits for patients who are privately insured and who, therefore, were the responsibility of their private funds. The Minister has conceded that figure and the source of the error. That is about all he has conceded and confessed to. The human and institutional ramifications that flow from these errors seem scarcely to concern him.

I want now to try to explore the vague, evasive and shallow responses from the Minister both in this House and in the media, contrast that with what little evidence we have and see whether we can tease out some truth from this sorry affair. Firstly, what is the likely national sum involved in this error? For the moment the Minister refuses to speculate on the total cost of the error although he is prepared to say that any of Labor's figures are exaggerated. The error in South Australia is $1.9m. South Australia has somewhat under 10 per cent of all nursing home beds in Australia. Therefore a national figure of approximately $20m seems to be a reasonable extrapolation. But the Minister told us yesterday:
It is not correct to extrapolate the South Australian situation throughout the Australian continent.

Therefore I ask him, in the interests of reasonable and rational debate and understanding, to explain to us-it is incumbent upon him to explain-why we cannot draw those conclusions from the South Australian figures. Why are the figures atypical in South Australia by contrast with the remainder of the States? Since yesterday we have a further source, that is, the report of the Auditor-General on an efficiency audit of the Commonwealth's administration of nursing home programs. That suggests that a minimum national figure of $4m per annum is involved which over the 3 1/2 year period from October 1977, would suggest that, at a minimum, $14m has been incorrectly paid to nursing homes. So we have an average figure of $20m and a minimum figure of $14m. Of course, if South Australia is atypical in the other direction and the errors are greater in some of the other States-as is certainly possible in relation to Victoria-it may be above the $20m figure. But the sort of range we are talking about is from a minimum of about $14m to a maximum of about $25m. Until we are provided with more precision by the Minister we are left with that range.

It is interesting, too, that the report of the Auditor-General helps us with what I can only take to have been a humorous aside on the part of the Minister yesterday when, in answering a question, he said:
. . . I think that the Department of Health is to be congratulated on its good administration in finding out this problem and recovering the money incorrectly paid.
It is fortunate that the audit report came out yesterday, because it states:

Whilst recognising the skills, diligence and good-will of men and women engaged in nursing homes program management, the Report reveals a number of weaknesses in program administration. These weaknesses have led to unnecessary expenditure and a lack of consistency in the distribution of Commonwealth assistance to the aged and infirm.

The report also goes on to show quite clearly that for the past four years the Department has had no formal procedures for determining the insurance status of patients in nursing homes. So, not having had proper monitoring procedures, the Department is now praised for finding the errors that derive from the lack of these adequate formal controls.

That brings me to a more important question: What is the source of the errors? Certainly it is not this time a computer. We have to find out the source of these errors. For the Minister the source is obvious. He stated:
Those payments--
In error-
were made on the advice of nursing home proprietors. It is up to the nursing home proprietors to provide the correct advice to the Government.

Here we have a very simplistic solution: The nursing home proprietors are to blame for giving the Department the wrong advice. That is simply not good enough. It is simply not good enough for the Minister blandly to state that it is the nursing home proprietors' responsibility to ascertain the status of a patient and then correctly claim. The source of the problem, of the confusion about the status of the nursing home patients, is the Government itself, in its confused, confusing and continuous changes to health insurance. Let us remember when we look at the particular errors involved that most of them stem from the period 1976-77. In those years massive changes occurred in the health cover system in this country. There were also major changes in nursing home charges and benefits.

Let me remind honourable members of the changes that took place in the period 1976-77. This was the period in which we saw the introduction of a public levy system, plus an alternative private insurance system, with a complex of choices. Secondly, it was the period in which the public Medibank organisation, which people associated with a public provision, became a purveyor of private health insurance. It was also the period in which the nursing home benefits ceased to be fully public benefits and were shared between the public and private sectors. An enormous number of confusing changes were made in that 12-month period. To magnify the inevitable confusion which resulted for the whole community, we are here dealing with aged people. Many of the aged and their relatives just did not know whether they were insured. Many believed that they were uninsured when, in fact, they were insured. Vice versa, many no doubt believed that they were insured when in fact they were uninsured. That is the real and basic source of the error that has now been discovered. The nursing homes are the victims of half a decade of maladministration of health by this Government. The production of confusion is the chief achievement of the Fraser Government in the health field.

The health funds themselves, even though they seem to have escaped the criticisms of the Minister to date in this matter, are not blameless because they added to the confusion. For example, when the Government introduced the policy whereby private funds had to pay the nursing home benefits of privately insured members, some funds actively sought pensioner patients in the mistaken belief that their benefits from the reinsurance pool would be greater. When they discovered their error they actively sought to offload the pensioners, mostly back to Medibank Private.

But the Government must shoulder most of the blame for the confusion. Health Department directives in 1977 told the funds that they must actively recruit pensioner patients in the same proportion as the rest of the community, even though it was pointed out that in effect pensioners were being urged to pay money for private insurance benefits which were their right, free of charge from the Government, if they were uninsured. This sleazy attempt to bolster private insurance undoubtedly added further to the confusion amongst pensioners.

The present fiasco is the direct result of these past policies. Today we have a mess, with funds refusing to pay, the Government and funds putting pressure on nursing homes, the Government threatening to withdraw legitimate subsidies from nursing homes as repayments, and some funds boasting that they will have to be taken to court by the nursing homes before they will repay the money. The Minister seems quite prepared to squeeze the nursing homes until the pips squeak. Recoupment procedures are already under way in South Australia, with nursing homes having deductions made from their monthly payments. But on the subject of the reimbursement of the nursing homes by the private funds, the other side of the picture, the Minister seems quite blase. Yesterday he said:
I have no reason to believe that they will not accept those obligations.

But there is every reason to suspect that they will not accept their obligations, and much of that evidence is already before the Minister. For example, in 1978 the Government sought to recoup $9.5m from the funds with respect to payments which all agreed were mistaken. The Minister of the day made exactly the same noises as the Minister at the table is now making about the funds observing their obligations. In the event, the Government surrendered to the funds and never recovered the $9.5m. Today the nursing homes have no confidence that the funds will meet their obligations and have told the Minister so. I wish to quote at length from a letter from the convenor of the Australian Affiliation of Voluntary Care Associations written to the Minister a fortnight ago:

When your Department sent out notices of recoupment to all Nursing Homes concerned, and courteously notified the S.A. Voluntary Care Association of this action, a meeting was sought with the Health Funds Association in Adelaide. A representative of the Private Hospitals Association was also present as was a representative of your Department. The presence of your officer was extremely helpful as the Health Funds representatives had been quite adamant that you had earlier informed their representative in Canberra that pressure would not be brought to bear for repayment. When faced with irrefutable evidence that Organisations were being pressed for payment, they had to withdraw their earlier 'bluff'.

Around the table, the Health Fund representatives who were present clearly indicated that they had no intention of making payment for these claims at this time or in the near future. It was also stated that they were even questioning the legality of the requirement to pay. When informed that our Organisations were in no position to stand the financial losses involved and consequently would have no alternative but to take legal action against the Funds concerned, they literally laughed in our faces and said that would be fairly futile as such action could be extended over a long time.
There is clear evidence before the Minister that he can have no confidence whatsoever that the funds will meet their obligations in this matter.

The fiasco is the result of the medi-muddle in this country. It derives in fact from the confused and confusing changes in health insurance that are characteristic of the Fraser Government. This Government must accept responsibility for the fiasco, and ensure that nursing homes and nursing home patients do not suffer as a result of the confusion created by the Government. It is quite insufficient for the Minister to claim blandly that the health funds will accept their obligations. He has to use the powers under the National Health Act to ensure that they do.

A second nursing home problem to which I will refer briefly seems to have been revealed by the audit. It is the problem of nursing home proprietors claiming benefits either from the Government or from insurance funds for patients during days when the patients are not in the nursing homes. Clearly this is a case where the nursing home proprietor is at fault for claiming a benefit he is not entitled to receive. Under the law, recovery of these moneys from the nursing home is justified. However, I wish to ask the Minister whether it is just that a nursing home proprietor, having claimed for years benefits on days when the patient was absent, should then seek to recover from the patient the moneys he had to repay? In most cases, the patient is not aware of the improper claim. For instance, I have a bill for $3,353, extending back over four years, which was received by a patient in a nursing home. The old lady was fortunate in that her relatives over the past four years had been able to look after her a couple of weekends in every month and occasionally had been able to take her home for a week. The result of that is a bill for $3,353. I am told by the welfare agencies that this is not an uncommon problem. It raises also the general issue of the coherence of the Government's policy towards the aged. The structure of nursing home benefits imposes a direct financial penalty on the family which seeks to play a role in the care of an old or invalid relative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I think we are becoming quite used to the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) approaching problems and subjects like this with a degree of exaggeration which I think is regrettable. In various Press statements we have seen the figure of $25m bandied about. I have refuted that figure and the honourable member has now described me as being vague, evasive and shallow. But he has not substantiated at all the figures that he has cited. That is regrettable. If we are to have a sound and reasonable argument or discussion about questions of very great concern to a large number of people throughout Australia, all those taking part in the debate must as far as possible stick to the known facts. I believe that would advance a debate which is, as I have said, of immense importance to us all.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Bonython raised two major issues. Unfortunately, he dealt with the second matter very quickly at the end of his speech. I will deal with that first and then move to the major portion of the case presented by the honourable member. In the last part of the honourable member's speech, he talked about the payment of benefits during a patient's absence from a nursing home. He detailed one particular case of which he is aware where an individual patient is being required to pay a considerable amount of money. I will outline to the honourable member and to the House the background to this situation. It is a fact that Commonwealth nursing home benefits are not payable during a patient's absence from a nursing home. That policy was not brought in by the present Government. In fact, it was introduced in 1973 by the now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden). It has continued to apply since that time. All proprietors were made aware of the policy in 1973 and again in 1977, so there is no excuse for their not knowing about it. Since 1973, proprietors have been able to charge a bed retention fee during a patient's absence from a nursing home when the patient requests that the bed be retained. The fee is determined by the proprietor but it cannot exceed the approved daily fee. Proprietors are responsible for advising patients of the fee when a patient wishes to have that bed retained.

One can see the difficulties in this area. Obviously from time to time patients will wish to leave the nursing home and that, of course, will leave beds unoccupied. That will cost the proprietor of a nursing home money. If he moves someone in, that bed is lost to the original patient. Because of the difficulties in the system, representations have been received from a number of patients, both uninsured and insured, who have been asked by the proprietors to repay amounts which the proprietor incorrectly claimed as Commonwealth and fund benefits in respect of periods when the patient was absent from the home. I think it is quite a responsible attitude on the part of the Government not to pay benefits when the patient is not occupying the bed for which the benefit is being paid. It seems from the number of days and amounts involved that the patients may not have been advised by the proprietor that benefits were not payable for periods of absence. The amounts of Commonwealth benefits involved have been recovered. Of course, the recovery of fund benefits is a matter between the proprietor and the fund. There are numbers of matters of concern in relation to this subject; it is not a simple problem. As a matter of urgency the Government is reviewing the position by looking at a number of options which will overcome some of the difficulties. I state quite clearly that there are difficulties. They were recognised by the Labor Government which brought in the original conditions, and they are recognised by myself.

I now return to the original debate, which is in relation to nursing homes and their administration, and the allegation by the honourable member for Bonython that $25m is involved. As I have already stated, I view with concern these sorts of accusations. I think it is fair to say that certain nursing home proprietors have incorrectly made claims on the Government for nursing home benefits. Obviously it is fair to say that, because it has occurred. But to say that this has been caused by confusion on the part of the Federal Department of Health or the government of the day is very far from the truth. The background to the proposition is that, in March 1980, the Department of Health-my Department-commenced an audit to see whether incorrect claims had been lodged with the Department from nursing home proprietors in relation to insured patients. Nothing could be said to be irresponsible about that action. The Department set about auditing the returns to make sure that moneys paid out were correctly paid out. That audit uncovered the fact that some nursing home proprietors had incorrectly made claims on the Department for insured patients.

I point out to the honourable gentleman and to the House that the guidelines for the operation of nursing homes are very clear. Proprietors have been made aware of their responsibilities to use all reasonable endeavours to ascertain the insurance status of patients. Therefore, I believe it is very unfortunate that some proprietors made little or no attempt to find out this information and just billed the Government for these insured patients when the claim should have been made on the private health insurance funds. As I have pointed out, the Government must rely on nursing home proprietors to provide this information correctly. The honourable member for Bonython believes that we should not rely on the proprietors; but, if we did not, we would face a massive expansion in the number of public servants required. We would need an army of public servants roaming around the country checking the insurance status of patients. That result might be dear to the heart of the Opposition, but it is not dear to this Government. We have to look in all of these matters at a form of cost benefit analysis, and the employment of vast numbers of additional public servants is of great concern to the Australian community, and it costs the Australian community a lot of money. We prefer to believe that we can rely upon the proprietors of the nursing homes to work more assiduously to provide the correct information to the Government.

Once the matter was unearthed and it was shown that the nursing home proprietors had not been fulfilling the requirements laid down by the Government, as a Minister of the Crown I had no option but to set in train recovery action because I believe strongly-and I am sure that the honourable member for Bonython would agree with me-that the Government must protect taxpayers' funds. Unfortunately, it is becoming more usual in this sort of matter for the Opposition to start spreading stories about the situation. It brings through this activity undue worry to the occupants of nursing homes and to their families. Let me assure this House that I have instructed my Department to take into account the financial circumstances of individual nursing homes in relation to the timing of the repayments to ensure that recovery action does not jeopardise their viability. All this talk of the Government bringing about the closing down of nursing homes is sheer scaremongery and I believe is not helpful--

TALK.START.PARA: —I doubt whether anyone has said it.

—I have heard it mentioned around the place. I point out to the House that nursing homes are entitled to submit a claim to the patient's health insurance fund for the payment of benefits. The health insurance funds have an obligation to pay these benefits. I am taking appropriate action to ensure that they do. The honourable member for Bonython has a jaundiced view of the response of the health insurance organisations. Perhaps I am filled with more of the milk of human kindness and charity than he is, but I believe they will accept their obligations when they are clearly pointed out to them, as they have been.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to lay to rest the rumour perpetuated by the Opposition as to the actual amount incorrectly paid. As we have heard today, the Opposition has claimed that the amount is $25m. I can assure all honourable members that the figures presented to date to me show that the final figure will be significantly less. On what do I base that statement? I base it simply on this information from my Department. We have heard about South Australia. In New South Wales, 74 out of 492 nursing homes have been checked and amounts totalling $131,327 were identified as owing by health funds. The check is proceeding. In Victoria about 50 per cent of current nursing home patients have been partially checked and amounts totalling $210,000 have been identified as owing by the funds. Recovery action is proceeding as the checks are made. Checks have been completed for all the major funds in Queensland. There are three small funds remaining to be checked and an amount of approximately $910,000 has been identified as owing. In Western Australia, 32 out of 121 homes have been checked and an amount of $117,790 is owing. The checking in Tasmania is almost complete and to date $16,740 is owed.

Those are the figures on which I based my statement that the total figure is considerably less than the $25m that the honourable member for Bonython has been trumpeting around the place. I hope that in the future when I make these statements the honourable member will treat them as I believe they should be treated, that is, as being honest responses to questions. Until the final checks have been completed-I have mentioned this in relation to these last figures-I believe that it would be quite unreal and unfair for anybody to make further statements as to what the final figure will actually be. We must rely upon proper audited figures. To speculate, particularly in the exaggerated way which has been done, about that final figure I do not think is at all helpful. The report of the Auditor-General, which was tabled in the House yesterday, recommended that audits of nursing home benefits payments be undertaken. Of course, we are already doing this. The report was tabled only yesterday and therefore I cannot comment on the various statements made in it. However, it has raised a number of points which must and will be considered by the Government as a matter of urgency.

In its usual fashion the Opposition criticises the Government's achievements in the area of assistance for the aged. The Government is committed to looking after the aged. It is part of its general philosophy of looking after those sections of the community that are least able to look after their own needs.

The Government's critics claim that the Liberal Party is uncaring because it firmly believes that people should be more responsible for their own needs and that governments cannot and should not meet all of the demands that individuals or groups in the community may make upon it. The community knows that the Liberal Party is committed to these philosophical views because it does not believe that governments should be able to tax away peoples' incentive, initiative and drive. We believe very strongly that those who are able to make a contribution should make that contribution. I believe that the community also knows at the same time that the Government believes it has a responsibility for those groups of people who cannot look after themselves. The community knows that only by ensuring that government actions promote a strong and thriving economy based on a viable private sector, will that economy grow. It is only in this way that there will be a growing economic cake that will allow the Government responsibility to provide greater assistance for those in need. If we are to look after those in genuine need, we must have a thriving economy. That is the base from which all resources or benefits can flow. If we do not have that strong economic base, we can have the best policies in the world but we will not be able to put them into effect because we simply will not have the community resources so to do.

The Government has a clear cut policy towards the aged, which is aimed at assisting them. In the health area special arrangements apply for pensioners. For instance, the Commonwealth will meet their medical bills at a cost of over $300m this year. In addition, free public hospital treatment and free pharmaceuticals under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme for pensioners and their dependants are to be provided costing about $195m annually. Contrary to the views of the honourable member for Bonython, the Government has acted in the area of nursing homes particularly. It controls nursing home fee increases to ensure that only justifiable cost increases are passed on to the patients. We have formalised the nursing home benefit arrangements to ensure that benefits are updated annually and set at a level to cover nursing home costs sufficiently for 70 per cent of beds throughout Australia. The benefits were increased in November last year. The Government also meets the approved operating deficits of eligible private, non-profit nursing homes. Considerable assistance is provided by the Commonwealth towards the capital costs of accommodation for the aged. I could go on giving examples. The Commonwealth also provides assistance in the area of home care for the aged such as housekeeping and other domestic assistance, paramedical services, meals on wheels and domiciliary nursing care benefits which, as honourable members will recall, the Government increased from 4 September last year from $2 to $3 a day.

The Government's concern for the aged is, I guess, very well demonstrated by its record in the area of pensions. Pensions are now at record levels in relation to average weekly earnings. We have been able to achieve this result while at the same time adopting a responsible economic policy.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) for raising this matter of Government policy and the application of Government policy in connection with aged people and particularly in connection with nursing homes. I find one of the most depressing aspects of this Government's record in its general approach to welfare to be its approach to the aged. Despite the platitudes that we have just heard from the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar), this Government attempted to repudiate the undertaking it gave to maintain the material standard of aged people in Australia. In that approach it capitulated only in the face of the fact that the community at large was more socially responsible and responsive and had a greater social conscience. Not only aged people but also the community at large indicated that it simply would not tolerate a government which would repudiate the undertaking it had given in relation to the indexation of age pensions.

SPEECH.PARA: Whatever the Minister may say now about the increases that have taken place in age pensions in comparison with average weekly earnings, the fact remains that those increases have come about simply because the Government has been locked into an approach which it had previously taken. I am sure that had the Government been aware of the results of that policy it would not have adopted it in the first place. The Government policy generally towards the aged has been incoherent in its conception. It has been incomprehensible in its purposes and it has been inept in its application. The Minister claimed that this issue had been exaggerated by the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett). If this issue has been exaggerated I wonder very seriously where this Government is going and where government responsibility generally is going. The total amount reflected in the two significant bungles to which the honourable member for Bonython made reference possibly represents about $40m or an amount in excess of that. Added to that is the bungle made by the Minister's Department relating to the overpayment of pharmacists. The list continues. It is all very well for the Minister to try to smooth over this matter with cliches and platitudes but he is responsible in this Parliament-he is the responsible member of the Government-for the operations of the Department of Health and for the very serious deficiencies that exist within that Department. The Opposition and the Opposition spokesman on health matters will permit neither the Minister nor the Government to smooth over the issues that are involved.

The Minister was critical of the estimates made by the honourable member for Bonython in relation to the most recent bungle. The honourable member for Bonython gave three estimates. He explained the basis of their preparation and indicated quite clearly that they have been determined on the basis of information which currently is available to him as a private member of this Parliament. He gave an estimate at the lowest level of $14m, perhaps rising to $25m with a middle figure of $20m. It is all very well for the Minister to criticise the honourable member for Bonython for the responsible and necessary action which he took in attempting to assess, on the basis of the information which was available to him, a sensible figure in relation to the amount that was involved. The Minister himself, with the total resources of the Department available to him, has refused to provide an alternative assessment. All the Minister says is that the final result will be 'significantly less'. Will it be significantly less than $25m, $20m or $14m? The Minister has given some preliminary results from the investigations that have been undertaken in each of the States. On the basis of those results he has still failed to provide an alternative assessment to the one which has been provided by the honourable member for Bonython.

This continuing and compounding confusion commenced in 1976 with the dismantling of Medibank. As I have said it is the second most serious bungle in the health insurance area. I think it reflects on the part of the Government a complete incapacity not only to devise equitable and coherent programs but also to administer the programs which it has devised. On the radio program AM on 17 February this year, when challenged on the wrong payment of millions of dollars to nursing homes which the interviewer referred to as a 'bungle', the Minister said:
Well you can say we paid out the money wrongly. We were acting on information which was given to us and we, in fact, paid out the money on that information.
He went on to say:

To say that this is a bungle I think is really over-stressing the situation because, in fact, it was the Department that found out about the situation and the Department which has for some time been involved in correcting it.

I believe that is an incredible comment by the Minister responsible in this area. The Minister may well adopt that attitude but it is not the attitude which has been adopted by other responsible people in the areas of nursing homes and health welfare. It is not the attitude which has been adopted by spokesmen responsible for interests in these areas. I refer to some comments made by the Australian Affiliation of Voluntary Care Associations. In part, in its approach to the Minister, it stated:
Although the number of individuals concerned is not great, the sum of money which is involved is very considerable since the period of time concerned is a long one.
I should like to emphasise the words: 'The period of time concerned is a long one'. It stated further:
We believe, however, that unless the situation here--
It was referring to South Australia-
is clarified, the same chaos will be produced in other States later.

Just where is the Government going? The Association to which I have just referred said that that situation has been continuing over a long period. This responsible body referred to the situation as one of chaos. In these cases there is a possible overpayment of an amount up to or in excess of $20m. The situation is that it will be extremely difficult for the Department of Health to recoup the funds. This situation has been referred to as one of chaos yet the Minister has the effrontery in this Parliament and publicly to refer to this as some difficulty which he chooses not to identify as a bungle and one, presumably, which could not have been anticipated. I refer briefly to some of the comments in the report of the Auditor-General in relation to the administration of nursing home programs which was tabled in this Parliament yesterday. In its overview of audit conclusions, the report stated:
As a result of its investigations, my Office--
That is, the Office of the Auditor-General-

has formed the view that whilst the Commonwealth Department of Health has, consistent with Government policy, actively sought to identify and cater for community requirements for nursing home accommodation and financial support, its existing systems of management control exhibit weaknesses that give rise to a lack of economy in Commonwealth expenditure and lack of consistency in administration between patients and between proprietors.
It goes on to say:
The Department's control over numbers of nursing home beds is deficient in some respects.
It states further:

Effective interaction between Commonwealth departments . . . in the planning and evaluation of related programs of care for the aged and the infirm is largely absent . . . Better value for the Commonwealth's health and welfare expenditure on the aged and the infirm could be obtained if related services were planned for and evaluated jointly.

So it goes on. Despite the position which the Government and the Minister have adopted in relation to this question I think it reflects the Government's approach which typically has been unresponsive in these important areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is seeking to lay on the Government an allegation that there is a general incoherence in its policy towards the aged. That is what this debate is all about. The Opposition is endeavouring to pin this accusation with the alleged induced confusion over nursing home benefits which has been receiving some publicity in recent times. In other words the basis on which it claims that there is a general incoherence-whatever that means; it seems a fairly incoherent way of criticising the Government-is in fact established by an overpayment to nursing homes. This overpayment naturally relates to the Government department involved taking the word of the proprietors of nursing homes about which patients were in fact insured and which were not insured. If it is a heinous sin to accept the word of these proprietors who may well have been misinformed-perhaps that is a charitable view-then the Government is wickedly guilty. It has in fact taken the word of people in the payment of these benefits. Then, quite properly, the auditor-in other words, in the proper functioning of government-has established that what was said to the Government was not in fact reality. If, as the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) said, the Labor Opposition really wants a horde of Public Service inspectors knocking on the doors or looking in the beds of every nursing home in Australia then its criticsim of the procedures that have been adopted is meaningful. The fact is that it would add massive costs to the provision of nursing home care-it would involve more than the few million dollars referred to today-in Public Service inspectors' wages every year, without fail. In fact what we have here is the proper resolution of a problem. The Government is not pretending that the problem does not exist. The Government in fact has pointed it out. This audit inquiry was commenced in March of last year because the Government in fact was concerned. This is the proper way in which to resolve the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition pretends that this demonstrates that there is some massive incoherence. What is the meaning of the word 'incoherence', which has been used as a fairly smart aleck component of the ridiculous matter of public importance before the House today? I understand that it means inconsequential, inconsistent and not easy to be followed. Let me demonstrate what in fact has happened to the whole area of nursing home activity under this Federal Government. The report of the Auditor-General to which the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) referred so enthusiastically contains a table which shows Commonwealth expenditures on the aged as a percentage of gross domestic product. I must concede that I have not had much time to look at this report because it was released only yesterday. The table shows the position in 1973-74 under the Labor Government, as we all bitterly remember, and the position in 1978-79 under the present Government. According to the table Commonwealth expenditure on the aged as a percentage of gross domestic product has gone up from 2.9 per cent to 4.2 per cent-a massive vote of incoherence. Here we have evidence of a very nice increase in Commonwealth expenditure as a proportion of gross domestic product under the present Government. If that is a matter for us to be criticised about, let the Opposition criticise us. However, this Government has increased the proportion very significantly.

Commonwealth expenditure on the aged as a percentage of total government outlays has gone up from 12.2 per cent to 14.6 per cent. We do not hear those sorts of figures honestly presented by the Opposition when it criticises our efforts in relation to the aged. These are achievements of which I think this Government ought to be proud and which the people of Australia should recognise. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table from the report showing the number of nursing home beds in each State as at June 1973 and June 1980.
Leave granted.
