TALK.START.PARA: —The table shows that the Australian total of nursing home beds has gone from 53,416 to 65,289, a significant increase in the number of nursing home beds available. The number of beds per thousand persons aged 65 or over has been maintained at around 46.7 per cent of the population of 65 or over. So, in effect, the nursing home situation has at least been keeping pace with the requirements of an aged population.

SPEECH.PARA: I recognise that some points of criticism were made in the Auditor-General's report and I think they should be discussed. However, it is interesting to see the dramatic difference in the performance of the States in the provision of nursing home beds. For example, in New South Wales the number of nursing beds per thousand head of population is 52.79 compared with only 37.25 in Victoria. In other words, there are clear differences between the States for a set of reasons which relate to the independent roles of the States themselves. The Victorian Government very sensibly adopts the view that the best way of providing assistance to aged people is in fact to keep them in their own homes. In other words, it supports the concept of home help which is funded on a fifty-fifty basis by the State and Federal governments. Home help is recognised to be far more significant in Victoria than it is in New South Wales, where the State Labor Government would much prefer to shovel the responsibility entirely onto the Federal Government. There is a much more responsible approach in Victoria. The Auditor-General had this to say in his report:

Professional medical and sociological opinion seems to support the view that the aged and the infirm should not be institutionalised except as a last resort, that their general well being, their ability to be self directive and to function effectively is enhanced by a familiar domestic environment.

Some very interesting sections of the report deal with this subject and I commend them to the House. I certainly commend them to the New South Wales Labor Government, which not only generally provides less for home help than the Victorian Government but also, in its latest Budget, reduced the agreed contribution to home help on which it had given the Federal Government an undertaking. The Federal Government had in fact provided a considerable amount; the New South Wales Government originally failed to match it. It had to be pushed screaming to a situation where it eventually matched it. The simple reality of the situation is that it would rather the Federal Government pick up the whole bill for nursing homes than contribute to what I believe is a much better system of home help.

Nonetheless I am concerned that there are some matters in the nursing home care area which need to be fixed up. For example according to the report of the Auditor-General, in the Illawarra region, an area which I represent in part, there were only 24.68 beds per thousand head of population aged 65 and over as at 31 August 1979. Compare that with the figure of 80.75 per thousand head of population in the western metropolitan area of Sydney. I do not believe it is right that my area, which is very much a retirement area, should be disadvantaged in this way. The Auditor-General referred in his report to the methods that are used by the joint Commonwealth-State co-ordinating committee. I want to stress that it is a joint Commonwealth-State committee. There is a degree of integration and co-operation. However, I feel that the methods often adopted by that committee do need improvement. Despite the very low ratio of nursing home beds per thousand head of population in the Illawarra region various applications from the area have been rejected by that joint committee. I believe it is unfortunate that an area already disadvantaged should be further disadvantaged.

No one on this side of the House will pretend that there are no problems in the nursing home area. There certainly are and this is clearly evidenced by the fact that some States have a different awareness of the needs and the importance of nursing homes. The Federal Government has done its job well in providing support for nursing homes. Certainly there are problem areas. I believe these are being solved. Let us recognise that this Government has supported the integrated retirement village concept of a nursing home, a hostel and units. I admit that the concept was initiated by the Opposition when it was in government. However, this Government has supported that principle as well. It seems to me that when we look across the whole structure of assistance for the aged we find that this Government has a record of which it should be proud. It is a record from which no one should seek to withdraw. I suggest that the figures I have used to demonstrate the big increases by this Government in outlays as a proportion of gross domestic product to help the aged is something of which we ought to be proud.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Nixon, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Dairying Research Act 1972 in recognition of changing circumstances in the dairy industry and to conform with current practice in other similar rural research legislation. The Dairying Research Act established the Dairying Research Trust Account and the Dairying Research Committee. The Research Account receives income from the industry research levy, Commonwealth Government matching contributions and other minor sources. Expenditure on research is approved by the Minister on the recommendation of the Research Committee.

Three of the amendments proposed in the Bill have been sought by the Dairying Research Committee and the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation. These changes are expressed in clauses 5 and 6 of the Bill. The Dairying Research Committee is frequently referred to by name in international journals and research papers. Renaming it as the Australian Dairy Research Committee will clearly establish its national identity.

At present three members of the Research Committee represent producers of milk for manufacturing purposes and one member represents producers for the liquid milk market. In view of changed circumstances in the industry this distinction is no longer appropriate and the Bill provides for the four producer members to represent all dairy farmers. To allow casual vacancies on the Research Committee to be filled for the remainder of the term of the member being replaced, the mandatory three-year term will be changed to a period not exceeding three years. Further consequential amendments are necessary to accommodate these changes. Clause 12 provides for transitional arrangements in respect of the renamed Research Committee and its members and their deputies. Clause 11 will amend the Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy Act 1972 to reflect the change in the Research Committee's name.

Other amendments have been drafted to bring the Dairying Research Act into conformity with recent rural research legislation and Government policy. Clause 3 will have the effect of bringing the wording of the provisions for payments into the Research Account into line with similar recent legislation. The original intent of the Act is not changed.

In accordance with established practice Clause 7 amends the arrangements for removal and resignation of Committee members and deputies, while Clause 9 provides for the Remuneration Tribunal to determine the remuneration of members and deputies. Clause 10 will enable the Minister to approve fees, et cetera, payable to persons appointed to advise the Committee. Finally Clause 8 of the Bill introduces the requirement that Research Committee members and their deputies shall disclose direct or indirect pecuniary interests. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Uren) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DRIED VINE FRUITS STABILIZATION LEGISLATION REPEAL BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Nixon, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to terminate the operation of the present Dried Vine Fruits Stabilisation Scheme. The scheme, which applies to dried sultanas produced in the three seasons 1978, 1979 and 1980, provides for grower contributions to a stabilisation fund if the average return received by growers in a season is above the established seasonal base price plus $10 a tonne. If the average return for a season is more than $10 a tonne below the base price, payments are to be made out of the fund to growers.

Growers contributed approximately $1.2m to the fund in respect of the 1978 season, and it has been assessed that further significant payments would also be the ultimate result of the 1979 and 1980 seasons accounting if the scheme were permitted to run its full course. This would be of no advantage to the industry, and would in fact deny growers the use of substantial moneys, which under the legislation would have to be collected from them in due course for these two seasons, as grower contributions to the fund. Growers would then have to wait for the winding up of the fund at the end of the stabilisation term before these moneys could be refunded to them. Such refunds could probably not be made before well into 1982.

The Government has therefore accepted a request from the industry that legislation be introduced to terminate the scheme and to authorise refund to the contributing growers of the moneys presently in the sultanas stabilisation fund. The moneys contributed by growers in respect of the 1978 season have been invested, the last maturity date of such investments being 1 October 1981. After consultation with the growers' organisation-the Australian Dried Fruits Association-the Government has made provision in the Bill for the investments to continue until their maturity. In this way a considerable amount of interest will be earned, and no risk will be incurred of loss of capital value through early redemption. After all investments have matured, all moneys standing to the credit of the fund are to be distributed among growers in proportion to each grower's share of the total contributed by growers. A formula is set out in the Bill for the purpose of establishing the amount payable to each grower.

The Bill also makes provision to enable the payments to growers to be made through the system already established for the making of stabilisation payments. I expect that payments to growers will be completed about the end of 1981. In anticipation of inquiry by honourable members as to possible on-going price support arrangements for this industry, I point out that discussions are proceeding with the industry designed to conclude mutually acceptable provisions for an underwriting scheme commencing with the 1982 season. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Uren) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPLE AND PEAR EXPORT UNDERWRITING BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Nixon, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill provides for the underwriting of returns from all export market sales of apples and pears over the five seasons 1981 to 1985. The Bill, together with the associated Apple and Pear Stabilisation Amendment Bill 1981 and the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Amendment Bill 1981 implement the Government's decision to vary the market support arrangements for export apples and pears following the inquiry last year by the Industries Assistance Commission into the assistance needs of the apple and pear industry beyond 1980. The Government accepted the IAC's recommendation that continuing price support assistance for apple and pear exports should in future be related to actual price experience on export markets, but that the existing cost of production based price support under the stabilisation scheme for apple exports be phased out gradually to avoid undue disruption in the industry.

Honourable members will be aware that the existing Apple and Pear Stabilisation Scheme was introduced in 1971. The then Minister for Primary Industry's second reading speech indicated that the intention of the stabilisation scheme was to give a measure of stability to the industry to assist it to examine and take steps to meet the adjustment problems then confronting it. In the ten years that the scheme has operated, payments to growers have totalled $22.6m of which the Commonwealth contributed $22.3m. Nearly all the assistance has been paid in respect of apples. It has always been acknowledged that the stabilisation scheme would not provide solutions to all the industry's problems. Honourable members will also be aware that the industry had the advantage of the Fruitgrowing Reconstruction Scheme which operated from 1973 to 1978.

During the 1970s the industry has gone a long way to meeting its adjustment needs. Total Australian apple and pear production has declined by about 30 and 40 per cent respectively; exports now account for some 15 per cent of production instead of about 30 per cent; a bigger share of the exports go to the more profitable 'forward sale' markets in South East Asia and the Middle East; and there is less dependence on the relatively unprofitable 'at risk' markets in Europe. Further adjustment is expected to take place in the next few years. However, with the development of alternative export outlets outside Europe, continued growth in domestic demand and the development of processing outlets, future adjustment is unlikely to be as great or of the same nature as the adjustment of the past ten years.

Looking back, I can confidently state that the stabilisation scheme has met its objective of providing a measure of 'breathing space' to growers facing difficult adjustment problems. However, as observed by the IAC, the stabilisation scheme has also had the effect of distorting market signals for export fruit and continuation of the scheme on an unchanged basis could now prejudice the successful completion of the necessary adjustment process. The changes which the Government will be introducing to the existing stabilisation scheme will be dealt with in more detail in my second reading speech on the Associated Apple and Pear Stabilisation Amendment Bill 1981.

There is one further aspect of the package of assistance arrangements which will apply to the apple and pear industry to which I should refer. In addition to the underwriting arrangements for apples and pears and continuance of the stabilisation scheme for apples on a phasing-out basis for four years to 1984 the Commonwealth is to continue to provide supplementary assistance on a dollar for dollar basis with participating States over that 4-year period. The Commonwealth commitment is for a maximum of $3m to be provided over this period in respect of apples and $800,000 for pears. The use of the assistance is to be flexible and available to fund orchard reconstruction and related adjustment measures for growers particularly affected by the changed market support arrangements for 'at risk' exports. It may also be used to provide additional 'at risk' export price support assistance for apples but not for pears. The Government has placed a ceiling of $750,000 of Commonwealth funds and a maximum pay-out per box of $2.20 that may be used to supplement export price support for apples in 1981, these maxima to be reduced by one-quarter in each of the three succeeding years. The Commonwealth is currently discussing with the States proposals on the form and the amount of supplementary assistance to be provided.

I should now like to deal briefly with the specific provisions of the Export Underwriting Bill. For each of the 1981 to 1985 export seasons, separate guaranteed minimum return levels will be established by this Bill for apple exports and for pear exports. The guaranteed minimum returns will be determined by calculating 95 per cent of the weighted average per box free on board return for all apple exports, and for all pear exports, over the immediately preceding four export seasons. At the close of each export season, the Bill provides for the determination of the average per box f.o.b. export return for all apple exports in that season, and another for pears. In the event that either of these average per box f.o.b. returns falls below the relevant guaranteed minimum return, then this Bill provides that an underwriting payment is made, such payment being the difference between the guaranteed minimum return and the relevant average per box f.o.b. return. Underwriting payments shall be made, in the case of fruit exported 'at risk', to the owner of the fruit at the time of export, and in the case of fruit sold before export, to the owners of the fruit prior to that sale. Unlike the stabilization legislation, this Bill does not provide for payments into the scheme by growers; the underwriting arrangements are to be financed solely by the Commonwealth. As with the stabilization scheme, assistance payments under the underwriting scheme will be made through the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation. The package of market support measures decided upon by the Government will provide a good basis on which the industry can develop to meet the changing marketing circumstances confronting it. As part of that package I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Uren) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPLE AND PEAR STABILIZATION AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Nixon, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill introduces amendments to the Apple and Pear Stabilization Act 1971 as part of the package of market support measures for the industry that I have just outlined in my speech on the Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Bill 1981. The principal stabilisation Act is extended by this Bill to cover apple exports for the four export seasons 1981 to 1984. The stabilisation scheme for pears is not to be extended. Stabilisation assistance for apples will continue to apply only to exports shipped at some degree of risk to markets in Europe, including the United Kingdom. The maximum rate of stabilisation assistance for apples for the 1981 export season is to be $2.20 per box, the same as applied in both the 1979 and 1980 export seasons. In 1982 the maximum is to be reduced to $1.65 per box, in 1983 to $1.10 and in 1984 to 55c. This maximum rate is to be payable on a maximum of 1.5 million boxes of apples in each season. In the event that more than 1.5 million boxes of apples are exported 'at risk' to Europe in any year then the maximum per box payout is to be reduced proportionately.

This Bill provides that in the event that both a stabilisation payment and an underwriting payment become payable then the stabilisation payment is reduced by the amount of the underwriting payment. The principal stabilisation Act is further amended to terminate the grower 'pay-in' provisions and to allow for winding up the varietal trust funds. The Bill also provides for the updating of the levels of penalties provided under the Act so as to bring them into line with those provided under the Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Bill 1981. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Uren) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN APPLE AND PEAR CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Nixon, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill introduces an amendment to the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Act 1973 consequential to the Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Bill 1981 to allow the Corporation to incur expenses in operating the underwriting arrangements. The opportunity is also being taken to bring the taxation liability of the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation into line with that of other statutory commodity authorities in the primary industry area, and to make a few technical amendments to the Corporation Act. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Uren) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howard, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the Currency Act 1965 to empower the Treasurer to issue a $10 silver coin. On 2 May 1980, the then Acting Treasurer announced that the Government had decided to issue three coins with special designs to commemorate the occasion of the XII Commonwealth Games to be held in Brisbane in 1982. He further stated that the 1982 commemorative coins would be a $200 face value 'collector' gold coin, a 50 cent cupro-nickel coin, and, subject to the passage of necessary authorising legislation, a $10 cupro-nickel coin.

It has now been decided that the proposed $10 Commonwealth Games coin be struck in 92.5 per cent silver, that is, sterling silver. The Commonwealth Games Foundation had originally proposed that the $10 coin be in silver. At the time the very high and volatile price of silver suggested that a $10 silver coin would not be practicable and it was then proposed that the coin be in cupro-nickel. Since the announcement last May, the extreme speculative influences on the price of silver have been removed. In addition, the practice has been established with the $200 collector gold coin of setting the price of a collector coin well above its face value. It is intended that this practice will be followed in the case of the silver coin. It is envisaged that the $10 silver coin will have a diameter of about 34 millimetres-that is, slightly larger than the 50 cent coin-and that it will weigh about 20 grams.

If the Bill is enacted in the current sittings of Parliament, it is expected that the Royal Australian Mint will commence minting the $10 Commonwealth Games coin in the second half of this year. The special designs for the reverse sides of the three Commonwealth Games coins have not yet been selected. Further details of these coins, including arrangements for their release, will be announced at a later date. In view of the ever-present legislative burden on Parliament, the opportunity is also being taken to provide in this Bill for greater flexibility in the types of coins that can be issued in the future without the need for additional legislation. Accordingly, the Bill provides for the issue of new denominations of coins and their standard compositions to be prescribed by regulation and will authorise the Treasurer of the day to cause any such coins to be made and issued. These amendments do not, of course, affect the Parliament's power to veto any such regulations that may be brought forward.

I now outline the main provisions of the Bill. Clauses 3 and 4 of the Bill will amend sections 13 and 14 of the Currency Act to provide for the composition of existing coins to be varied by regulation and for the denominations and composition of new coins to be prescribed by regulation. At present the denominations and standard compositions of coins are specified in the Act. These amendments will avoid the need to amend the Act each time a new denomination of coin is to be introduced or the composition of an existing coin is to be varied.

Clause 5 will amend section 14A of the Act to allow the issue price of the proposed $10 coin that is to be issued in the first instance as a silver commemorative coin for the 1982 Commonwealth Games to be determined by the Treasurer in the same way as he is at present authorised to determine the issue price for gold coins. Because of the potential volatility in the price of silver and production and marketing factors it is not practicable to set in advance of the legislation the price at which the $10 coin is to be issued. For similar reasons, this amendment will also empower the Treasurer to determine the issue price of any new coins of a denomination exceeding $10 that may be prescribed.

Section 16 of the present Act provides that the tender of coins up to certain values is a legal tender in discharge of a debt. Clause 6 will amend that section to place a limit of $100 on the legal tendering of coins of the proposed denomination of $10 and, in the case of any new coin of a denomination exceeding 50c but under $10, a limit of 10 times the face value of the coin. Any new coin of a denomination exceeding $10 will be a legal tender for payment of any amount. This clause complements the proposed amendment of section 14 by providing for appropriate legal tender values to be accorded coins of any new denomination that may be prescribed by regulation without the need for a further amendment of the Act. Clause 7 will amend the Schedule to the Principal Act to provide for the introduction of the $10 coin and to specify its standard composition as 92.5 per cent silver and 7.5 per cent other metal. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Uren) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hunt, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

On 22 May last I introduced the Shipping Registration Bill 1980 and proposed that it lie on the table of the House for comment. That Bill of course lapsed but many submissions were received in relation to it and these have resulted in the preparation of a revised Bill which I now introduce. In view of the fact that the Shipping Registration Bill is an important step forward in the development of Australia's status as an independent nation I propose to reiterate many of the points made when introducing the legislation in the previous Parliament.

The right of a country to determine the conditions for the grant of its nationality to ships is fundamental to its national sovereignty. In international law the nationality of ships is determined by the flag they are entitled to fly. It is also customary to require at least the larger ships to be registered in order to secure the right to fly the national flag. The present law governing the registration of ships in Australia was enacted by the Parliament at Westminster 87 years ago. Indeed, it is contained in Part I of the Merchant Shipping Act 1894. Originally that law applied throughout the British Empire on the basis that a ship was a British ship if it was owned by a British subject or corporation in any part of the Empire. The Act required all British ships to be registered except certain small ships of less than 15 tons carrying capacity. Registration could be effected at any British port of registry throughout the Empire and this entailed the entry of particulars of the ship and of its owners and mortgagees in the register at the port. The registrar at the port was required to transmit returns at regular intervals to the Registrar-General of Shipping and Seamen at Cardiff and in that way a complete record of all British ships was built up. However this procedure has been abandoned in recent years.

From the commencement of the Statute of Westminster 1931, the various member countries of the British Commonwealth were free to repeal the Merchant Shipping Act 1894 and to establish their own shipping registers. However, under an agreement negotiated in 1931 the laws of each country were required to adopt a common status of 'British ship' and to follow closely the provisions of Part I of the Merchant Shipping Act 1894. By mutual agreement in 1978 the British Commonwealth Merchant Shipping Agreement 1931 was rescinded by all member countries. Australia is the only major independent member of the Commonwealth, other than Britain itself, to have continued to operate under the Merchant Shipping Act system. The stage has now been reached where it is essential that we put an end to this anachronism. The Commonwealth countries have recently agreed on common principles for the future operation of their own shipping registers. In accordance with those principles the United Kingdom is expected to confine the Merchant Shipping Act system to Britain, to ships more than 50 per cent owned by residents of Britain or companies based in Britain. It is understood that the adoption by Australia of its own national system will simplify the task being undertaken by the British authorities.

The principles underlying the present Bill have been the subject of extensive discussion with the States and the Northern Territory in the Marine and Ports Council of Australia. Their views were taken into account in the framing of the legislation. In recent discussions in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, agreement has been reached on the form of the clause relating to the preservation of State and Territory laws and that revised clause relating to the preservation of State and Territory laws appears in the Bill.

I turn now to a description of the main features of the Bill. Firstly, the Bill repeals Part I of the Merchant Shipping Act 1894 insofar as it is part of the law of Australia, thus terminating Australia's reliance on the British legislation and clearing the way for the adoption of an appropriate Australian system. Secondly, the provisions spell out the ships that are eligible for Australian registration, either on a compulsory or on a voluntary basis. The main elements are: Defence Force ships are excluded and registration is compulsory only for Australian-owned commercial ships of 12 metres or more in length, other than certain government ships, fishing vessels and pleasure craft; Australian-owned ships for which registration is not compulsory may be registered on a voluntary basis and also ships under 12 metres in length that are owned or operated by Australian citizens or residents may be registered; and registration is also permitted in the case of foreign-owned ships that are demise chartered to Australian interests.

The procedures for registration, including the evidence of ownership required, the division of property in the ship into 64 shares, issuing of registration certificates and of provisional certificates, and the naming and marking of the ship have been made broadly comparable with the British system to ensure that the changeover from that system to the Australian system can be effected with a minimum of inconvenience for shipowners. The same can be said of the provisions of Part III of the Bill which deal with transfer and transmission of title and the registration and priority of mortgages.

The flag proposals for Australian ships were arrived at after considerable public discussion. In the Australian Merchant Navy there was strong support for the continued use of the Australian Red Ensign. Therefore it is proposed to declare the Australian Red Ensign the national colours for Australian merchant ships. Regarding other ships the general opinion was that they should be allowed to fly either the Australian National Flag or the Australian Red Ensign. This was accepted on the condition that the two flags would not be flown simultaneously. Complementary amendments to the Flags Act 1953 and the Navigation Act 1912 are necessary. The Flags Amendment Bill and the Navigation Amendment Bill are being introduced for that purpose. Apart from these flags, which until now have been covered by a mixture of British and Australian laws, the British Admiralty has issued individual warrants to certain members of some 16 yacht clubs in Australia, authorising them to wear the British Blue Ensign, either undefaced or in a defaced form. The British Blue Ensign is similar to the Australian National Flag but without the stars. Approximately 400 Australian yacht owners have been issued with such warrants. This causes some difficulty as under the Geneva Convention on the High Seas 1958, to which Australia is a party, ships have the nationality of the country whose flag they are entitled to fly.

These international requirements apply particularly to the high seas. It is possible to permit departure from the Convention requirement in the Australian territorial sea and internal waters. In view of the concern expressed by yacht owners who presently have Blue Ensign warrants, the Bill will allow them to continue to fly that flag in Australian waters so long as British law allows them to fly the flag. The Bill also preserves the use of the flag of a State or Territory in Australian waters and contains provisions in respect of flag rights for unregistered Australian ships.

The provisions of Parts IV and V of the Bill set out the broad administrative arrangements for the establishment and operation of the Australian Register of Ships. In this area there are some significant departures from the present system. The proposed Australian system is basically a centralised system in that there will be only one register. The Bill provides that the Register and copies of the Register or such part or parts of the Register as the Minister directs shall be kept at such places as the Minister directs. It also provides that there shall be, at such a place in Australia as the Minister determines, an Australian Shipping Registration Office and such number of branch registration offices as the Minister determines. This is a flexible arrangement and it enables a certain amount of decentralisation. However, it does not suffer from the disadvantage of the present system in Australia under which there is a separate register at each of 20 ports of registry and the complete record of all ships registered in Australia is not available at any one place. One consequence of that change is that there will be no ports of registry as such. However, because of the importance of the port of registry concept for legal and other purposes, the Bill makes provision for the adoption of a concept of home port for each ship and the regulations will spell this out in greater detail including the practice of continuing to mark the port on the ship's stern.

Part VI of the Bill contains a number of miscellaneous provisions including power to remove unqualified ships from the Register and the provision of penalties for offences. It also includes the clauses relating to the preservation of State and Territory laws and the review of decisions of the Minister or the Registrar by the courts or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Finally, the Bill contains transitional provisions that have been framed in such a way as to minimise any inconvenience to the owners and mortgagees of ships registered in Australia under the Merchant Shipping Act. On the commencement date the existing registers will be deemed to form part of the Australian Register and no further action will be required of owners or mortgagees in order to effect the transition to the Australian Register. The Australian Register will of course make use of modern procedures, equipment and documentation and ships will be progressively transferred over to the new documentation after the commencement date. As I mentioned, this Bill is an important step forward in the development of our status as an independent nation. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Morris) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hunt, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Flags Amendment Bill is a small Bill to complement the Shipping Registration Bill 1981 and the Navigation Amendment Bill 1981. The only amendment of substance is made to Schedule 1 of the Flags Act 1953, which contains the description of the Australian National Flag. The new wording to be inserted in that Schedule will describe both the Australian National Flag and the Australian Red Ensign. This is necessary because at present the description of the Australian Red Ensign is partly contained in section 406 of the Navigation Act 1912, which is being repealed by the Navigation Amendment Bill 1981.

One consequence of this adjustment is that the present reference to the British Blue Ensign in describing the Australian National Flag is removed. This means that the description of the Australian flags stands on its own and does not rely on reference to the flag of another country. Other changes proposed in the amending Bill are of a drafting nature only. I refer honourable members also to the remarks I made in my second reading speech on the Shipping Registration Bill on the question of flags to be worn by Australian ships. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Morris) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hunt, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The principal purpose of the Navigation Amendment Bill 1981 is to amend the Navigation Act so as to accord with the proposed Shipping Registration Act. The Shipping Registration Bill which I have just introduced provides for the prescribing of the national colours to be flown by Australian ships and therefore the Navigation Amendment Bill repeals an overlapping provision in the Navigation Act.

Many provisions of the Navigation Act refer to British ships and, in particular, the whole of Part II is expressed to apply only to British ships except where a contrary intention appears. These references to British ships are being replaced with references to ships registered in Australia under the Shipping Registration Act or otherwise having a close connection with Australia. Schedule 2 to the Bill contains many of these consequential amendments. Australia's withdrawal from the British Commonwealth Merchant Shipping Agreement 1931, which took effect in 1979, is an added reason for making these changes. Provisions of the Navigation Act relating to the tonnage measurement of ships refer to ships registered in Australia under the Merchant Shipping Act. There is a similar reference in section 411 of the Act. These provisions are being replaced with references to the Shipping Registration Act.

A second purpose of the Bill is to update the offence provisions of the Navigation Act and to ensure that the penalties prescribed are appropriate to present-day conditions. These amendments are made by clause 44 and Schedule 3 to the Bill. Some of the amendments affect sections of the principal Act introduced in 1979 or 1980 that are not yet in force. Special commencement arrangements are required for these provisions and are contained in sub-clause 2(5) and Schedule 1 to the Bill.

The general purpose of these amendments is to update the level of pecuniary penalties in line with present money values. At the same time opportunity has been taken to repeal offences that are not relevant to present-day conditions or that are now covered by the general criminal law. Other improvements are the provision of higher pecuniary penalties for offences by corporations and the provision of indictable offences that can be dealt with summarily if the parties and the court all agree.

The Bill also makes a number of minor adjustments that are considered to be appropriate at this time. An example of this is contained in clause 6, which adjusts the Minister's power of delegation. Another example is in paragraph 3 (2) (c) of the Bill, which adjusts the definition of 'ship' in relation to off-shore industry mobile units that are not self-propelled. Finally, the Bill proposes to insert into the Act a power to exempt ships from one or more of the provisions of the Act where the ships come within the jurisdiction of the Act only infrequently-for example, where they have to undergo a single interstate voyage. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Morris) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROVISION OF ARMY HOUSING AT TOWNSVILLE, QUEENSLAND

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Provision of Army housing at Townsville, Queensland.

The proposal is for the provision of 120 married quarters, each of three bedrooms, to be occupied by soldiers of the 3rd Task Force. Question resolved in the affirmative.
Sitting suspended from 1.4 to 2.15 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 December, on motion by Mr Spender:
That the following Address-in-Reply to the Speech of His Excellency the Governor-General be agreed to:
May it please Your Excellency:

We, the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to Our Most Gracious Sovereign, and to thank Your Excellency for the Speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.
Upon which Mr Kent had moved by way of amendment:
That the following words be added to the Address: ', but note that the Government:
(1) has failed to adequately respond to-
(a) record unemployment;
(b) a high and worsening level of inflation:
(c) reduced and falling family living standards; and
(d) the highest taxation burden in the nation's history;
(2) allows unsatisfactory administration of foreign investment guidelines which permit an uncritical and open-door policy to the takeover of Australian industry and resources to continue; and

(3) makes no long-term provision for assistance to manufacturing industry and farming industries, which are likely to be severely disadvantaged as a result of successive exchange rate revaluations and substantially increased imports in the context of resources development'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, it is always a privilege to participate in the Address-in-Reply debate in this House. Equally, it is a privilege to represent the electorate of Franklin. Franklin is an average electorate that could be regarded as reflecting across the board the problems facing people in all Australian electorates today. I was particularly interested in the remarks of the Governor-General when he said in his Speech that the Government is committed to a range of social security and welfare measures which will strengthen the family and through it the basic social fabric of this country. Already the Government has introduced a number of measures designed to assist the family. There are many others that need to be introduced. I can understand that the Treasury dollar can go only so far. Therefore, as a member of this House, one must fight tenaciously to make absolutely certain that the people in need in the community are the ones who receive assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said on many occasions that the Department of Social Security has many grave problems to combat. The care of the sick and the aged and the protection of the welfare of the needy in the community are becoming extremely complex. One can argue the political point, but far too many arguments are based on political points. We find that we get ourselves locked into a situation in which all we do is talk and fight. I am afraid that a great number of people in the community who have problems suffer as a result of the form of those arguments. During times of high inflation, people on fixed incomes have been adversely affected. The backlash of that has been spelt out over and over again in this House. Admittedly, although inflation is decreasing we still have a difficult situation.

The unfortunate aspect of high unemployment already has been mentioned in this debate. Regrettably when people cannot get jobs the social implications flow right back through the family unit and thus many people are affected adversely. Over the years I have been involved in politics it has been sad to find that the parents of young people who cannot find employment suffer also. The young people are affected psychologically, but the parents also suffer. Unfortunately it has been one of the gravest problems tearing at the social fabric of Australia for many decades. It is only natural that when children cannot find employment there are problems. Those problems have flowed right through the family.

The Government has introduced many measures to overcome this situation but, unfortunately, there are reasons-and they are fairly well known-why we have not been able to overcome those problems completely. It saddens me to think that there are so many elderly and sick people in the community who are unable to afford repairs to their homes or are unable to afford people to assist when they need assistance. A very simple example is that of mowing lawns. Yet, on the other hand, there are many young people who would love to do something constructive but unfortunately they cannot be harnessed in such a way as to overcome those sorts of problems.

There are two schools of thought about this matter. One school of thought suggests we should not introduce compulsory national service or compulsory schemes where people would be paid to do certain work, and the other believes they should be involved in community affairs to a degree and not get paid. We all know those arguments; we have discussed them many times in this House. Unfortunately, we are never able to come to a consensus about the matter. Consequently, sometimes the young people of Australia head in a direction that we can only term as being down the path of self destruction. We need to do more about it; we need to talk more about it.

Last night I listened with interest to my colleague the honourable member for Wilmot (Mr Burr) who talked about restructuring government. He talked about more participation by members, et cetera. I agreed with some of the sentiments that he expressed but I did not agree with others because I thought he was taking the easy way out. It is very easy for a backbencher to say that if he does not toe the line he will not get all the little bits and pieces. I do not think that is relevant because, in this arena, one has to fight for what one believes in. If a backbencher fights and believes he has been defeated on a certain point, he should come back for more. He does not look for the easy way out, because there is no easy way out in this political arena. Therefore, in regard to the unemployment problem we need to work together to a degree and not to try to take political points off each other when this matter is discussed. We should not use certain statistics from our own areas to embarrass someone else who is earnestly trying to overcome the problem, because, as we all know, the electorates of Australia vary considerably. Each electorate is different. Some we term 'blue ribbon' electorates, where unemployment is not so high, and others, such as my own, are ordinary electorates in comparison and have all those sorts of problems. I am glad my friend the honourable member for Wilmot has come into the House. All the electorates are different, so we need to start to talk together. I hope we may be able to overcome those problems and stop some of the bitterness that occurs when we start talking about one of those subjects.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will have to talk to Malcolm.

—I have already spoken to Malcolm. I will speak to anyone if I think I am right. That will not stop me. I am sure the earnest desire of this Government-I am sure of all governments-is to ensure that people in need receive fair and adequate treatment. Sometimes that is extremely difficult to achieve. Unfortunately, in our society many do not require assistance but nevertheless derive it, although it should be redirected to the needy. We are all aware of the millions of dollars that have been misused as a result of certain social security activities and of how the Government searches out those who abuse the system and thus decrease the benefits that could and should flow to others who are genuinely in need. I suppose we have to live with it because not everybody is fair, not everybody cares for his neighbour, and not everybody cares for the needy. They pretend to; they talk about it; and they use it as a platform for themselves: But that is all they do. When it comes to getting their hands dirty and trying to overcome a problem, they are left wanting. I am afraid that there are far too many like that in Australia. I would like to direct a little barb at some of the social welfare workers with whom I get involved. All they can do is talk and, when they are put to the real test, they cannot measure up to it. They cannot overcome the problems and they are afraid to work in some of the areas in which I have to work. I am afraid we have far too many talkers and not enough workers. It is up to the politicians to do a tremendous amount more than merely give lip service. They should fight on a political level to overcome some of the problems I have mentioned.
—You have fought hard.

—Yes, I have fought hard. I thank my colleague, the honourable member for Braddon. He is a genuine fellow and he knows a genuine attempt to overcome these problems. Like most politicians, to a certain degree I have been involved with the problems of the elderly pensioners in my community. Unfortunately, some live in sub-standard homes which are structurally inferior and to some degree are infested with pests and vermin. That statement has been echoed by many reports. It is estimated that over 100,000 persons living in Australia are in a difficult situation. It is estimated that 24,000 people over the age of 60 are living in houses or flats that are completely beyond repair. I think one can derive from those figures the fact that we have a massive job to do and that continual political arguing will not overcome the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: I plead again with people who, for one reason or another, derive social welfare benefits unlawfully to think carefully of those elderly people who live in what can only be termed shocking conditions. In some cases it can be argued that those conditions are partly their own fault and, of course, all people are not the same. However, in the majority of cases, the result has been determined by circumstances. I repeat that it could have resulted from their having reared large families, from sickness or from ill-luck that they are in such difficult straits today. We cannot continue to use as an example that that person did something or other and therefore deserves what he or she gets. We have to look more deeply at that problem, be more compassionate and not use the same rule for everybody. It is up to every politician in this Parliament to realise the needs of those people and help them to overcome their problems.

Again, we are faced with the problems of those people living in nursing homes. It is estimated that approximately 56,000 people live in such institutions. I have mentioned on many occasions that Australia has a greater number of nursing home beds per 1,000 head of population than any other country. It shows an extraordinary weakness in our civilisation that we have so many selfish people-I use the word 'selfish' deliberately-who unfortunately cannot wait to get rid of their elderly relatives and put them into nursing homes. That problem could be argued but we must realise that if we are to maintain the strong family unit we must be absolutely certain and be very careful about what we do with our elderly parents.

Like all other politicians, I visit senior citizens' homes, nursing homes, et cetera, and it saddens me to see some of those lonely people who are young really and who have been placed in those homes. I am afraid that some of their families should hide their faces in shame. This is not the case on all occasions because I know that some elderly people cannot be looked after by their families; so they have to go to a certain place to be looked after properly. But some families are selfish. Consequently, we as a government are faced with the massive problem of trying to direct funds to the people who really need them when, in fact, funds are sometimes being wasted by other people.

The elderly become sick, difficult to handle and, of course, create many problems for the children; so the children have no alternative and many of them are very sad indeed to place their mothers or fathers in nursing homes. I am sure that the standard in most nursing homes is good. Most of the staff realise that it is a difficult job and that it requires compassion and, of course, time. But growing old can have many grave problems. Therefore I ask everybody to consider carefully the problems of the aged to make absolutely certain that we do all within our power to direct the necessary funds and make the necessary commitment to overcome some of their problems because those problems are real. We have to search for them and make certain that we understand them.

It saddens me when I go to many senior citizen functions to find that there is a predominance of ladies who have lost their husbands through death. They have been left alone. All the males in Australia must consider not only that the ladies are living a lot longer but also that they are being faced with massive problems when their husbands go. They cannot look after their homes or do the normal things their husbands would have done for them. Therefore, we have to be very careful to make sure that we understand what is occurring in our community and make certain that we overcome these problems.

There are many fine lobby groups which represent the elderly people. Their publicity machines are permanently primed, they respond with quickness to Press inquiries, they can quickly submit evidence to a government inquiry and they co-operate and know exactly what to do and where to strike on a critical point. I think they realise that the only way they can overcome the massive problems of the aged in this country is to fight on a political basis. Of course, at times we are plagued and inundated with people trying to make us provide funds. I know that Ministers are plagued in this way. But we have to be very careful to make sure that the people who receive the funds are those who deserve them. We have to make sure that some of the worthy organisations hiding in the backwoods receive those funds. As politicians we must make certain that Ministers are aware of that.

I now turn to the family. After being personally involved with single parent families, and to a degree with others in this House in campaigning for payments to lone fathers, I became even more aware of some of the disadvantages suffered by many children of single parent families. The difficulties of raising a family today are increasing, as is the incidence of family breakdown. The children of one parent families are becoming increasingly more vulnerable, although in most cases through no fault of the parent. In many cases the children are obliged to be left alone for long periods. I have found instances of poor diet, lack of warm clothing and emotional problems largely created by the unhappiness or loss of morale of the parent as a result of the breakdown of the marriage. Children need a great deal of personal care and attention if they are to grow up as adults willing and able to contribute to this society. Security and stability are, therefore, essential. There is a strong link between the experiencing of such problems and the high incidence of unemployment or employment difficulties among some young people.

In many cases lone parent families suffer a high degree of social and economic disadvantage. As a country, we need to be more aware of family breakups. We need to re-educate the general public and to alert the people of Australia to the fact that this continual breakdown of marriages is having a disastrous effect not only on the young and the parents but also it is unfortunately having a grave effect on the economy of this country. The economy can only stand a certain amount of disruption. When we have these continual breakdowns every day, somebody has to pay somebody to help somebody else. If it is a breakdown between the mother and the father usually she is left with the children and needs assistance from the Government. Now there is a benefit which can be paid also to the lone father. The problem goes on and on and it is becoming more and more dangerous to our economy as each year goes by. Therefore, I am a great advocate of the need to increase family allowances.

It is argued that the Government cannot afford to do so. Of course, there is a reason for that argument. But if we increase family allowances, we may be able to get the mothers to stay at home and look after their children a little more, which may help to keep the family together. I know that situation is not perfect and that some honourable members on the other side of the House can smile about it. I know that it is not a Utopian situation but at least this is a thrust which we should try. As the family structure is breaking down we, as a Government, are beginning to argue about all the things occurring but we are not achieving anything. By directing increased family allowances to the family, we might be able to overcome the problems that I have mentioned. I and many other members in this House know that there are grave problems. If we apply more funds in that direction we may be able to overcome these problems.

I repeat that I am a great advocate of increased family allowances. Many honourable members on my side of the House may disagree or agree with me, but I believe that if we are to overcome the problems we need to analyse carefully what some people are saying, namely, that we should not increase family allowances because that will have an adverse effect on the economy. We must look more deeply at the problem and realise that many people are affected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. It is not proper for an honourable member to attribute falsely to another member of this House remarks which that member never made. The honourable member for Franklin has deliberately misrepresented the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) in remarks he very quietly made.
—I never mentioned the Leader of the Opposition.
—I ask for those remarks to be withdrawn.
—Why would I mention the Leader of the Opposition?
—Order! The honourable member for Franklin will resume his seat.
—He does not even come into my reckoning.
—Order! The honourable member for Franklin will resume his seat. There is a point of order before the Chair. The Chair is not in a position--
—No, wait!

—Order! The honourable member for Franklin will resume his seat. I will rule on the point of order. The Chair is not in a position to know whether the remarks attributed to an honourable member were made or not made. If the honourable member in question feels that he has been misrepresented, he will have an opportunity to claim that he has been misrepresented and to seek the indulgence of the Chair to clear--
—It is a false accusation. I never mentioned the Leader of the Opposition. Why would I?
—Order! The honourable member for Franklin will remain silent.
—I am sorry.
—I call the honourable member for Franklin.

—I have lost the train of my thought after that stupid interjection. The other point I make is that by the year 2000 we could have zero population growth in this country. The great socialists opposite can laugh, but when we think that 60,000 babies are aborted and when we start talking about the family, some people are very hypocritical because they do not really want families in Australia. They want there to be no children at all. Some women want children. Some women within the Australian Labor Party seem to advocate that principle quite firmly. So, please, I do not want to hear any of those women talk about what we should be doing for the family because in doing so they destroy the very fundamental of the family. Mr Deputy Speaker, I thank you for allowing me to reply to the Governor-General's Speech. I also thank my colleagues for listening to my speech so intently. I hope that they have learned something.

— Order! Before calling the honourable member for Burke I draw the attention of the House to the fact that the honourable member is about to make his maiden speech. I ask that the traditional courtesy be extended to him and that he be heard in silence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to begin by thanking all the people in the electorate of Burke who supported me and assisted in my election. I am grateful to all the members of the Australian Labor Party in Burke and to the people at the Melbourne head office who worked very hard during the campaign. I would also like to pay tribute to my predecessor, Mr Keith Johnson who, as Deputy Whip, made a considerable contribution to the Labor Party in Parliament. I wish to begin my speech in the Address-in-Reply debate by reminding honourable members of the concluding words in the Governor-General's Speech, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: My Government believes that this-an explanation to the Australian people of the ideas, principles and values in terms of which the Government of the day shapes its policies-is something which has been somewhat neglected in Australia and that this neglect has diminished the quality of political life of the country. It believes that this should be remedied. During the life of this Parliament, therefore, my Government will be making a serious and sustained effort to explain to the Australian people the philosophy on which it bases its approach to governing.

My occupation before coming to this place was that of lecturer in political philosophy and political science, so I welcome the Government's intention to debate the deeper philosophical issues determining policy and the long term goals of our society. Certainly, we on the Labor side have nothing to fear from a debate on ideas, principles and values, for our party, the Australian Labor Party, has always represented the values of equality and justice. The intention expressed in the Governor-General's Speech to explain the philosophy on which the Liberal and National Country parties base their policies seems to have led to certain peculiar developments in the staff of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). It appears that we are witnessing the invasion of the right wing academics. Hundreds of thousands of dollars are to be spent paying these individuals supposedly to illuminate ordinary Australians who, it is said, do not understand Mr Fraser's actions.

The ancient Greek philosophers, with whom I have some affinity, coined the word 'sophistry'. By this they meant the use of philosophical arguments, which appear to illuminate but which in fact lead one to completely false conclusions. Unfortunately, the Governor-General's Speech, plus other statements on philosophy by the Prime Minister, are nothing more than attempted sophistry. For clearly, it is sophistry to speak of the policies of the present government as based on a small 'l' liberal philosophy. Indeed, the vast majority of Australia's political theorists believe that the Fraser Government's past policies have nothing to do with liberalism, in any meaningful sense of that term. Of course, if there had been a change of policies, if indeed Mr Fraser had learnt something from the dramatic--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will refer to the Prime Minister as such and not refer to him in a personal sense. He may continue.

—If the Prime Minister had learnt something from the dramatic swing against the Government it may have been possible to call his program liberalism. But no, we are told that the Government will maintain the basic thrust of the policies which have been followed over the past five years. It appears that the Australian people are to have more of the same medicine, the only change being what Mr Laurie Oakes described as 'the selling of a government', that is, the use of liberal principles as propaganda.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind honourable members opposite that the liberal tradition was based on maximising the liberty of the individual through opposition to oppressive power structures. These structures included not only the State, but also other organisations, including major corporations that control the lives of many thousands of people. The father of modern liberalism, John Stuart Mill, believed that the State could only interfere with the freedom of the individual in order to prevent harm to others. Mill envisaged a society in which each person's needs would be met, while at the same time maximising human liberty. This true liberalism is so far removed from the present policies of the Government that one can only conclude either that it is totally ignorant of that philosophy or is blatantly misusing it to deceive the Australian people.

Indeed, the present policies of the Fraser Government, far from being liberal-humanist, are based on an extreme, somewhat frightening, form of conservatism. By his own confession, the Prime Minister's real philosophy is based on the half-baked ideas of people like Ayn Rand and Milton Friedman, both of whom have explicitly rejected liberalism. According to this new conservatism, the present crisis situation in Western economies is to be resolved by imposing severe burdens on the working people of those countries. These policies involve an intervention by the Government on behalf of the rich against the poor. In Australia, these policies have reduced real wages and standards of living. They have done real harm to the average Australian family and have dramatically increased the number of people in poverty. Yet the outrageous thing about this is that the Government seeks to sell this exercise in turning back the clock to nineteenth century economics by appeals to the noble concept of liberty. To be poor and needy is not freedom; it is oppression, and tyranny.
There are two general slogans which are repeated ad nauseam by the Government in this propaganda exercise. The first one is described thus by the Governor-General:
My Government does believe profoundly that it is vitally important that the powers and functions of the State should be limited and contained.

Hardly anyone would disagree with this general principle, but again it is the way the Government manipulates it that concerns us. For the Government uses this principle to justify its brutal attack on the Public Service, its attempt to reduce not only the size of various departments but also to cut out some departments altogether. The argument here seems to be: The smaller the public sector and the State, the more free individuals in a society will be. This argument is manifestly absurd. It is based on failure to differentiate between those activities of the Government which actually harm individuals and those activities which help and support them, those activities which increase freedom and those activities which reduce it. This Government's actions clearly show that it will increase activities that harm Australians, as in its support for mining corporations against the Aboriginal people. Its actions show too that it will reduce the liberties of our people. An example of this is the legislation to attack unions and the right to strike. On this point, contrast the present Government's views with what John Stuart Mill said about unions over 100 years ago. He said:

I pass to another kind of government interference, in which the end and the means are alike odious . . . I mean the laws against combinations of workmen to raise wages; laws enacted and maintained for the declared purpose of keeping wages low . . . If it were possible for the working classes, by combining among themselves, to raise or keep up the general rate of wages, it needs hardly be said that this would be a thing not to be punished but to be welcomed and rejoiced at.

It is clear that when the Fraser Government speaks of reducing the size of the State, it attacks those departments whose function it is to provide services to the Australian people, especially the poor, the disadvantaged, the migrants, the unemployed and the sick. Indeed the Government was strongly attacked by the Young Liberals on this very point. The present policies and the ministerial inquiry are designed to do nothing more than reduce that sector of the state which is providing for human needs. Yet if the Government were genuine in what it says about caring for people, let it strengthen-not weaken-this sector of the state. Let it provide decent social security for the millions of Australians who are in need so that they might at least live at the level of the poverty line, instead of well below it. Of course, the Government will not take up this proposal because, as the Governor-General told us, it believes: '. . . that the State is likely to be in many ways an inefficient and wasteful provider and that many services can be better supplied in other ways'. Yet are we to suppose from this statement that health, education, transport, welfare, environmental protection and a host of other State services can be better provided by the so-called free enterprise sector? If this is so, why then do most Western societies maintain these services through the public sector? The answer clearly is because the capitalist system-especially the large corporations-will not provide them. We forget that prior to the development of the human needs sector of the state, people were left to starve by the huge corporations which cared nought for their welfare.

The second slogan of Fraserism is the glorification of so-called free enterprise. According to the Prime Minister's December speech, capitalism is said to be, firstly, responsible for improvements in standards of living in the twentieth century and, secondly, a necessary condition for political freedom. However, it is at least arguable that it is not capitalism, but rather the democratic welfare state and the development of trade unions, which have been responsible for the increases in living standards of workers. Yet as the Prime Minister concedes, both these latter factors are not essential elements of the capitalist economy as such. The claim that only capitalism is compatible with political freedom is dogmatic, and few political philosophers would entertain it. Even Mill believed that it was possible that some form of socialism would allow for greater freedom.

Although there is reference to 'imperfections' in capitalism, the Prime Minister shows no recognition of the fundamental evils which are essential elements of a rampant private enterprise system, namely, the savage inequalities between the rich and the poor and an ethic of greed and materialism. As His Holiness, Pope John Paul, said two months ago about modern capitalism:

Side by side with those who are wealthy and living in plenty, there exist those who are living in want, suffering misery . . . It is obvious that a fundamental defect, or rather a series of defects, indeed a defective machinery, is at the root of contemporary economics and materialistic civilisation which does not allow the human family to break free from such radically unjust situations.
More seriously, the Fraser speech confuses modern monopoly capitalism with the ideal free enterprise system, which no longer exists, if it ever did.

We do not deny that in any modern society there is room for a private sector, consisting of small companies in genuine competition with each other. However, what democratic socialists do not, and will not, accept is the way in which modern capitalism has historically developed-with power and wealth increasingly concentrated in the hands of a small number of multinational corporations which control not only the resources but also the destiny of the nation and its people. In Australia, this excessive ownership and control by foreign corporations has been well documented by people such as Professor Wheelwright. This development in the capitalist system-the increasing monopolisation of power and wealth-is actively supported by the Fraser Government, notwithstanding its denials. As evidence for this, witness the Government's actions in overriding its own advisers in Treasury and refusing to impose a resources tax so that the Australian people might gain some benefit from the exploitation of their own mineral resources.

This intervention by the state on behalf of big business is not a peripheral feature of modern private enterprise-it has now become an essential feature of the system. Whilst the Government talks about reducing the power of the state, it has in fact intervened to an increasing degree to stifle competition and to support increasing control of vast areas of our economy by a small number of corporations, as in its actions to emasculate the Trade Practices Commission, thus ensuring that price fixing and other forms of conspiracy are not prevented. Yet the liberal economist, Adam Smith, warned that if capitalists are allowed to follow their general tendencies and reduce competition, they 'levy for their own benefit an absurd tax on the rest of their fellow citizens'. John Stuart Mill recognised that such state-created monopolies would increase prices and that people have to pay what is demanded for basic necessities of life.

This is a fact of economic life which the Treasurer (Mr Howard) conveniently chooses to ignore. He has sought to blame workers' wage increases for inflation and other economic ills. This is putting the cart before the horse, for workers merely seek to keep up with artificially inflated price increases imposed by the power of big business, a power which is not responsive to the will of the people. The capacity of these corporations to fix prices as they wish is the major cause of inflation and until the Government faces this fact its monetary policies will fail. They will merely place further burdens on the majority of Australian workers, as with the recent rises in interest rates on homes. Yet the power of these corporations is not limited to increasing prices. They can-again without reference to the democratic will-dismiss hundreds or even thousands of workers and thus dramatically increase unemployment. This was clearly demonstrated by the callous action of General Motors-Holden's Ltd at its Pagewood plant. They can also, without notice, remove their capital and investments from the country and thereby create serious economic problems for any government. These developments of monopolistic capitalism are extremely disturbing and dangerous. They have nothing to do with freedom- quite the contrary. The very sovereignty and legitimacy of our democratic society is being threatened, as I have argued in my book.

If the Liberals are genuinely concerned with individual liberty, with the improvement of the people and with providing for human needs, they need radically to re-evaluate their program and change direction. They need to support the public interest against foreign private interest; they need to introduce a Bill of rights; they need to break up monopolies and ensure genuine competition in the private sector; and they need to protect the individual against the excessive power of corporations and to provide for his or her welfare when the private economy fails to do so. If the Liberal Party fails to do this, the judgment of history on it will be harsh. It will be remembered as a reactionary group which sold out the interests of the Australian people and which created poverty and unemployment unparalleled since the Great Depression. It is because of the two million Australians in poverty, the vast social inequalities and the record levels of unemployment, that we believe that one must go beyond the principles of liberalism.

Unlike the Fraser conservatives, the Labor Party does not wish to obscure its real philosophy; we are proud of our belief in democratic socialism and stand ready to defend it, both in the Parliament and throughout the nation. Since 1921, our socialisation objective has provided the basic philosophical direction for the party. Although the wording has changed from time to time the essence has remained the same. It reads:
The socialisation of the means of production, distribution and exchange to the extent necessary to eradicate exploitation and other anti-social features.

This objective determines a long term program of transformation of Australian society, especially in the economic area. We are concerned to eradicate the evils of advanced monopolistic capitalism that I referred to earlier. Although there may be disagreements between us on the strategy and pace of change, we are united in our long term goals, which include the following: Firstly, the redistribution of wealth to reduce inequalities and provide everyone with a guaranteed minimum income. The obscenity of the richest 10 per cent owning 59 per cent of the wealth while the poorest 10 per cent own only 0.27 per cent must be eradicated. As Mr Hayden said in 1979:
If resources cannot be found through growth then they must be diverted away from those who have them in overabundance and directed to the fulfilment of urgent human needs.

Our second goal is for dramatic increases in the level of public ownership and control of major resources, especially in the mining and energy areas. The wealth generated from such productive enterprises would go to achieve our third general goal-increases in the quality and quantity of human needs services provided by the state, including better education, health, welfare and public transport.

Our fourth goal is the introduction of more industrial democracy and worker participation, especially in public enterprises and partly socialised industries. Our fifth goal is the establishment of new productive areas of the state, in the form of public companies which will both compete with private firms and create many more jobs for Australians.

The general philosophy of the Labor Party has never been more relevant than it is today, for together with other countries of the Western world we are faced with an economic crisis of substantial proportions. Indeed, it can plausibly be argued that, if it were not for the happy accident that we have many natural resources, the Australian economy would be in a similar crisis to that of the United Kingdom. Certainly, as Peter Robinson has argued in his book, The Crisis of Australian Capitalism, our manufacturing and service industries are facing severe difficulties. Furthermore, as Mr Keith Windschuttle has shown in his book, Unemployment, this economic crisis has translated itself into a social crisis. In the last five years we have had massive increases in violent crimes, suicide rates, marital breakdown, drug addiction and other social ills-all of which are tearing the fabric of society apart. Yet the Government has no real program to solve these problems-it does not even recognise the real causes.

The ancient Greeks-who had hundreds of years of democratic experience-believed that democracy can survive only if the people are well informed about the values and philosophies by which they are governed. We in the Labor Party believe that our democratic socialist philosophy provides the basis for a more just and egalitarian society.
