As Bill Hayden commented recently: 'We must return to our socialist heritage . . . and not try to sneak in through the back door as a low key, pale imitation of the conservatives'. In the next three years, we shall endeavour to explain our philosophy, because we believe that our values are the same as those of the Australian people themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to speak in this Address-in-Reply debate. I congratulate the Government on its performance. The Governor-General said in his speech that the Government's economic policies have considerably improved Australian international competitiveness and enhanced export opportunities for Australian industries. The Australian economy is in good shape. The recent consumer price index figure of 9.3 per cent inflation in the last financial year shows that our policies are working. Recent retail sales figures show that the consumer is spending. There are a number of other encouraging favourable economic indices. It is important that we concentrate on creating wealth in the community and a healthy private sector does just this. The wealth so created benefits the community by the creation of jobs, opportunities for further investment and tax revenue for government expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: I think all honourable members will agree that there is an unacceptably high number of people unemployed at the present time but there are more people in jobs in Australia now than at any other time in our history. This trend will continue as, in the next few years, new resource and manufacturing development projects will create tens of thousands of jobs. The Government's policies on development and economic growth are in stark contrast to the Opposition's attitude to the developmental decade ahead. The Australian Labor Party says that it is in favour of development but actually it is hard to find a project that has its support. The Labor Party's attitude to uranium mining is well known. It is against the important aluminium development project in Portland, Victoria. Essentially, when all is boiled down and analysed, the only industries which the Australian Labor Party supports in Australia are reafforestation, housing and solar energy.

I wish the committee of senior Ministers reviewing the functions of all Commonwealth departments and associated agencies-the so-called Lynch committee or razor gang-success in its task. As the Governor-General said, that review will recommend which functions might be reduced, eliminated or altered so as to achieve a more efficient and economic administration. It will also examine areas where Commonwealth activities overlap with those of the States or intrude into the private sector. I am encouraged by this morning's Press reports that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is to widen the scope of the committee and enlarge the committee's responsibilities by giving it new directions. Perhaps the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) might consider having a phone-in similar to that of the Minister for Economic Development in Victoria. I would certainly commend to the Minister that he consider taking the advice of independent, outside consultants-independent of Government-in reviewing the functions of government departments. There is a real risk, when one gets Ministers and departments making recommendations about their own reductions, of almost attempting the impossible, in that bureaucrats are hardly likely to recommend to Ministers their own abolition. This review provides a great opportunity to get rid of a large number of bodies advising government. Additionally there is a broad range of government functions that could be better carried out by the private sector. Auditing, accounting and computing come quickly to mind.

The Government's recent decision not to impose any form of indirect taxation has put more pressure on the need for this committee's recommendations to be successful as government expenditure must be significantly cut to give the urgent tax relief necessary to those thousands of Australians who need it. The committee has one of the most important tasks in the history of this Government.

On the question of taxation relief, it is urgently necessary to increase the amount of discretionary or disposable income available to Australian families to increase the freedom of choice of taxpayers in spending their own incomes as was mentioned in the Speech by His Excellency the Governor-General. One option to be seriously considered is to allow single income families to split their incomes. The policy objective to restrain public expenditure is now more important than it was at the time the Governor-General spoke because of the Government's subsequent decision not to alter the tax mix by introducing indirect taxation. The strain on personal income tax payers must be relieved. The Government deserves credit for establishing a three-tiered standard rate tax scale system and for the reductions in personal taxation already achieved. There is, however, still a long way to go.

In talking of the Public Service, I must state to the House that I believe one of the great challenges of the decade is control over the bureaucracy, the growth, nature and function of the Public Service. The Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act is a start in this direction, but only a start. Public servants cannot have security of tenure on the one hand and the unfettered right to strike at the whim and will of union officials on the other. The public is sick and tired of being inconvenienced. Public servants must accept that they really are so much better off than many thousands of Australians in the private sector and that, by continually striking, they have abused their preferential position.

The question of industrial relations, trade unions and the role of organised labour is one of the keys to where Australia is going in the decade ahead. Undoubtedly, a number of union officials are abusing the trust of their members in wielding power at times to bring selective industries to a standstill. Look at the harm the Australian Council of Trade Unions-backed Qantas Airways Ltd strike is doing to Australia and its overseas reputation at this time. This is one of Australia's tragedies and we have to look towards improving industrial relations. The poor state of affairs is a challenge for managers and management. I consider that there is a need for Australian employers to improve their handling of Australia's industrial relations matters. Managers at all levels, whether chief executive, plant, or divisional, need to be trained to be more skilled in dealing with industrial relations problems, preferably as to prevention of them. We live in the era of the wildcat strike and we need to achieve mechanisms for resolving confrontation between management and labour. There is a need for greater communication between management and the shop floor. I believe the effect of ever increasing wage demands and union activity causing unemployment is well understood in the community. We need to develop a consensus among government, unions, employers and the community.

Another area to which I refer is the orderly development of Australia in the 1980s. We need to have a clear overall idea of the country's industries that will be successful in the decade. I see the need for greater co-ordination between the States, as I believe the States have a vital and important role to play in resource development. We need to look towards setting up and establishing a set of guidelines in consultation and co-operation with the States to see that development is co-ordinated in an orderly way. The Australian Loan Council and the Foreign Investment Review Board have important roles to play, as have State and Federal taxation and royalty policies. The Foreign Investment Review Board alone cannot be the arbiter of new projects, nor can the Australian Loan Council. A framework needs to be developed.

In Australia at present there is undoubtedly a trend of transfer of ownership from individuals to financial institutions and, to some extent, overseas investors. The need for capital for new projects in the 1980s is one of the greatest challenges to the economy. In the last five years, $2.5 billion has been raised through Australian stock exchanges as new equity capital. One billion dollars of this amount was raised in the most recent financial year and comes largely from mining companies' capital raisings. This has to be compared with the predicted $33.4 billion in capital required for projects either committed or in the final stage of feasibility for the next five years. Enormous amounts of local equity capital will be required. My figures do not include investment projects of less than $5m, which would include the majority of manufacturing industry investment.

The disincentives to individuals investing through the stock exchanges must be reviewed. Individuals must be encouraged to buy shares in corporations. Questions to be examined include double taxation of the income of public companies by way of dividends in the hands of individuals, the 30-20 rule obligating certain life and pensions funds to purchase government securities, the special taxation treatment of life companies, and the rates and nature of commissions charged by stockbrokers.

It is important that individual Australians identify with the development of Australia, and have ownership of it. It is important that shareholdings in resource development projects be as widely spread as possible throughout the community, especially amongst those who work for particular corporations. The capacity for individuals who work for corporations to participate in their ownership may be one of the ways in which we can improve Australia's poor industrial relations. At Grand Central Station in New York, a leading firm of stockbrokers has an office. I look forward to the day when an Australian stock and share broker has an office on Flinders Street Station.

The challenge is all the greater for individuals to participate in the decade ahead in the ownership of enterprises because in the past fund raising has coincided with a period of low investment in the commercial property market. There is evidence that this trend will not continue and that the commercial property market will be competing for funds with the development projects to which I have referred. While talking of Australian participation in resource development, I would raise what I consider to be a loophole in the foreign investment guidelines that needs examination. This loophole, I believe, allows overseas engineers and consulting firms to get too large a share of work in resource development projects. There needs to be more Australian participation in firms servicing the resource construction industries.

I am concerned about the position of homeless people in Australia today-an apparently increasing problem in the community. The Government has pledged $10m for a 3-year homeless persons assistance program, with special priority for young people. The Government is currently considering matters which require determination before the policy commitment can be implemented. One issue is to make sure that assistance is directed fairly to meet the need of client groups. I have received a copy of a report on homeless youth from a group in Malvern, in my electorate in Victoria, prepared by project officers at the Malvern Self Help Employment Exchange. I think this is a valuable document in analysing the problems and causes of young homeless people being adrift in the community. I have forwarded a copy of the report to Senator Chaney, the Minister for Social Security, as I believe it has a wider application than just in the municipality of Malvern and could assist in implementing the policy promise. The development of these policies is urgent. We have restored opportunity through economic growth. The Government's policies are succeeding. However, we still have a way to go. We are taxing working savings, work and initiatives beyond reasonable limits.

I would like to refer to philosophy before I conclude. We have just been treated by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous), to an unbelievable, incredible and ridiculous attempt to analyse Liberal Party philosophy. All the honourable member did was to make an attempt that failed to destroy the philosophy of the Liberal Party. That shows that the Australian Labor Party is destructive; it is not constructive. The honourable member said that he was proud of his belief in socialism. I reiterate that he said he was proud of his belief in socialism. He reaffirmed it. He said that the socialisation of the means of production, distribution and exchange to the extent necessary to eradicate exploitation and other anti-social features is still the belief of the Australian Labor Party. He said that this objective remains a long term program for the transformation of Australian society. That is what the Labor Party is about. It wants to transform Australian society by socialisation, by increased ownership by government of activities in the country.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —They are interjecting on the other side of the House because I have hit the raw nerve. The Labor Party is about socialisation. The previous speaker's words were about socialising the means of production, distribution and exchange. That is what the previous speaker, a member of the Labor Party, reaffirmed. What does this mean? It means increased taxation to finance the growth of the public sector to transform, as they call it, Australian society. It means increases in public expenditure. It means increases in the number of public servants. It means more and more bureaucrats. It means the growth of the bureaucracy. That is what the Labor Party is about today, and it has just been reaffirmed in this House. I want to bring that fact to the attention of those people listening today to this debate. The Governor-General in his Speech stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . my Government will be making a serious and sustained effort to explain to the Australian people the philosophy on which it bases its approach to governing . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you start?

—I hear an interjection. I am proud of the philosophy. The Government has told the Australian people what it stands for-the revival of initiative and incentive for both workers and investors, something which the Labor Party has not heard about. The Liberal Party is proud of its philosophy. It has laid out that philosophy and in the Governor-General's Speech it has laid out its ideas of government.
—Tell us something about it.

—I refer to the interjection. Please read the Governor-General's Speech which we are debating in the House today. I also refer the honourable member to the policy speech of the Prime Minister. We must not weaken in our resolve. Our policies must and will reflect the Liberal philosophy, of which I am proud. I am confident that our policies will meet the needs of the Australian people at this important time in our history.

—I call the honourable member for Macquarie. I draw honourable members' attention to the fact that this is a maiden speech. It is the custom and convention in this place that members delivering their maiden speech be heard in silence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by expressing my delight in being sent here to represent the electorate of Macquarie, and I thank the electors for their trust. I have come to this House on my third attempt, that is, after three elections. I should particularly like to thank my family-my wife, Margaret, and my three sons-for all that they have put up with for a very long time indeed. I should also like to thank the local organisation of the Australian Labor Party, the party's New South Wales and national offices, and the members of the parliamentary Labor Party for their constant support and encouragement over a long and at times difficult road. I should also like to extend good wishes for a long and happy retirement to my immediate predecessor, the former Liberal member for this seat, and to his wife. I congratulate him on his recent endorsement as a State candidate, and I repeat my desire that his retirement should be a long and undisturbed one.

SPEECH.PARA: The electorate I represent, the seat of Macquarie, was one of the original seats in the Parliament. Its face was changed, however, with the 1977 redistribution, and the historic centres of Labor's country support-the cities of Bathurst and Lithgow-were removed from the traditional seat. Instead, Macquarie has become an electorate based on outer western Sydney. It covers the bulk of the cities of St Marys and Penrith, and the 20 towns and villages in the Blue Mountains. The electorate stretches across the Cumberland Plain. It takes in the Nepean River, the spectacular sandstone scenery of the Blue Mountains, down to the limestone formations of the Jenolan Caves. It is a district rich in history, from the early days of the settlement west, through the crossing in 1813 of the Blue Mountains. It was the path taken by the diggers to the Hill End gold rush. It was a district populated and settled by battlers, and it is still a district populated by battlers.

Macquarie is now one of Sydney's fastest growing areas. At the time of the election in October last year there were over 85,000 electors on the roll, making it the largest electorate in Australia. The recent growth has been a direct result of the rapidly rising prices of land and homes in Sydney. People have moved out to my part of the world to find places at a price that they can afford. This process, of course, will continue to accelerate with the movements in interest rates. It is an electorate of home buyers. According to the last census, over 75 per cent of homes in the district were owned or were being purchased. In this respect I must commend the activity of the New South Wales Government. Through the Land Commission of New South Wales and the Housing Commission of New South Wales, it has made available in this district accommodation within the reach of ordinary people.

Macquarie is an electorate of young people. Again, in the latest census the electorate was ranked fifth in Australia on the percentage of pre-schoolers it contained. Almost one in eight of the total population then was under five years. All of these kids now are at school, placing enormous strains locally on the education system. I must say that in that time there has been precious little help from the Federal Government to the local education system. I recall hearing the Minister for Education (Mr Fife), who is at the table, refer late last year to the role of federal funding in education as topping up what the States had to offer. In fact, federal funds made available to New South Wales schools have declined by over 11 per cent in real terms since 1975. If a decline of over 11 per cent in real terms is defined by the Minister as 'topping up', I await with bated breath his definition of a funding cut. These children, the pre-schoolers who come after them and their brothers and sisters at the 14 local secondary schools, all deserve a better deal from this Government. There is also an urgent need for childcare facilities in the district I represent, especially in the new estates. Those further needs are not being met by this Government.

There is an urgent need for the level of support for all schools in the district to be raised, particularly in the newer areas. It is not that the schools are not doing their job. Last night I listened to the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) blame the education system for youth unemployment. I put it to the House that that is utter nonsense. If we compare the number of jobs available with the number of young people out of work, it is obvious that no education system on earth could create the jobs necessary to put the youth of Australia back to work. It is simply a fallacy to blame the education system for that situation. I have worked in schools for 15 years and I can say with complete confidence that kids today have a better education and schools are doing a better job than ever before.

Honourable members do not have to take my word for that. Objective evidence is published in the latest issue of the journal Education, which contains an article by Graham Little in which he examines the objective criteria in literacy and numeracy. That provides evidence that the products of our schools are better educated today than ever before. But schools are operating under enormous difficulties. The demands being placed on them are ever increasing and they can carry on only if they receive the increased assistance which they need so urgently from this Government.

My district is also a popular area for retirement. It contains high concentrations of aged pensioners. It also has many single parent families and a great many of that endangered species under this Government, namely, invalid pensioners. They also are people who are not getting a fair deal from this Government. Their needs are not being met; consequently their living standards are declining. The services they are receiving from government departments are inadequate. As I have indicated, it is a district with problems which affect individual groups of people. I am not suggesting that the area is unique; it is experiencing difficulties common to growth areas relatively distant from our large cities. The district suffers because services are lagging behind population growth-the people come to the area and the necessary services come far too late. In the period 1972 to 1975 a great deal was done to provide those services. Prior to 1972 a great proportion of the district was not sewered. That was largely remedied in those years. Problems are being experienced with water supply at the moment and those problems are being remedied by the New South Wales Labor Government.

Problems are being experienced in the field of transport. It might interest honourable members to know that many people-the vast majority of working people-in my electorate commute for up to two hours each way each day to and from the city. Again, I commend the New South Wales Government for the improvement it has made in commuter services in that district. It is also a district in which people rely a great deal on the family car. A family car is much more necessary for them than it is for city people. Because they are relatively distant from local services, the car must be used. These people in recent years have borne the brunt of this Government's petrol pricing policy.

Also it is a district which has an urgent need for better and cheaper communication facilities. I refer particularly to the local telephone service in the 047 telephone district. At present over 2,000 people are awaiting connection to the telephone service; people who have paid their money and made their applications perhaps six months ago or more and still are waiting for the service, with no clear indication of when they will get it. The people who are connected to the telephone service have an additional problem: They might have a telephone service but for a large part of the day the telephone performs a purely ornamental service. When they pick up the receiver it is most unlikely that they will get a dial tone and be able to ring anybody. This is as a result of country-type equipment-inappropriate and inadequate equipment-being provided to meet the needs of the district. It is obvious that if the district is to have the communication facilities it needs there is a need for a massive commitment of federal funds to provide equipment to get the job done. Also, clearly there is a need to lift staff ceilings in the Australian Telecommunications Commission to provide staff to do the job.

Many of the people who are lucky enough to get a dial tone and dial a number are forced to pay through the nose for that kind of telephone service because, although districts such as Penrith are rightly considered to be part of the Sydney city area, for telephone charging purposes they are not so considered and the subscribers must pay trunk rates for telephone calls to Sydney. That has been a bone of contention with local councils, local organisations and local business for many years. I can assure the Government that the fight will go on until at last places such as Penrith and the Blue Mountains are given a fair go and are provided with local call access to Sydney.

It is also an area which frequently is prone to natural disaster. I am sure that honourable members would recall the disastrous bushfires which swept through the Blue Mountains in 1968 and 1977. It is certain that we will have those kinds of disasters in the future. It is equally certain that action on a national basis is needed to avert such disasters. When a fire occurs all the assistance in the world is available: The Army comes in and help is provided for the victims by way of accommodation and money. But clearly there is a need for preventative action before a disaster occurs. In that respect I commend the Government for taking the step of instituting, through the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, experiments on the effectiveness of water bombing and the use of fire retarding chemicals. I am sure that will assist. It has come a little too late. The Federal Government could be doing other things to assist the volunteer bushfire brigade movement with vehicles and equipment.

It is also a district which is experiencing a disastrous level of unemployment, especially among young people. At the three Commonwealth Employment Service offices which cover my electorate, the number of registered unemployed as at the end of 1980-these are the most recent figures I have-total some 7,500 people. Let us consider the ratio of applicants for jobs to vacancies in December, which was a relatively good month because the bulk of the school leavers had not yet been included in the figures. In Penrith 23 people were out of work for every job vacancy available. In Mount Druitt, which covers part of my electorate, again 23 people were out of work for every job vacancy available.

In Katoomba 53 people were out of work for every job vacancy available. For the 339 youngsters registered as unemployed in Katoomba, four job vacancies were available. I anticipate that the situation will peak in the January-February period this year, when we will see the figures mirroring the performance of last year. We will have applicant to vacancy ratios like the disastrous Mount Druitt ratios we had last year. In the early part of last year in Mount Druitt and St Marys for six job vacancies for young people, 2,773 youngsters were out of work. Those are the kinds of odds those young people are facing.

It is essential that we count the social and economic costs of that situation because sooner or later society will pay the price. The correct responses are not to be found in punitive expeditions against the unemployed or by juggling the figures, this month preferring the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures or the Commonwealth Employment Service figures; nor are they to be found in talking about the number of people employed compared with the number unemployed. The solutions will not be found in appeals to incentive, initiative or motivation. Clearly, the solutions will be found only in providing jobs for those people who so desperately need them. That kind of realisation must begin with a basic change in the attitudes of the people in power in this country. When we consider those attitudes we can see how badly and desperately they need to be changed. I refer to a talk by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr Viner) to the National Young Liberals Convention in 1979. He said:

To make work and work generating initiative fashionable for them a real impact will have to be made on the cool young to whom dole-bludging is a bit of a joke rather than something to be overcome if humanly possible.

I also refer to a statement by another member of the conservative forces in this country expressing the point of view which all too often is expressed that work is available if only people look hard enough for it. The statement read:
For those who work hard there are rewards. Therefore, even though the unemployment market is at this moment difficult, I believe if you really want to find work and you are sincere about it you will.

The author of that statement was the Premier of Queensland-the recently elected and, I hope, soon to be redistributed, Premier of Queensland. He is something of an authority on finding jobs. He has the best job creation scheme in Australia. He is the man who obtained 41 per cent of the seats in the Queensland Parliament with just 27 per cent of the vote. I turn to the question of electoral reform, having just spoken of the vote in Queensland and the allocation of parliamentary seats. It is an area in which I have been interested for many years. My interest has been heightened by my representing more electors in this place than anybody else. It has been heightened by the Queensland situation in which one National Party vote is worth four Labor Party votes in another seat. It has been heightened by looking at the result of the October Federal election in New South Wales. The ALP gained 50.4 per cent of the two-party preferred vote. The Liberal and National Country parties gained 49.6 per cent of the two-party preferred vote. Yet those parties gained seven seats more than the Labor Party. With almost 1 per cent less of the vote they finished up with seven more seats.

Quite clearly, fundamental to any democratic system, if votes are to mean anything, is the principle of one vote, one value. We must enshrine that principle in our system. If votes are to have equal value, it must follow that they should have an equal chance of being counted and rendered formal. Therefore, there should be a draw for positions on ballot papers. Party affiliations should be shown on ballot papers. Party how-to-vote information should be displayed in polling booths and the optional preferential system should prevail. We should no longer put up with the situation in this country in which the exhaustive preferential system renders upwards of 10 per cent of votes informal. We should also guarantee equal access to information and allow parties a fair go in its distribution. This means that we should have public funding of political campaigns at a national level. The public funding of political parties is a fact of life in very many Western democracies such as West Germany, Sweden, Denmark and in Norway from 1920. It will soon be a fact in New South Wales and when that State adopts the practice I sincerely hope that the nation will follow.

Before concluding, I will pay tribute to two distinguished former members for Macquarie. The first is Anthony Sylvester Luchetti, or Tony to his friends. There are many of them in this place. He gave 24 years of distinguished service to the Parliament and the electorate. I fought with Tony in six campaigns, three as his campaign director and three in which he campaigned for me. I thank him for his friendship and support. I was very pleased that he and his wife, May, were able to come to Canberra for the opening of Parliament last year. The second former member for Macquarie of whom I speak was Joseph Benedict Chifley, a great and good Australian. There may be some argument about who was our greatest Prime Minister but there is no argument about who was our most loved. I can think of no better way of finishing my maiden speech in this House than by repeating some of the words that Ben used towards the end of his career. He said:

I try to think of the Labour movement, not as putting an extra sixpence into somebody's pocket, or making somebody Prime Minister or Premier, but as a movement bringing something better to the people, better standards of living, greater happiness to the mass of the people. We have a great objective-the light on the hill-which we aim to reach by working for the betterment of mankind not only here but anywhere we may give a helping hand. If it were not for that the Labour movement would not be worth fighting for. If the movement can make someone more comfortable, give to some father or mother a greater feeling of security for their children, a feeling that if a depression comes there will be work . . . then the Labour movement will be completely justified. These things are really worth fighting for.
I am proud to be part of that fight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the speech that has just been made. I can well see a love-hate relationship growing up between me and my attitude towards what the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Free) has said. I disagree with much of what he said but I believe that he said it most impressively and sincerely. I make that comment without apology. Mr Deputy Speaker, I am pleased that you are presiding when I make my contribution. I believe that I will receive a degree of tolerance. We have just heard a reference to the great Ben Chifley. Another person who fits into that category was the giant towering figure of John McEwen. A statement he made has often been quoted. He said that he did not mind what was happening in the land provided that everything was right in the bush.

SPEECH.PARA: I will devote the first part of my contribution today to what is happening and what may happen in the bush. After 15 years in the Parliament I have sought and groped for a definition of the bush. I think the best way of finding a definition is to consider, as an example, how quickly a person gets into the bush. At the moment something that is occupying the minds of all Australians is petrol prices. We are inclined to overlook the fact that we are probably still enjoying the lowest petrol prices in the Western world. I do not know what happens on the other side of the Iron Curtain and I have no particular desire to know. If a person drives out of the city of Brisbane-I use my own State as an example-he will not drive 100 kilometres before he has to pay 41 or 42 cents a litre for petrol. We are in the bush very promptly when we consider the effects of the disadvantages and penalties of existence.

I have referred to petrol pricing but the results of the disadvantages flow very quickly to almost everything with which people in remote areas have to contend. Another example which we all come up against is the price of services, such as electricity which affects just about everything. The effects flow on from the prices of such commodities as fuel, building materials and so on. God must have had a worrying sense of humour when he planted his treasures, whether they be gold, silver, lead or zinc. He seemed to put them in very remote areas. With a pure and, I suppose, admirable sense of decentralisation, he decreed that his animals would best thrive in isolated and remote areas. He provided the basis for the establishment of the resources industries, the agricultural industries and the grazing industries in disadvantaged areas. Human beings have to live in those areas and produce. Because they do so two things happen. They will fill the treasury of this nation and they provide its basic wealth. But they do it under the most lamentable conditions, both physically and financially. What do we do about it? We make speeches year after year.

Another thing that John McEwen said was: 'When you come down here you are going to find that most of the cases you put appear to fall on deaf ears'. I thought that the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) spoke words of wisdom when he said today: 'You must keep trying'. I have been a Minister and have sat in the Cabinet room. We would like to provide everything that everyone asks for. Would it not be wonderful if one, or all, of the back benchers could have everything that he or they sought; what a wonderful world it would be. Mr Deputy Speaker, you and I could have all of our problems in regard to road safety solved overnight. We would be delighted. But it just does not happen that way. As the honourable member for Franklin intimated, you have to get your teeth in like an old blue heeler and hang on. Those are my words, of course. I do not think that the honourable member would know very much about blue heelers. People think that we who live out in that part of the world are a lot of miserable clots; we are not. We live under very serious disadvantages. However, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has provided an opportunity to remedy that.

I refer to the proposed reassessment of concessional taxation zones. Those concessions are not of great significance these days. Incomes are so high that the particular concession one may get may be of little significance. As one who has spent a lifetime in these areas, as one who to the extent of his capacity tries to emphasise in Canberra the tremendous disadvantages suffered because of the penalties of distance, I am trying to get a message across to my people. I hope that it flows on. I am sure that every member, whatever his party, is trying to do the same. The opportunity to obtain new taxation zone allowances must be grasped. In any case, because of doubts as to constitutional validity, it is a dubious quantity these days. My message is: Do not concentrate so much on getting an increased advantage in a particular taxation zone. For heaven's sake, having squealed about it, having worried your member and yourselves until you are sick at heart, having sat and sympathised with yourselves for years, seize the opportunity to bring before the Treasurer, before the Government, before the Executive, before the men who sit around a table and make these decisions, the disadvantages that are already so obvious to people who live in remote areas. Prepare your case and present it forcibly and with cohesion. For God's sake forget your politics and put forward a case to the Government.

I take this opportunity to get another message through to the Treasurer. I hope to do so personally as soon as possible. If this is to be a meaningful inquiry-and I have no doubt as to his intentions in that regard-designed to obtain evidence of the disadvantages suffered by people beyond metropolitan areas, hearings will have to be held in strategic centres of the north-west of Queensland and the north of South Australia, areas from which the wealth is flowing but people must live under tremendous penalties. I am putting in a plug for the areas with which I am most concerned and I do hope that the message gets across and that the inquiry will be a meaningful operation.

I made an attempt earlier today to bring into public focus what I regard as a terrible tragedy, one that I feel a little more intensely than most because my father was one of the 12 or 13 men who decided that they may be able to get a little old aeroplane and start an airline between Cloncurry and Longreach and Charleville. They got in an old buggy, or something of the sort, went down to Winton and started a company. I am absolutely confident that there is not one honourable member opposite who is not immensely proud of the way in which that small airline has since grown into the flag carrier of this nation. I have never been a union basher. I have been on the executive of three unions and have worked on the wharves. I hope that I can see both sides of the question fairly. But there is nothing to sustain an argument that would ground these aircraft and would prevent people who apparently want to go back to work from doing so. I cannot understand the attitude of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Over the years we have all had a great deal of respect for that organisation. What could activate an attitude which would bring an airline to a standstill, and as a result of which people who might be planning to come to this country would say: 'It is not much use making a booking there because you just do not know when that aircraft is going to travel. We may be grounded. God knows what may happen'.

Thus, we are caught up in a wave of criticism that has swept across the world. We who have been overseas know that Australia has that unenviable reputation, one that represents an exaggeration. It could well operate to the serious disadvantage of the whole operation of Qantas Airways Ltd. There is talk now of ceasing operations altogether. That is a disgraceful situation.

I have the advantage of living in a city which has a wonderful industrial climate. I refer to the city of Mount Isa, the biggest industrial city in Australia, with the exception perhaps of your own city of Newcastle, Mr Deputy Speaker. We have a group of unions which have set an excellent example of responsibility; I mean that. The same sort of atmosphere seems to prevail in Newcastle. Over the years, having been an active unionist myself, one learns to gauge the feelings of the great body of unionists. They do not want the Qantas disaster to continue. They could not possible do so. No decent, fair-minded Australian could want it to continue.

I turn now to a bipartisan matter which is of great concern to Australia, that of Australia's defence. Australia's ultimate capacity to deter a potential aggressor is dependent upon perceiving the development of a potential enemy's capability and intention to mount a direct attack and matching that capability within the period of warning with forces that would impose an unacceptable degree of risk on the enemy. I continue to have some reservations as to whether our present Defence Force can be expanded to the required size within the period of likely warning for several contingencies. Those doubts are based on a good deal of experience gained in recent years.

One matter to which I wish to draw attention today is the expansion capacity of our forces. It would seem that, despite the absence of a clearly definable threat, greater attention needs to be given to planning for a possible mobilisation. That is a real possibility, given the way the world is today. This requires an interdepartmental or national approach to determine the industrial and manpower support which would be available during a defence emergency. I always have the feeling that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) keeps a very close watch on this situation. I would feel that such a co-ordinating body would operate under his eye, but we would like to see that concept exposed a little more, to know a little more about it. It may be worth considering whether the wider aspects of our national defence should be co-ordinated by a separate national security division which would, of course, be under the Prime Minister's own jurisdiction and scrutiny. Military aspects and requirements on mobilisation could then be co-ordinated with the wide array of industrial and manpower resources which are encompassed by other Ministers' portfolios, but the enhancement of which is not normally reflected in the defence vote in peacetime. One just cannot see it.

A substantial ingredient of any expanded Defence Force is the current Army Reserve. The Government has announced its intention to expand the Army Reserve from 22,000 to 30,000 by 1 July 1981. It is gratifying to see how successful the campaign has been to date. I am delighted to indicate that the number has already reached 26,000 and that it appears that, despite gloomy predictions to the contrary, the target will be reached.

It would seem that the Army Reserve needs to overcome its low retention rates as, in the past, 58 per cent of recruits have not served for more than two years. I hope that that is remedied. There have been signs of improvement in recent years but there is still a requirement for additional inducements for reservists to serve longer periods. Australia expects them to give up their leisure time in the national interest over a protracted period. Last September, the Government promised to make provision for adequate financial compensation for those reservists who are injured while on military duty. This is happening. It is important that the fine details of the new arrangements be announced as soon as possible.

I wish also to draw attention to the question of whether there is a need for legislation to enable the call-out of the Army Reserve in a situation short of a defence emergency. Not only would such legislation cater for the eventuality of a more rapid expansion of the Army beyond its present 32,500 regulars as a possible threat is gradually perceived, but from time to time it would enable deployment of Army reservists during civil emergencies such as natural disasters. I stress that any strengthening of the Army Reserve and enhancement of its role would obviate any need for national service. I support firmly the build-up of the Reserve even for this reason. Due to the exigencies of service life, it is essential for the retention and morale of servicemen and their wives that there be a continuing improvement in their housing situation. The willingness of service personnel and their families to endure harsh living conditions in time of war should not be taken advantage of in time of peace by denying them pay and conditions at least on a par with those of their peers in civilian life. I understand those difficulties. As Minister for the Army, I used to ask for so many million dollars, and hope I might get half of that, to provide more adequate housing for my troops.

I wish to talk a little about the defence of northern Australia. There is little doubt that Australians living in the North feel, and are, more vulnerable than those living in the more populous south-eastern parts of Australia. This is accentuated because of inadequate communications in the North. Already these communications leave a lot to be desired, particularly during times of national disaster. These limited communication links with southern Australia give no cause for confidence in the event of a defence emergency. Improvements in communication facilities are in prospect for northern Australia. I know there is a lot happening but I emphasise the fact that these improvements are needed now and any action to expedite the plans of Telecom Australia for the region would be greatly appreciated by the people of the North.

The feeling of vulnerability in the north-west is not lessened by the fact that there is not even an Army Reserve unit in the vast region between Geraldton and Darwin. One way of providing a military presence in the Kimberley region would be to raise an Army Reserve sub-unit based on towns such as Broome, Derby and Kununurra. No doubt a similar pattern could be developed in the Pilbara. Supported by good regular Army cadre, including specialists, such Reserve units with local knowledge of the terrain could form the basis of a land surveillance force in north-western Australia. There has been considerable criticism of the current system of aerial surveillance by civil contractors in northern Australia because the contractors' flying pattern is far too predictable and is limited to conditions of good daylight visibility. The ability to respond to unauthorised landings in remote areas may be regarded as inadequate. Significant problems of co-ordination have also to be overcome in the absence of a single law enforcement agency operating under its own Act of Parliament. This has an inherent disability.

I wish to comment on the construction of the Darwin-Alice Springs standard guage railway, and express the hope that we may also see at the planning stage in the not too distant future a Darwin-Mount Isa rail link. But I refer now to the Darwin-Alice Springs link. Such an enhancement of the national infrastructure, linking Darwin with the national rail system, undoubtedly will serve the defence interests of this nation. There is also a need to make greater use of the skills of the Aborigines for surveillance work and a need to give more opportunities to Aborigines to serve in the Army, including the Reserve, through the provision of appropriate pre-enlistment training. It is not good enough merely to say: 'If they meet our standards we will take them'. That means no Aborigines would ever serve. That is not the sort of attitude that would encourage these programs. Positive programs must be implemented to enable them to reach pre-enlistment standards.

It is important that a committee of the Parliament takes a continuing interest in defence matters, and the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence through its Sub-committee on Defence Matters has an important role to play in this respect. It is my hope that the work of the sub-committee will promote a better informed, rational and bipartisan debate in this Parliament on defence matters. I speak today as an individual, not as the chairman of that sub-committee. The Sub-committee on Defence Matters plans to hear further evidence on a number of important issues during the life of this Parliament, and of course will then report to the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable members to the fact that we are about to hear the maiden speech of the honourable member for La Trobe. It is the custom and convention in this Parliament that a maiden speech be heard in silence. I call the honourable member for La Trobe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. In this, my first speech in the House, I have the dubious privilege of being the first person to represent the electorate of La Trobe with a seat on the opposition benches. My four predecessors-Lord Casey, Mr John Jess, Mr Tony Lamb and Mr Marshall Baillieu-were all members who sat on the government benches. I thank the people of La Trobe for their confidence in electing me as their member and assure them that being in opposition will make me even more diligent in pursuing their interests which, it is clear from the Governor-General's Speech, will not be served by the announced Government policies for the next three years. I will elaborate on that matter later in my speech. In the first speech in this House of my predecessor, Mr Baillieu, he referred to his member's gold medallion being presented to him by Mr Tony Lamb on loan from the Australian Labor Party. It is gratifying that the loan has now been repaid but I regret that it has been at great cost to the people of La Trobe who have suffered a drastic lowering in their standard of living over the past five years.

SPEECH.PARA: I will now describe some of the features of my electorate and point to the serious problems the people are facing. A large part of the electorate encompasses the Dandenong Ranges, which include the Ferntree Gully National Park and Sherbrooke Forest. They are areas of outstanding beauty and contain preserved fragments of the original forest which once covered the whole of the ranges. It is a place of splendid scenic landscapes and it includes many picnic spots and recreation reserves to which thousands of visitors, mainly from Melbourne but also from interstate and overseas, come each year. The people who live in the ranges are keen conservationists and strongly resent continuing attempts by land developers to encroach on the area by indiscriminate land subdivision. It is tragic that the aspirations of the Upper Yarra Valley and Dandenong Ranges Authority, which has been set up to conserve the environment and its natural resources, could be frustrated as a result of the unpreparedness of Federal and State governments to provide appropriate funding for conservation purposes. The population has grown rapidly in the past decade and now comprises some 125,000 people, 40 per cent of whom are of pre-school or school age. For most of these people Government policy over the past five years has been deficient, particularly in the areas of employment, health, education and housing. To make matters worse, these deficiencies have been accentuated by an acute lack of public transport facilities. Future Government policy, as outlined in the Governor-General's Speech, will do nothing to remedy these deficiencies. Indeed, the Speech is nothing more than a verbal facade designed to hide a lack of Government economic planning. It is the lack of such planning which is the predominant cause of the difficulties which the people of La Trobe face in their day to day living.

In August 1980, 4,175 people were registered as unemployed at the Boronia and Lilydale Commonwealth Employment Service offices, but there were only 126 job vacancies. The latest local unemployment figures are not available but, with the flood of school leavers on to the job market, unemployment has reached serious proportions, particularly for young people. By cynically manipulating the use of selective statistics, the Government attempts to delude the public into believing that job opportunities are growing. But what are the facts? The Government pays lip service to job creation but in the past seven years the number of jobs available in Australia has increased at approximately one-third the rate of increase of the recorded labour force. Six hundred thousand new jobs will have to be found over the next five years to prevent unemployment rising higher than the present unacceptable level.

Let us not forget that a large part of the growth in available jobs, which the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr Viner) so proudly trumpeted during the October election, represents part time, unskilled teenage labour. There is little permanency or job satisfaction in such dead-end work. Manpower training programs, career counselling and an additional year at school may improve job skills for the young unemployed but they do not provide them with new, permanent full time jobs. The Government has set its sights on mineral development involving overseas investments of thousands of millions of dollars which it is claimed will produce new jobs. But, for example, capital invested in manufacturing industry would produce 25 times as many jobs as an equivalent investment in uranium mining. Let us also not forget the hidden cost to the community of uranium mining with its accompanying dangers of nuclear weapons proliferation and the ever expanding dumps of nuclear waste.

Reference was also made in the Governor-General's Speech to the encouragement of growth in the private sector, yet small business, which provides up to half Australia's jobs, is being hit by a shortage of available finance, high interest rates and inequitable taxation structures as a result of Government policy.

After five years of continual and confusing changes to the health insurance system and the complete destruction of Medibank, health care is now in complete chaos. The cost of health insurance is too high for many low and middle income earners. In consequence, they are not taking out health insurance but are relying on keeping healthy and on using the public hospitals for treatment of unexpected illness. The health care of the nation should not be subjected to a Liberal philosophy which categorises illness as a personal responsibility and which encourages profit seeking at the expense of the sick. How else could one describe, for example, the growth of overseas multinational hospital corporations in Australia?

Two public hospitals and one community health centre provide public health facilities for the people of La Trobe. The Maroondah Hospital and the Maroondah Social Health Centre, are both situated in Ringwood in the neighbouring electorate of Casey. Both institutions are suffering financial difficulties. The William Angliss Hospital is the only public hospital which is located in my electorate and it is undergoing a severe financial crisis which must result in a restriction of services. It is also an appalling fact that it will be at least two years before a casualty department will be available at the William Angliss Hospital. In consequence, major casualty patients, including many road accident victims, occuring in Knox and Sherbrooke have to face a long, 20 kilometre drive to either Box Hill or Dandenong hospitals before they can receive treatment.

With the last available statistics indicating a ratio of 2,239 people to every medical practitioner in the electoral sub-division of Knox, compared to 580 people to every medical practitioner in Melbourne and its inner suburbs, it is a disgrace that funds are not made available to support the community health centres in La Trobe. It is even more reprehensible that the Government, by cutting the funding for existing community health centres, is causing a severe restriction of their much needed services. The lack of health care in my electorate is a direct consequence of the emasculation by the Government of Medibank, the failure to provide funds for health development programs and a cutback in the provision of State government funds for public hospitals. The latest cutback involves the removal of vitamins, laxatives and pain relieving drugs from the free list for pensioners. This bureaucratic decision is causing great distress for elderly pensioners as they cannot afford to purchase the drugs and the recommended substitutes are inappropriate and inadequate.

Education is another issue of great concern. Since 1976 the share of the gross national product devoted to education has been reduced from 9 per cent to 8 per cent. At the same time, funds have been disproportionately allocated to private schools at the expense of public schools. This disparity has been particularly evident in La Trobe where two-fifths of the population are of pre-school or school age and where funds for school building programs have been drastically curtailed. It is sometimes argued that the funding of education is primarily a State matter but for me that view represents an abrogation of Commonwealth responsibility. The plain fact is that the Government's new federalism policy, with its devolution of financial and political accountability to State and local governments, is a device to cut back funds for education, health and social welfare. In real terms the States have been starved of funds, none worse than the State of Victoria. The tax sharing arrangements are so inequitable that even the Liberal State Government has been forced to mount a campaign against the Federal Government with which it is normally in sympathy. The lack of funds for education is also causing confrontation between teachers and the State education authorities. The confrontation is being fuelled by the implementation by the Victorian Minister of Education of limited tenure employment and teacher-in-excess policies, which are being used as a means of pruning running costs. Such policies involve considerable personal hardship for teachers and result in a lack of teaching continuity for pupils.

Another serious problem is housing. Two-thirds of home occupiers in La Trobe are paying off housing loans and the ever increasing interest rates are making large holes in family budgets. Each one per cent rise in interest rates as a result of government policy can cost a home buyer an additional $5 a week. The typical home buyer is now paying $16 a week more in interest than one year ago. With the average cost of a house being around $43,000, it is generally only two income families which can now afford to buy their own home. The new Home Savings Grant Scheme introduced by the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) provides no help for those people already buying their homes. For home seekers, the required deposits remain unobtainably high and borrowing capacity is unrealistically low.

Finally, I wish to comment on the severe lack of public transport in my electorate. We have a rail service which is inadequate for the regular train travellers. For the many people who live in locations which are isolated from the rail network, the bus services are infrequent, unreliable and badly co-ordinated. For young families, the aged, the handicapped and the unemployed, the lack of transport facilities causes depression and loneliness. Honourable members on this side of the House have drawn attention to the government cuts in State government grants for public transport. This apparent saving in costs is no real saving. A greater use of public transport would provide energy conservation and reduce traffic congestion, road accidents and pollution. What is even more important, an increase in funds for public transport facilities would improve the quality of life for many of the people.

I have dealt at length with the problems of my electorate because I believe it is important for Government members to appreciate how the policies of their Government have affected my constituents. It is equally important to bear in mind that my electorate is, in many respects, a microcosm of urban Australia and our problems are reflected in every metropolitan city in Australia. It has been a disastrous five years and government policy, so briefly sketched in the Governor-General's Speech, makes it clear that the position will become worse. The strategy of the Government is a continuation of the policies which have resulted in a transfer of resources from the public sector to the private sector. Put in another way, this means a redistribution of resources away from wages, salaries and government expenditure towards corporate profit.

There is nothing abstract, specialised or rarefied-to paraphrase an extract from the Governor-General's Speech-about what the Government has been doing in the name of the people. Real wages have been reduced by plateau and partial indexation. The social wage has been cut. The unemployment pool has been maintained and expanded to discipline the work force. The national income has been redistributed towards corporate profits. The Government's role in economic management has been reduced and last, but not least, so far as Victoria is concerned, there has been a forced decline in the domestic manufacturing and construction industries in favour of overseas owned, monopoly corporations. All of these actions have been made under the mantle of Liberal philosophy and they have resulted in a decline in the standard of living of the majority of Australians. It is hypocritical for the Government to express concern for people when policies are being followed which will cause a deterioration in the lives of those people. The Governor-General's Speech referred to the policy speech which the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) delivered to the nation on 30 September of last year. That speech indicated a need for a broad-based and responsible program of national development and mentioned prospective investments of $29,000m. It is not difficult to envisage how this investment will take place because it is already pouring in from overseas. It will be neither broad-based nor responsible for it will be used predominantly to exploit our mineral resources. Such development will benefit Western Australia and Queensland, and to a lesser extent, New South Wales, but Victoria and Tasmania will be largely neglected. Nor is it the people of Australia who will gain the primary benefit from these developments, but overseas investors and mining entrepreneurs. Manufacturing industry will decline still further as cheap imports flood into the country in exchange for our mineral exports. Government planning and control could prevent the resultant dislocation of our economy but Liberal philosophy believes in the free flow of market forces, unhindered by government regulation. The Government's blind adherence to this doctrinaire obsession was indicated in the Governor-General's Speech when he said:

A sustained lift in exports and a higher level of capital inflow will increase Australia's capacity to import and to undergo the structural changes which will allow economic growth to build upon itself as resources move to areas of higher profitability. My Government will encourage this process . . .

Make no mistake about it. The process which will be encouraged is one which will involve the loss of employment for many thousands of workers, particularly in Victoria. Some honourable members on the Government benches appear to gain satisfaction from their description of Opposition members as socialists. Apparently they believe that this description is in some way derogatory. The democratic socialist tradition of the Australian Labor Party envisages a greater participation by Australians in making the policy decisions which shape their lives.

In his admirable speech the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) indicated the framework of democratic socialism. However, since the views of ALP parliamentarians are often misrepresented I will emphasise some of the practical aspects. In practical terms it means the introduction of industrial democracy and an expansion of public enterprise. It involves a complete restructuring of our taxation system so that wealthy individuals and corporations contribute equitably to government revenue as opposed to the present blatant and unscrupulous use of tax avoidance schemes. Above all, it envisages a public planning framework within which development plans would be formulated, guided not by the vagaries of profit-seeking but by the community need of all Australians. To be part of such a tradition is in no way derogatory. It embraces policies which the Australian people will increasingly come to accept as a viable alternative to the conservative philosophy and policies of the present Government. I strongly urge honourable members to support the amendment moved to the Address-in-Reply by the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent), an amendment which succinctly highlights the abysmal failures of government policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling the honourable member for Chisholm I remind honourable members that this is his maiden speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harris Mr G.McD.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is both an honour and a pleasure to represent in this place the people of Chisholm, an area I know very well. I have worked and lived in that area virtually the whole of my life. The seat of Chisholm has had three representatives, Sir Wilfred Kent-Hughes, Tony Staley and myself. Sir Wilfred served the Chisholm area in the Victorian and Federal Parliaments for 43 years-22 years in the State Parliament and 21 years in the Federal Parliament. He was a Minister in both Parliaments. He was a veteran of two world wars, a Rhodes scholar, and an Olympic representative. He continued to serve the people of Chisholm until his death in 1970. He was then aged 75. His remarkable life is amply testified to in the many speeches made by honourable members of this House on the occasion of the motion of condolence, including speeches made by the present Speaker, the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) and the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren).

SPEECH.PARA: Tony Staley was in terms of parliamentary time a dramatic contrast to Sir Wilfred. He served in the House for 10 years and retired at the early age of 41. His career none the less was a distinguished one. Prior to his election he was a senior lecturer at Melbourne University. He was from 1968 to 1970 a member of the Victorian State Executive of the Liberal Party. He was elected to this Parliament in September 1970. From April 1973 to November 1975 he was Parliamentary Secretary and subsequently Parliamentary Assistant to the Leader of the Opposition. For nearly five of his 10 years in Parliament he was a Minister. He was first appointed Minister for the Capital Territory in February 1976, a portfolio he held until his appointment as Minister for Post and Telecommunications in December 1977. He held this portfolio until his retirement in October 1980. He was also for a time Minister Assisting the Prime Minister in the Arts. The various areas of the arts have always been of particular interest to Tony Staley. Honourable members may recall his liking for poetry.

Tony Staley worked hard at his job. In common with many honourable members he saw less of his family than he would have liked. Perhaps I should report to the House that he now presents a re- laxed advertisement of the benefits of early retirement. On behalf of the people of Chisholm, whom he represented over the last decade, I would like to thank Tony Staley for his service. I wish him and his family well for the future.
Honourable members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —The electorate of Chisholm is an urban seat. It is part of the eastern Melbourne metropolitan area. It covers the city of Box Hill, and parts of the cities of Camberwell, Waverley and Nunawading. Some sections of the present electorate of Chisholm were in the past represented by Mr Speaker and the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Jarman). Chisholm is essentially a residential area. There are some limited areas of industry. In parts there has been flat, or home unit development. But the dominant feature of the electorate is that it is almost uniformly an area of houses, of family homes. Chisholm can quite accurately be described as a family residential area. In saying this I do not ignore, indeed I include, the significant numbers of people who are of or who are approaching pensionable age. They are, typically, people whose families have grown up but who continue to live in the family home. The interests and the concerns of the ordinary Australian family are very much those of the people of Chisholm.

SPEECH.PARA: The welfare of the family is and must remain an important objective of this Government. It was good to see that in His Excellency's Speech this commitment was plainly stated. In the words of the Governor-General the Government: 'Will be looking at its policies with the objective of further enhancing the position of Australian families'. As the Governor-General said in his speech, this will strengthen the basic social fabric of this country. Families involve the concept of dependence. They require a long term commitment to persons. They provide stability and perform valuable functions in caring for children, the sick and the aged who otherwise would have to be looked after by the state. The family unit can carry out these roles best and at least cost. It is the most cost effective way of providing many social services.

When the Government looks at the various ways in which it can assist Australian families I encourage it to look at the family allowance. The development of the present system of family allowances was an initiative of this Government and one of which it can be proud. The replacement of the previous system by the family allowance took place several years ago. Since that date the amount payable has not been altered. I accept that the necessity to control inflation and to limit expenditure has imposed restraints on this and other programs. But following upon the stated objective of enhancing the position of Australian families I hope that action can now be taken to increase the amount payable by way of family allowance. It is not just a question of allowing for inflation over the period since the amounts paid were last fixed. I believe that the Government should consciously and deliberately benefit those who have the responsibility of bringing up and supporting families.

If the Government is prepared to make the family allowance taxable, it will be able to provide for a substantial increase while at the same time containing the net cost of such a measure. When, as I hope, the question of an increase in the family allowance is being considered, I would ask that some thought be given to making a proportionately greater provision for the first child. At present the provision for the first child is $3.50 per week, for the second $5 per week, for the third $6 per week and so on. I would have thought that it is the experience of most parents that the first child involves the greatest cost. It is the child who occasions the setting up expenses; it is the child for whom there are no hand-me-downs. Perhaps more significantly, these days the arrival of the first child is the circumstance which causes the wife-the mother-to cease employment. It is a time when an income supplement can be of real use. A number of methods have been put forward as a means of assisting families, but it seems to me that the system of family allowances is of particular value because, being in the form of a direct payment, it is of greatest value to those who need it most.

The next topic I would like to turn to also bears upon the well-being of Australian families-that is, family law in Australia. The Commonwealth Family Law Act is in a sense misnamed. It should be called the 'some of the family law' Act. Many facets of family activity are not covered by the Act. I would like to bring out the kind of complications that exist as a result of the incomplete jurisdiction of the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth Constitution only gives to this Parliament power over 'marriages', 'divorce and matrimonial causes and, in relation thereto, parental rights and the custody and guardianship of infants'. Before the enactment of the 1959 Matrimonial Causes Act the Commonwealth had sought to exercise its powers in only very limited areas. By that Act the Commonwealth established a single divorce law for the whole of Australia and provided for the determination of custody, maintenance and property proceedings. However, if no divorce proceedings were on foot, these disputes, as with all other matters of family law, remained subject to the different laws of the various States. Under the 1959 Act no family court was set up and the Act was administered through the State courts. Although this Act was an improvement it was still limited in its application. Further, being administered through the different State courts, there were differences of approach and problems of enforcement. It was demonstrated to be inadequate.

When the 1975 Family Law Act was introduced it was hoped to bring within Commonwealth jurisdiction not only custody, property and maintenance disputes when ancillary to divorce proceedings but also all proceedings relating to custody access and maintenance of children of the marriage, maintenance of either party to a marriage, and property of the parties or either of them. Experience and the High Court have shown that this hope cannot yet be fulfilled. High Court rulings and subsequent amendments to the Act have imposed limitations on the operation of Commonwealth family law. This limited power has meant that disputes over property or over custody of children may have to be brought in some instances in a State court and in other instances in the Family Court. Worse, in some cases litigation may ensue in both jurisdictions.

I will show by example what this can mean. A dispute between a married or divorced couple over a child who is or was a member of the household but who is not the natural or adopted child of both parents-for example, a stepchild-is within the jurisdiction of the States. At the same time, that same husband and wife may well be in dispute over children who are their natural children. This dispute would have to be handled in the Family Court. This kind of example is not uncommon. With the increasing number of divorces there has also been an increasing number of second marriages. In consequence, there are more families consisting of both natural children of the parties and stepchildren. This situation can lead to real difficulties for the courts. The State and Federal courts can each be faced with the problem of dealing with some children of a household where they would prefer to treat them all as one family unit but they can deal only with those children before them. Again, where a third party-most often a grandparent or an aunt-makes a claim for custody of a child, a State court is the appropriate venue. With a greater number of marriages breaking down an increasing number of relatives are being asked to care for children and this promotes this very kind of litigation. However, if an order has previously been made for custody, guardianship or access in proceedings between the parents, proceedings between a third party and a parent may take place in the Family Court.

At present, property disputes between a husband and a wife remain within the determination of State courts until divorce proceedings are instituted, which means 12 months after the parties have commenced to live apart. This can lead to various manoeuvres in the State court with one party trying to get the case on while the other stonewalls until the 12 months are up. Meantime, the Family Court may well be hesitant about making a final determination regarding the custody of children because it does not know what accommodation will be ultimately available for them. The end result of this fragmentation of jurisdiction is additional costs, inconvenience, delays and emotional trauma. The emotional content in this jurisdiction should not be overlooked. It is said that justice delayed is justice denied. That is true no doubt. In the context of family law, where feelings are often strained, justice delayed is bitterness exacerbated. The price paid for all this is not just a matter of human hurt; nor are the costs left just with the parties. The additional legal aid, the provision of social security payments and the employment of various kinds of social workers are a charge on the whole community. They are an inevitable consequence of the circumstances of family law in this country at the moment.

A number of solutions have been put forward to resolve this unhappy set of circumstances. The Federal Government can begin by ensuring that it uses its legislative powers to the fullest extent. There are two areas in particular where the extent of Commonwealth power is worth exploring. Firstly, we should re-enact the earlier definition of child of the marriage. It also included any child adopted by either party since the marriage, with the consent of the other party, and a child of either party if at the relevant time the child was ordinarily a member of the household of the marriage. The High Court has ruled that proceedings should be limited to children who are the natural or adopted children of parties to a marriage. However when this ruling was made, no reasons were given in support of such a limited definition. Further, a very similar definition had existed for a long time in the previous Matrimonial Causes Act without challenge. It is not possible to be sure that the broader definition will not again run into difficulties with the High Court, but because of the problems existing at the moment in custody matters I believe it ought to be tested.

The second area where legislation may be worth while is the area of matrimonial property. An examination of High Court judgments would suggest that the Commonwealth, relying on the marriage power, may be able to legislate in respect of property which has been acquired or is used in the business of the marriage. If this is so, at least these kinds of assets would not need to be tied to property proceedings ancillary to the divorce power. Neither of these solutions would completely solve the problem I have described. They would both have to tread the constitutional minefield. To achieve finally an end to the fragmentation of jurisdiction, one of four solutions will have to be accepted. The first is a reference by the States to the Commonwealth of the relevant power.
