The second is the establishment of a State family court system along the lines of that operating in Western Australia. The third is the issue of dual commissions to judges of the Family Court to permit them to exercise power under State law. The fourth solution is to amend the Constitution by referendum to give the Commonwealth power to deal with these matters. None of those four avenues of reform is without its problems. To be achieved they will, in each instance, have to be supported by the States.

If one looks at what has occurred to date it is hard to be confident that co-operation will be forthcoming from all of the States. The reference of powers by the States to the Commonwealth clearly is the best of the four courses of action. In saying this, I acknowledge that the State Family Court in Western Australia has worked well but that approach has its problems. For example, appeals go to the State Supreme Court where the court has exercised State jurisdiction and to the Full Court of the Family Court where it has exercised Federal jurisdiction. A similar situation would arise if the solution of dual commissions were to be tried. I need hardly tell any honourable member in this place that referendums have a high failure rate especially when they are subject to opposition. This course should be viewed very much as a last resort.

There may be some argument about how best to resolve the problems that have risen as a result of the split jurisdiction but there surely can be no dispute as to the need to achieve a resolution. I hope that the State governments will have regard to the continuing cost, the inconvenience and the hurt suffered by their residents at present. I urge the Federal Government to press on and to use its legislative power to the fullest extent, while at the same time seeking an accommodation with the States to obtain a reference to the relevant powers.

In conclusion, while listening the other day to the speeches on a motion of condolence, I was very much struck by the way in which all of the speakers in this place from whichever side referred to the fact that Eric Robinson was able to fight and fight hard but still retain their friendship. I expect that while we are here we will have many disagreements. It would be disappointing if we did not. I hope in the end that we will still retain regard for one another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Chisholm (Mr Harris) on his maiden speech and on the points of substantial importance which he made. I wish him well in this Parliament while he represents his party and his electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: With the elections behind us, the start of a new parliament is a proper and necessary time to take stock, to offer observations and to make commitments for the conduct of the nation's affairs for the next three years. We, in the Australian Labor Party, strongly dispute the actions and policies of the Government coalition parties. We dispute vigorously what we see as their preference for sectional privilege. But we do not dispute the fact that the Australian people have made their choice and that they have given our political opponents opposite a mandate for the new term ahead. It will be our role in the next three years to assist, where possible, and to criticise when necessary. We will be neither obstructive nor compliant. It is the Government's role to govern within the terms of the people's mandate. It is our role to seek to ensure that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and his colleagues do so as fairly, as justly, and as efficiently as possible for the benefit of all Australians.

Within those parameters, the Government will receive our support, for whilst we all represent various diverse electorates throughout the country, and whilst we come to this Parliament representing different political parties, all honourable members on both sides of the House should first and foremost represent Australia. The people who sent us here expect fair and proper conduct, and fair and proper administration. They expect their national parliament to uphold the national interest and to carry out policy, in the day to day affairs of public life, that fairly looks after all sections of the community.

We discredit ourselves, and we damage our nation's potential if we allow this place, this Parliament and our conduct as parliamentarians to become remote from, or aloof to, the hopes, the needs, and the aspirations of the Australian people. I cannot stress too strongly that I refer to all Australians, wherever they live and whatever their social and economic circumstances. It is this theme that I want to develop more broadly today-the theme of the absolute need for national government to recognise at all times that it is elected to govern on behalf of the people; not institutions, narrow sectional interests, overseas mining companies, or privileged groups of great and powerful friends, but people and-I stress-all the people.
I acknowledge that the Governor-General's Speech refers to policies developed over the last five years. I quote from that Speech where it was stated:

These policies are designed to work for the well-being of all Australians, to develop a society which maximises the reward of individual effort and initiative, and which also respects the rights of individuals to shape their own lives.

These are fine words and admirable sentiments. Unfortunately, they have no relevance at all for a very large section of the Australian community who so far, under this Government's policies, have reaped no rewards of any kind, nor been given any reasonable opportunity to shape their own lives. I talk, of course, about the 480,000 Australians who cannot find jobs. I talk of the two million Australians-I stress the figure of two million-who now live in poverty, a total which has doubled over the past five years. I talk of our black Australians, the most disadvantaged and neglected group of people in our society. I talk also of a great proportion of our new settler Australians. Lastly, I talk of the many pensioner Australians, our young Australians, and our sick and hospitalised Australians. The Fraser Government has failed all of these people in recent years.

They have been the worst casualties of a rigid and unyielding approach to economic management which has done nothing for their wellbeing except to denigrate it and which has maximised only the distress and desperation in which most of them now live. By and large, most of them either do not have the dignity of a job, the comfort of a decent home, the security of enough money to pay essential bills, the opportunity of a reasonable education, or the right to be free of the fear of expensive illness. In many cases, these people have none of what should be the simple basics of life in such a wealthy country like ours, and their numbers are increasing. It is these people to whom Government has become little more than a symbol of worn-out and discredited slogans, slick and deceitful advertising, and of rank social injustice and economic unfairness.

The Prime Minister would do well to remember that the process of government does not begin and end with the fine words of his speechwriters. It is all very well to send 3,000 words of scripted prose to the Governor-General on what the Government would like the Australian people to believe is the tenet under which it will administer the nation's affairs for the next three years. It is quite another thing to make that script come alive, to give substance to the rhetoric, and credibility to the promises, particularly for those many Australian who have heard them all before and who still find that they make up the many hundreds of thousands of losers in our society. It is for these people, and the great majority of all Australian families who have seen their living standards go backwards over the last five years, that the Government must start living up to its word.

We cannot expect people to respect their country's political institutions if they become convinced that those institutions have no real regard for their welfare and livelihood. We cannot gain their trust in politicians if those politicians continue to display an arrogant disregard of their campaign pledges, and a contemptuous indifference to their responsibilities to the community as a whole. Far too many promises to the people have been dishonored in the last five years-promises concerning the full range of unemployment, interest rates, inflation, the Medibank health insurance scheme, lower taxation, smaller government, Aboriginal welfare, community programs, wage indexation, education funding, housing, social welfare and ministerial appointments.

This Government, at the start of a new parliamentary term, has a new opportunity to fulfill those pledges, and to reach towards the real potential of our country to the benefit of all Australians. It will have the fullest support of those on this side of the House if it honestly seeks to do so, if the Prime Minister will cease persistently attempting to divide the community, if he will accept his responsibilities to all sections of our society and if he will work for consensus rather than confrontation and the broad national interest instead of sectional privilege. I assure him it really is not all that difficult. It simply requires that the Government spend less time spoon-feeding the BHPs and the CRAs and the Ansett Airlines of this world, and give a great deal more attention to listening to, and acting upon, the basic needs of the Australian people. After all, big business in this country has had a pretty fair go from the Fraser Government since 1975. In the last five Budgets, tax concessions to the corporate sector, particularly the mining industry, have amounted to $3,000m in current terms. For a Prime Minister who is forever decrying the evils of big government and the imperative of small government supposedly to benefit ordinary people, the honourable member for Wannon seems not to have been embarrassed at such plundering of the public purse for the benefit of so small and privileged a section of the community.

Given the increasingly high profits in recent years of so much of big business, and especially the mining companies, many Australians could be excused for asking why such large public funding might not have been diverted to areas more directly benefiting the community as a whole. The Government at last now has the opportunity to re-order its priorities. If it really intends, as it says, to support policies which are-I quote it again-'designed to work for the well-being of all Australians', it surely cannot continue to scale down government spending in areas directly affecting people and then use those funds to subsidise big business's profitability.

This broad and vital issue of exactly who the Government serves in this country will, for our part, be one of the dominant issues of political debate throughout the life of this new Parliament. We make no apology for our commitment to the necessity for government to reverse its withdrawal from a direct involvement in the funding of so many aspects of community life. The simple, unvarnished fact is that, for most Australians, there cannot be an adequate level of security, comfort or satisfaction in our society unless there is an adequate level of government involvement on their behalf. That means, among other things, a more effective and certainly a fairer redistribution of the great wealth generated in Australia, which is restricted to comparatively so few people. It also means not only the provision of material satisfaction, of physical and social security, but the provision of an adequate contribution in support of those aspects of community life which inspire creative endeavour and promote a strong and confident cultural identity and independence of expression. It means as well that we must adopt a longer-term perspective to economic and social planning to properly equip Australia and its people, not just for the 1980s and 1990s but into the twenty-first century.

There is not the slightest indication in the Governor-General's speech of any such forward thinking, let alone planning. It would seem the future is being left to look after itself, while the Government concentrates on a perspective limited to the next six to 12 months. This cannot be justified in any terms, given the major resource development now getting under way in many parts of the country, which could seriously distort our economy for many years unless properly managed and regulated to ensure the widest benefit to the greatest number of Australians. Let me make it clear. We want and need mineral development at a pace that can be accomodated by our social and economic system. We want its benefits to be shared fairly by all Australians. We want more of the prosperity generated by this development to stay in Australia and to be used to revitalise our factories and our manufacturing industry, to provide jobs where they are needed most-in our great cities and provincial centres-and to strengthen our whole economy. We must have a resources tax that guarantees a fair profit return to mining companies but which does not allow excessive profits to be drawn off overseas. It is the only way to ensure adequate retention and fair redistribution of our vast mineral wealth. We want a confident foreign investment policy that maximises Australian ownership instead of selling out to foreign carpetbaggers and overseas board rooms.

I can find none of these matters dealt with in the Government's speech opening this first session of the thirty-second Parliament. Not a single line is given to explaining whether, or how, resource development is to be properly managed to maximise the benefits to the national economy. It seems a curious omission by a government which for so long has been insisting so stridently that resource development is the answer to all the economic problems it has not been able to solve in the last five years. We do not accept the Government's exaggerated claims and its failure to offer the Australian people any detailed knowledge of what government planning is going on. The failure only increases our scepticism of the forecast extent of this development. Yet the complex problems are considerable-problems involving the competition for investment capital; the impact of this competition on the general interest rate structure; its spin-off effect on manufacturing industry, small business and consumer credit; the claims to be made on public sector infrastructure capital for development related to the new mining projects; the effect in turn of those claims on the capital funds available to local government and public instrumentalities like Telecom Australia and public transportation authorities; the impact on the supply or money or large capital inflows from overseas and its likely effects on inflation; the influence of increased mineral export income on higher imports and the value of the dollar; and so on. None of these problems has been attended to. All of them are difficult and complex, but none of them is insurmountable.

Careful planning by concerned government will ensure that a regulated level of mineral development will not distort or damage our traditional economy, and that these problems I mentioned will not impede development. It is simply a matter of the Government getting itself into gear. Obviously this is not occurring, either because the Government does not comprehend exactly what is involved, or because it intends merely to ignore its responsibilities to the Australian people and allow development to proceed at whatever pace the mining companies like, irrespective of the consequences. Whatever the case, the Government's complacency is totally unjustified.

My colleagues and I consider that the issue of mineral development will be the great economic and political issue of the next 10 years. We do not see it as a matter simply to be rolled out for its 'gee-whiz' value at election time. It could be, and should be, an issue on which there is bipartisan agreement in this Parliament, just as there is already bipartisan agreement on the massive North West Shelf gas project. That is how importantly we view this matter. So far, however, we have heard nothing but rhetoric from the Government, and only in the context of the last two election campaigns. This seems to me to be selling Australia short on an issue of the most profound importance to the future of this country.

Unfortunately, the same sort of behaviour befuddles the continuing debate of so-called big government versus small government, a debate conducted in cliches for much of the past five years. Since 1975 there has been a good deal of posturing by honourable members opposite on behalf of small and efficient government, as they describe it. At the same time they have practised the deception of bigger government to serve the interests of the privileged. The present Government believes in redistribution as passionately as anyone on this side of the House, but it reverses the process-from the needy to the greedy.

What the Prime Minister and his colleagues are really opposed to is not big government, for government in Australia is now as big as it has ever been in peace time, but fair and efficient government that protects and services the interests of all Australians. Their argument in support of small government has been nothing more than a public rationalisation of their persistent scaling down of funds, right across the board, that go directly to community and welfare support to benefit the multitude of ordinary Australians who are the backbone of this great country.

What has been intended is an assault on the confidence of the Australian people in the capacity of government to serve community needs, and in the dedication and efficiency of the public work force. If this succeeds, it is then only a further short step to convincing people that they in fact are better off with more government neglect, fewer government services, and less government welfare. For example, government policies of strict staff ceilings and restricted finance for key areas of the public sector have struck Telecom with punishing effect. Telecom is now quite unable to meet growing demands for its services. The Government reacts by publicly questioning Telecom's ability to perform its designated function.

The scenario goes like this: Telecom is a big public instrumentality generating increased public dissatisfaction because it cannot now service public needs; therefore, such instrumentalities are inherently bad, their usefulness and cost effectiveness are matters of increasing doubt and they should be cut back. It is a discreditable tactic. Telecom's problems are the direct result of the Government's ideaological malice toward efficient state-run enterprises.

To reinforce my point, I need only remind the House of the proposal continually raised within the Government to sell Trans-Australia Airlines. In Telecom's case, the Prime Minister now misuses the circumstances created by his Government's policies as a cudgel against it. In Perth, only a fortnight ago, he was suggesting publicly that profitable areas of Telecom's operations could well be opened up to private entrepreneurs. It sounded very much like the opening shots of a quite deliberate campaign to dismantle Telecom in the same way that Medibank was hacked to pieces over a period of two years.

The real political debate should not be about big government because government is as big as ever under the Fraser Government. The real political debate should be about good government. It should not be about what the Government describes so abusively as a parasitic Public Service, but about the privileged parasites who feed off the Government's handouts to its friends and supporters. Even an organisation such as the Murdoch empire believes big government can be good government when it is an active government operating on its behalf. With a stroke of the Government's compliant pen, the Murdoch group is about to have broadcasting and television legislation and the two-airline policy rewritten on the group's behalf.

TALK.START.PARA: —A licence to print money.

—Exactly; one has only to recall the role of the Murdoch newspapers in the last three national election campaigns to understand that Mr Murdoch recognises good government-big or small-as government that can be controlled, government that pays up on its election IOUs and with a handsome dividend. Anyone who seriously doubts what I say need only wait for the revamped broadcasting and television legislation the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) will bring into this House this session. (Extension of time granted). We on this side of the House have little doubt that this new legislation will ensure that Mr Murdoch keeps the Melbourne television station which a public tribunal, in a public hearing, ordered last October he must sell in the public interest. The public interest will now be circumvented by Government fiat. Obviously this is what the Government means when it says that its policies are designed to-and again I quote-'maximise the reward of individual effort and initiative'.

SPEECH.PARA: A similar set of double standards operates whenever we hear the Government attacking State enterprise and extolling the market force economy and free enterprise competition. Neither of these curious animals is anything more than a myth when applied to the monopolistic and cosseted atmosphere that cocoons much of industry in this country. The Fraser Government cannot possibly believe that commercial giants like BHP and CSR are the odd corner store writ larger. Certainly nobody else does.

If we really want to fill the corporate sector with fear and loathing we need only talk seriously about opening up the market place to some real free enterprise competition. The Ansett corporation, for instance, argues persistently in support of being allowed to compete against Qantas Airways Ltd on overseas air routes. The competition, says Ansett, would be good for Qantas as well as good for Australia. But Ansett is much less forthcoming about Qantas competing within Australia on the longer routes between capitals, because the competition would be unhealthy for Ansett, particularly for Ansett's profits-the principle being, of course, that competition is good when you can rig it to give you an edge over your opponent or an avenue to greater profits. Where it does not, where competition is commercially dangerous and one is big enough and influential enough to twist the Government's arm, one makes very sure that competition does not take place.

That is the real scandal of the two-airline agreement, an agreement which for many years was constructed to suit the best interests of a previous benefactor and handholder of a succession of Liberal-Country Party governments, and which is now being re-worded to suit his more ambitious successor. Once again, the public interest and the future of a viable state-run enterprise are of secondary importance to privileged sectional advantage.

In looking beyond our shores, I agree with the Government's assessment that the next decade will be difficult and unstable. But we must be careful to avoid excessive gloom at the beginning of the 1980's simply to compensate for excessive optimism at the beginning of the 1970s. There is every justification for concern about the actions and intention of the Soviet Union, but not obsessive preoccupation. At the same time, we cannot be totally uncritical in our new relations with China.

We are not a great power on the world stage, but we can have a greater influence in our own region. We can help shape a sensible set of international attitudes that promote peace and greater international understanding. We can defend basic human rights and establish international respect for the consistency and fairness in which we promote our national interests as an independent state.

The strategic arms race is not an exclusive prerogative of the super-powers. The new doctrine of limited nuclear war has the gravest implications for Australia. United States of America installations in Australia fulfil all of the requirements for a first Soviet target in a limited exchange with the United States. The Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) casually announced last year that Australia was in fact a nuclear target.

In those sobering circumstances we should seek, with all of the diligence and persuasiveness we can muster, to be one of the key protagonists of detente. We should give balanced and fair opinions to our allies. We should not cringe before great and powerful friends. That means more forethought and, where appropriate, greater independence of our allies. Australia must work with its allies to achieve mutual aims. But we must not allow ourselves to be used for objectives we believe to be based on false interpretations of international events. We have to remember that alliance does not equal servitude.

A clear miscalculation would be for our closest ally, the United States, to embark on unwise policies that converted El Salvador into another Vietnam or an American Afghanistan. In the proper forums we should not hestitate to say no. We should urge on the new administration in Washington the futility of trying to store up aggressive right wing regimes, just as we persistently oppose oppressive left wing regimes. We must be steady supporters of human rights. It is not our right to tell other countries how to organise their societies. But we have the right to choose our friends and to demand the observance of international law concerning the oppression of political and civil liberties.

We often hear Government members attack repression in Vietnam, but we have heard almost nothing from them on human rights closer to home in the Philippines and Indonesia. Our servility towards Indonesia seems to know no bounds, despite that country's appalling record in Timor and the intimidation and political harrassment of those who fail to support President Suharto. We in the Labor Party do not subscribe to the belief that Indonesia is vitally important to Australia and we are of only marginal importance to it. We are neighbours, we have to live with each other, but we do not have to accept so meekly the contemptuous and offhand treatment now regularly handed out to us.

In conclusion, I congratulate the new members now serving in their first Parliament. I regret there are not more from the Australian Labor Party. A comparative handful of votes is all that now separates honourable members opposite from being returned to their rightful places on this side of the House. It will be our task over the life of this new Parliament to ensure they do not miss out at the next opportunity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) in congratulating those new members on both sides of the House who have joined the Parliament as a result of the election which was held in October last year. The Address-in-Reply debate provides to speakers on both sides of the House the traditional opportunity of reviewing any aspect of government policy or, indeed, any aspect of the policies of the alternative government of this country. Not unnaturally I will direct some of my remarks to the Australian economy. Again, I take this opportunity of observing what developments have occurred in the Australian economy since the Budget of August 1980 was brought down. I do so in the context, as I did yesterday, of reminding the House of some of the things that have been said by the Leader of the Opposition who has just concluded speaking and by other front bench spokesmen on behalf of the Opposition recenty and over the past few years about the economic policies of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been a fairly constant theme of speeches of the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) that the economic policies of this Government have failed, created conditions of recession, brought about stagnation, discouraged investment and consumer spending and created a sense of despondency, hesitancy and caution on the part of consumers in Australia. The truth, of course, is that virtually every day evidence is emerging of just how wrong those descriptions have been. Evidence is emerging of how correct the Government was in taking the decision it took in 1976 to put the first priority on reducing inflation and how wrong were the descriptions of the 1978, 1979 and 1980 Budgets by the Opposition and other supporters of the Opposition in the community.

The truth is that the policies of this Government are now bearing fruit. Not only have we attained a position in the world in respect of our rate of inflation that is the envy of most of the industrialised world, but also we are now starting to see, quite unambiguously and supported by statistics and economic indicators across a very broad front, the evidence of strong growth in the Australian economy. We are seeing it not only in the sector of the economy which has had most publicity in recent years, that is the mining sector, but also in the manufacturing sector, the sector that probably suffered more than any other industry sector in Australia when the high inflation of the early and middle 1970s came. It was also the sector which produced the largest number of people who became unemployed during those years. That sector has also experienced considerable growth, not only in domestic activity but also in export activity.

Who would have believed three or four years ago that 1979-80 would see a significant rise of about 30 per cent in the volume of manufactured exports from Australia? People may have believed that in respect of primary produce, or the mining industry, but they would have greeted such a claim regarding the manufacturing industry with very considerable scepticism. The better investment policies, the lower inflation policies, and the policies of making this country more competitive in the world economic environment, have provided a stimulus not only to the mining and rural industries but also, significantly, to the Australian manufacturing industry. We have seen markets open up for Australian manufacturers that would not have been thought possible only a few short years ago. So this growth is occurring across all sectors of the Australian economy.

Another development that has been particularly pleasing in recent months has been the strengthening in the employment situation. I do not pretend, nor does anyone on this side of the House, that the problem of unemployment is behind us. Clearly, it is not. We still have an unemployment level in this country which is far too high and on that there is common agreement in this Parliament. We may disagree as to how the problem should be tackled but at least there is common agreement that it still remains. Even on that front the growth in employment has been so strong in recent months that we have started to see a brightening picture of the unemployment level. For example, in the 1980 calendar year employment in Australia grew by about 2.7 per cent or 169,000 to 170,000 people. This employment growth, of course, is a direct result of the increased economic activity across the various sectors of Australian industry that I have mentioned.

In recent months we have also seen for the first time very encouraging evidence of a sustained growth in the volume of retail sales. Only a few months ago I was told by people on the other side of the House: 'Well, you have got some capital investment and you may be doing a little better on the external account but the real Achilles' heel of the Government's policies is where it counts and that is the willingness of consumers to spend their dollars'. They pointed with satisfaction at fairly modest rises in the volume of consumer sales. They can no longer do that because there has been a strengthening in the volume of consumer sales which is further evidence of gathering economic activity.

Only 12 or 18 months ago the Opposition fairly regularly introduced matters of public importance into this House about the volume of overseas borrowings by the Australian Government. I can remember the honourable member for Gellibrand and the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins), as a duo on this subject, fairly regularly arguing that it would be necessary, because of the economic policies of this Government, for us to go on borrowing very large amounts overseas to supplement our external account. What the Government did by way of an official borrowing program from 1977 onwards was a proper, legitimate and entirely justifiable instrument of policy by a government in a country that has always relied on significant inflows of capital to supplement a current account deficit. In no way could the activities which the Government undertook in a proper and orthodox manner during that period be criticised as being other than the correct and sensible economic action. It was done at a time when the Government believed that the fairly subdued volume of private capital inflow was of a temporary character. The Government said at the time that it believed that the right thing to do was to borrow large amounts on official account until more normal levels of private capital inflow were resumed. That prediction and that description have been proved correct. During the past 18 months there has been a major strengthening in the volume of private capital coming into this country.

I know that some members on the other side of the House think there is something wrong with capital coming into this country from overseas sources. They clearly do not want it and would be very happy if it did not come in at all. But the truth is that that money has come into this country because Australia is seen increasingly as an attractive place in which to invest. It is seen as a country that has stable economic conditions, good investment prospects, predictable and certain economic and other policies. Generally it is the sort of place in which people want to make long term and very large investments. We have seen in the last 18 months-it is a very instructive exercise to look at what has happened during that period despite the dire predictions of the Opposition about our external account-a major strengthening. We have been able to scale down quite dramatically the overseas borrowing program that was undertaken in 1977. That is yet a further piece of evidence of the strengthening which has occurred in Australia's international economic reputation.

Yesterday I referred to some capital investment figures which give an idea of the confidence of private investors in the future of Australia. Capital investment, by any measure, is increasing very strongly. New fixed capital expenditure by private enterprise is expected to be 46 per cent higher in the half year to June than it was in the same period last year. If this expectation is realised it will represent a doubling of capital expenditure in the mining industry and a 70 per cent increase in the manufacturing industry. Against that sort of evidence, is it really credible to talk, as did the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) during the McPherson by-election, about a stagnating Australian economy and a failure of government economic policies? Is it any longer credible for members of the Opposition to speak in tones of gloom and despair? These are the figures of an economy which is beginning to reap the benefits of the restraints, the fighting of inflation, that this Government undertook to pursue when it came to office in 1976.

One is reminded that when the Budgets of 1978 and 1979 were brought down, the Leader of the Opposition said that they would drive the Australian economy through the floor, that they would force us into a recession and would produce further stagnation, loss of activity and loss of production. The truth is that the reverse has occurred and is occurring across a very wide front. In my judgment, this is due primarily to the fact that over the last five years the Government has tackled the fundamental problems of the Australian economy. It has not pretended that there was a short cut to economic recovery. It has believed that ultimately economic recovery was possible if one provided for the private sector the environment and incentive, via lower inflation, to invest and therefore produce greater activity. That was the economic prescription that the Government proclaimed, and upon which it was elected, in 1975. We have kept faith with that prescription. We have not been seduced by the blandishments that we have received from the other side, and from elsewhere in the community, over the last four or five years, into believing that large amounts of government stimulus of the economy are needed.

Perhaps more than any other set of statistics, the evidence which is now accumulating about the volume of private sector capital investment demonstrates that if one persists long enough with the right economic policies, if one is prepared to have faith in the ability of the private sector to respond to conditions which stimulate activity investment, the reward will be there. I believe that the Australian economy is now on a stronger base than it has been on for many years. Our growth prospects among countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, according to that Organisation and not just the Commonwealth Government, are considerably greater than those of our principal trading partners. We are feeling less than are many other countries the effect of the temporary economic downturn in the United States. I do not pretend that all of that is due to the Government's economic policies. Some of it is due to the fortuitous destination of many of our exports. I acknowledge that. I say equally that government economic policies have had a great deal to do with the competitiveness of Australian exporters, have had a great deal to do with encouraging people to come to this country. Over the last five years the competitivenes of Australian industry has been significantly improved. That has played a major role in the improved export performance of so many sectors of the Australian economy.

The last three months more than perhaps any time in the last five years have seen evidence of the success of the Government's economic policies. In saying that, I do not in any way regard the job as having been nearly finished. There is still a considerable distance to go in achieving the economic goals of the Government. Unemployment remains too high. Until there is in the community a broader recognition that the cost of labour plays a far greater role in the level of unemployment than the arbitral authorities of this country have been prepared to recognise to date, unemployment will continue to persist as a significant problem. There still remains a significant challenge to this Government and, indeed, to the entire community to find rational solutions to the present unsatisfactory levels of unemployment. We have to recognise that at a time of increased economic activity, particularly in sectors of the economy which will place strains and demands upon fairly scarce resources, it will be necessary to continue to give the very highest priority to our fight against inflation.

Finally, as we go through the 1980s and the economic development and growth of this country proceed, increased demands will be placed upon our resources, not the least of which will be the financial resources available to support the activities of both the public and private sectors of the Australian economy. Even many members of the Opposition are prepared to concede that great private sector investment is not only occurring but also in prospect for the remainder of the 1980s. That makes it all the more imperative that we contain the public sector demand for funds. There is a limit to the funds available for investment. If honourable members believe, as we on this side of the House certainly do, that it is the role of government to encourage activity by the private sector, it is absolutely essential that we so tailor the demands of the public sector that there will be available sufficient financial resources for the private sector to take up. If we really believe in giving priority to the private sector, we must be prepared at all levels-not just at the Federal level but at the State level also-to contain the size both of Budget spending and of the demands we make by way of borrowings on the capital markets of this country. We must be prepared to contain the demands of the public sector as a whole.

When I refer to the public sector and speak about achieving a proper balance between that sector and the private sector in the Australian economy I do not speak just about the size of the Commonwealth Budget deficit. That represents only a portion of the overall public sector borrowing requirement of governments in Australia. It is imperative that we contain, and where possible reduce, the size of the entire public sector borrowing requirement in Australia. That will become a more and more important and urgent responsibility of governments as we go through the 1980s, because the demand for financial resources from the private sector will not diminish but will rather increase. I have pleasure again in complimenting and congratulating those members on both sides of the House who have joined this Parliament and in supporting the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the honourable member for Canberra, I remind the House that this will be the honourable member's maiden speech. Honourable members are requested to extend to the honourable lady the usual courtesy of paying silent attention to her maiden speech. I call the honourable member for Canberra.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was no coincidence that on 18 October 1980 the electors of the seat of Canberra, whom I now have the honour to represent in this Parliament, recorded one of the largest swings against the present Government recorded anywhere in Australia. The outstanding political and economic fact in the Australian Capital Territory is that it reflects more directly, immediately and completely the effects of national government policies than does any other region in Australia. Here the Federal Government alone bears full and undivided responsibility. Here there is no responsibility to share with State governments or local government. Here the consequences of the Government's policy of the past five years have shown up sharpest and worst.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of those policies, the Australian Capital Territory has had, for most of that five year period, the highest unemployment, the highest cost of living, the lowest level of housing and construction activity and the lowest level of business activity in Australia. The youth unemployment situation, in particular, remains appalling. The Bureau of Statistics figures for the last quarter put the unemployment rate for young people aged 15 years to 19 years at 20.8 per cent for the whole of Australia, but 28.9 per cent for the Australian Capital Territory. The figures themselves tell only part of the story of the ravages inflicted on this great Australian community, in terms of its confidence and cohesion, in the past five years. This community has borne not only the heaviest burdens of Government economic policy; it has been the main target and chief victim of a sustained ideological campaign by members of the Government.

I am the third person to represent the seat of Canberra, created in this Parliament in only 1974. Before the 1974 splitting of the Australian Capital Territory into two seats, the Territory comprised one seat, created in 1949 and represented during 19 of its first 21 years by Jim Fraser, one of the most effective and most dedicated local politicians to sit in this Parliament.

Today I wish to put before honourable members three propositions: Firstly, that the unusual system of government administration in the Australian Capital Territory places special responsibility on all members of this Parliament; secondly, that the political myths about this city should be dispelled and members should realise that its inhabitants merely demand fair and equal treatment with other Australians; and, thirdly, that there is a need for this Government to rethink the basis of its policies towards the Public Service before one of the most significant institutions in this country is very severely damaged. On the first point, I stress that while all honourable members have a role in passing Federal laws, when it comes to the Territory they are also fulfilling the role of state and local government. Under Section 122 of the Constitution, the Parliament may make laws for the government of any Territory. This means that all members of the Parliament are responsible for Government of the Australian Capital Territory. I wonder how many honourable members have thought of themselves as the city councillors for Canberra.

Parliament can make laws for its territories on all matters including labour relations, health, education, local government, prices, rents, wills, property, land use and so on. Consider the Minister for the Capital Territory. He has an all-encompassing responsibility for this Territory. There is no other Federal portfolio which so comprehensively affects the lives of so many people. The Minister makes decisions about traffic control, travel for handicapped people, business regulations, the municipal budget which determines the rates people pay and services they get, social and moral issues such as whether we have nude bathing, poker machines or a casino, and other questions such as abortion law. Of course, many of these decisions do not rest just with the Minister, but go to Cabinet.

We have a fully elected 18 strong House of Assembly, now seven years and two elections old, which sits part-time. Its members serve on boards and authorities running the Territory and, despite their total absence of any law-making power, they are dedicated and hard working and make a significant contribution in communicating between rulers and ruled. I know this from my own experience, having been an Assembly member for five years.

Despite the fact that the House of Assembly is elected by the people of the Australian Capital Territory, it is only an advisory body. The members of this Parliament have more real power and responsibility for Australian Capital Territory legislation. There has been much criticism of the Assembly's so-called failure to live with the Government of the day, but this is a two-way process. I have seen Liberal members of the Assembly walk out on Liberal Ministers for the Australian Capital Territory. Before that I saw Labor members citicise Labor Ministers. Sooner or later this Parliament and the parties in it will need to face up to the political realities that the wishes of the Territory cannot be blatantly ignored and that despite some faults, by and large the Assembly respresentatives reflect those wishes. The failure of Federal governments to appreciate this point has cost them credibility and ultimately votes in this city in the past, and it will most assuredly do so in the future.

Let me give you examples of how the respective Ministers for the Capital Territory have ignored the wishes of the elected representatives of the citizens of Canberra: The overruling by the Minister of the unanimously endorsed ordinance by the Assembly to protect small business people from exhorbitant rent payments, an ordinance passed by the Assembly in 1975, 1976 and 1979, and still not gazetted; the overruling by the Minister time and time again of Assembly proposals for business incentives comparable with those given in the States, an essential condition for a diversified employment base in this Territory; moves by the Minister as late as last week to reject serious efforts to inquire into the disadvantages of this city and provide adequate welfare funding; and the overruling by the Minister of Assembly advice to establish a casino to help the economy, provide revenue and promote tourism and of course the overruling by the Minister of the termination of pregnancy ordinance.

This list could be turned into a litany. There is no individual and no group in this city who has not suffered by ministerial fiat overruling the opinion of elected represenatives. At this point, despite the most recent disagreements with the House of Assembly on welfare, I must welcome the enthusiasn displayed and the communication with local politicians demonstrated by the new Minister for the Australian Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman). I congratulate him on his appointment, wish him well in his portfolio, assure him of my assistance and guarantee him my political surveillance.

One of my regrets is that most federal politicians who spend so much of their lives in Canberra travel like ships in the night, arriving at port but never disembarking to discover the town. They come so frequently yet see so little. One understands why. It is because of the pressures of political life. Yet, it is about time we put away the myths surrounding Canberra-that it is sterile and dead, elitist and spoilt. There are some distinctive features of the Territory which a proper analysis reveals. Yet the simple truth is that Canberra is populated by ordinary Australians who have the same aspirations as their counterparts in the states, who are concerned about their future and that of their country, who are worried about inflation and unemployment and want merely a 'fair go'-no more, no less-and who are angry when they find that they are being made ideological scapegoats. They live in a new city which has all the advantages of modernity and a host of the social disadvantages including family separation and physical isolation. We should not forget the dual nature of this city. It is both a place to live and a national capital. Too often politicians forget the former and resent the latter. If people in this city find that their city council and Federal government, both located in this Parliament, are treating them like statistics or a variation of Milton Friedman's economic model; they will react strongly.

This is a city of people and those people have shaped its identity. It has a strong and vigorous ethnic community, a youthful population which places stress on outdoor activity, a cosmopolitan approach to sport, particularly football, a school system quite different and more progressive than any in Australia, a high proportion of women in the work force a growing sense of community participation and involvement in running the Territory, and a high proportion of employees in the public sector. That means that in this Territory, the strength and viability of the private sector is more dependent on the public sector and government decisions than most other cities in the nation. This means the interdependence of the public and private sectors in this city is extra- ordinarily high.

In regard to the second role of Canberra, as a national capital, despite the criticism of Canberra and the public sector which this Government has fostered it is my firm belief that this city will be recognised as one of the nation's great achievements. It is our national capital, a forum in which we strive for excellence because others will judge our history and identity by what we do here. For this reason the Federal government of the day must continue the collective momentum of its predecessors. I note that after some fits and starts that is the course adopted by this Government and I trust it will continue. Yet, few regions have been so adversely affected by Fraser Government policies than this city. Unemployment is a striking example of this-it is currently 6,300 or 5.7 per cent of the labour force. Family living standards have plummeted. Social and family consequences of this are huge. Much of Canberra's population is based on the movement of young people to this city in the 1960's and 1970's. This generation came, leaving its families behind in capital cities and the countryside, and settled here. Now it finds that there are no jobs and no future for its own children, the next generation in this city. We face the spectre of having the children of the people who expanded this capital now being forced to leave their families in an ironical reverse process.

There is another critical aspect of Government economic policy in relation to Canberra. It is simply not good enough to say that, after we squeeze the public sector which is the life blood of this city, the private sector will automatically expand. This has not happened and it will not happen. There is no development strategy for this city held by this Government. The fact remains that some of the signs of renewed growth apparent in recent months stem not from the private sector but from government spending decisions, particularly in the construction of the new parliament house. There are a number of steps which need to be taken and, as I have explained, they can be taken only by the Federal Government if a proper program for economic development and, hence, social cohesion is to be framed for this Territory.

Let me explain the essence of such a program and what it should include. A long term plan for Canberra based on steady growth and co-operation between the public and private sectors is essential. This plan should include at least a 10-year construction program aimed at avoiding the stop-start-go effects of recent years. Unless there is such a plan, once the new parliament house is completed, Canberra will see an even greater depression than the one it has been through in the past five years. Tourism, which is now Canberra's second biggest industry after the Public Service, should be promoted. Stress should be placed on the attractions of the natural environment of the Australian Capital Territory and emphasis given to attracting tourists to lengthen their stay. Efficient and cheap transport is essential for the development of an inland city like Canberra. With the escalating cost of petrol there must be an upgrading of the rail services linking Canberra with Sydney and Melbourne.

To achieve a more diversified employment base for Canberra, the Federal Government must provide incentives to business to establish here. At present, most State governments offer such incentives and unless the Australian Capital Territory can provide assistance to private sector establishments, we will remain a Public Service town. These incentives may have to be provided for only a short period-say, 10 years-but they are necessary.

Let me talk specifically about the Public Service. During the past five years the Public Service has been used by the Fraser Government to score cheap political points. This Government is of the view that Public Service bashing is electorally advantageous, and its rhetoric has grown more shrill every year. The Liberal Party campaign notes for the last election, for example, suggested that there was political capital to be made in aligning the Public Service with the Australian Labor Party and denigrating both. The disparaging remarks of the honourable member for Flinders-The Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch)-that since 1975 there were 11,000 fewer bureaucrats with their snouts in the taxation trough is well known. It has been easy to launch the unnecessary attack and this has worked to the detriment of the Public Service and ultimately, the Government. This contrasts with the tone of the comments of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in his 1977 Garran oration when he said about the Public Service:

. . . in general there will be stability in the service. There will, of course, continue to be change and progress to meet the changing needs of modern government. It is important, however, that changes to the existing framework should only be brought about for good reason.

Yet I would argue that a study of this Government's approach to the Public Service reveals that it is a rhetorical stand only and that it has no concerted policy-contrary to the words of the Garran oration. If this Government took its own words seriously, it should have had a truly reformist attitude towards the Public Service. This has not happened. There has been no genuine concern with reform. The whole motivation of the Government has been to cut numbers to reduce costs. The Government's attitude towards the Public Service has contributed to declining morale. Many officials feel their professionalism is not recognised by the Government. I would simply point out that while political theory suggests that governments demand and expect loyalty from their servants, human practicalities suggest that such loyalty must be based on reciprocity.

So what is the Government's record? In June 1976 there were 160,298 public servants under the Public Service Act. Today there are 153,429, a reduction of 6,869 and at what cost? The cost was increased workloads, excessive demands on individuals and reduction of community services. The departments that have suffered the reduction are the service departments-like the Department of Health-not departments such as the Prime Minister's, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. Reductions have been most significant in the Fourth Division, often resulting in inefficiencies. More highly paid senior public servants are seen doing the filing and photocopying, while Canberra retains 5.7 per cent unemployment.

The Government has now at last realised that Public Service functions must be reduced if an effective reduction in Public Service numbers is to be attained. Only now, after five years, is it moving ahead with the desirable reform of voluntary early Public Service retirement. I fully support this move as do most public servants. But instead of being used to revitalise the Public Service and increase mobility within the Service and between the public and private sectors, early retirement is merely seen as a numbers saving device. This is a tragedy because it has the potential to transform morale and conditions inside the bureacracy. Unfortunately, it has been coupled with redeployment and retrenchment provisions.

The Government has shown a punitive, short-sighted attitude towards the Public Service time and time again. The Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act makes it possible for the Government to stand down, suspend or even dismiss-without notice, without time limit, without appeal and without any recourse to independent arbitration-any Commonwealth employee engaged in industrial action. The Public Service and Statutory Authorities Amendment Bill 1980 has further embittered the Government versus Public Service conflict as has the Prime Minister's politicisation of the Public Service Board. The worst aspect of these developments is the long term damaging and destructive effects on good government in Australia.

Another myth which needs to be exposed is the widespread belief that genuine savings in Government spending can be brought about through squeezing Public Service numbers. The facts speak for themselves. The Public Service wage bill last financial year was $2,996m, compared to total public sector outlays of $31,694m. So the cost of public servants themselves is merely 9.4 per cent of total spending. Even if in one year public service numbers were cut by 2 per cent or 3 per cent-a huge task-it would reduce total spending by only 0.2 per cent or 0.3 per cent which is infinitesimal. It may be politically popular to talk about cutting back government spending through reducing the number of public servants. The facts show that this is merely nibbling the edges of the problem as a substitute for cutting into the real funding cake.

This brings us to the Lynch razor gang. It was set up to review Federal Government functions and to decide what Federal Government functions could be abolished. This is the way the Government sees that it can reduce its size and its spending. Maybe one of the greatest savings in Public Service spending will be brought about if the razor gang cut its own throat, as I would hate to attempt to assess the amount of time spent by public servants in replying to their Minister's call to defend their own territory and in other Minister's calls to wipe it out. The Government has applied a numbers and finance squeeze on the Public Service while asking the Public Service to do more and not less. It has not streamlined, it has squeezed the Public Service. No Prime Minister in the history of this country has been so demanding of Public Service time, advice and dedication as this one. Yet no Prime Minister and no government has been so ruthless in applying legislative sanctions and threats. There is obviously room for more efficiency and more economy; everyone admits that. But the candle is being burnt at both ends. This does not mean that reform is not necessary in the Public Service. There is room for great reform and we might start with the 190 or more recommendations of the Coombs report.

There is no doctrine more damaging and divisive, than that which asserts that the public sector is unproductive and that public servants are parasites on the public purse. The truth is, of course, that the public sector has a vital, productive and constructive role to play, just as the private sector has. There is no economy and no society in which this has more truth than that of Australia. They are interdependent, and I shall maintain and seek to advance that truth as long as I am privileged to represent this great Australian electorate, not only because I am the member for Canberra, but because I believe it to be a cause and truth at the very heart of the best interests of the people of Australia.
Honourable members-hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMahon The Rt Hon Sir W.

TALK.START.PARA: -I must thank the honourable gentleman for the very pleasant and persuasive way she has presented her case.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If I said 'honourable gentleman' I take it back. I will have to start again. I must compliment the honourable member from Canberra (Mrs Kelly) for the very delightful way she has presented her case and for the very persuasive arguments she has put to us in the House today. But I must also make one complaint and that is that I believe she did not effectively recognise the fact that the Government has performed near miracles so far as unemployment is concerned. The number now employed is unexpectedly much greater than was envisaged six months ago. In the three months to November 1980 employment improved by 175,000 which was 2.9 per cent higher than the improvement for the corresponding period a year earlier. We have to look in particular at the question of youth employment to which the honourable member for Canberra referred. Some progress has been made in this area. We hope that as a result of what has been done now youth unemployment will improve substantially during the months to come. I should mention that the Government is providing opportunities for specialist training in order to permit young people to get jobs in the new energy society. This year 75,000 people will be assisted under the Special Youth Employment Training Program; 13,000 young people will be assisted through transition courses; 80,000 apprentices will be trained under the rebate scheme for apprentices; and an additional 50,000 will be helped through the Community Youth Support Scheme. I also point out that in a recent analysis by Dr Gregory and Mr Stricker some of the difficulties associated with finding jobs for young people were brought out. They pointed out that a typical three-month period in 1978, about 262,000 jobs became available for teenagers. I stress the word 'became'. It was found that teenagers changed their jobs so frequently that different methods of assistance had to be found. This is one of the main reasons that the real rate of teenage employment is so high.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I wish to point out that I believe the Government is doing much to improve youth employment in other sections as well. I want to concentrate on two aspects of the Governor-General's Speech of 2 November 1980. Firstly, it is emphasised that the basic thrust of the Government's fundamental economic policies will be maintained. They are designed to benefit all Australians and to develop an economy which maximises the rewards for individual effort and initiative and the right of individuals to determine their own lifestyles. I emphasise that to achieve these objectives, government policies must continue to restrain public expenditure so as to provide the funds for reducing the burden of taxation. Second in importance, is that we should ensure that the Government does all it can to contain wage increases in the short term in order to expand aggregate employment and income over the medium term. The Government is trying to do this within the constitutional powers it possesses. These objectives and policies must be considered against the background that when the Fraser Government assumed office late in 1975 the economy was in a frightening mess.

In 1974-75 inflation was running at the rate of 16.7 per cent. It is now 9.3 per cent. In the first half of the 1975 fiscal year it was 15.1 per cent. Gross domestic product was falling. In 1975 as a whole domestic product increased by only 0.5 per cent and non-farm product declined by 0.8 per cent. In December 1972 136,000 people were unemployed. At the end of December 1975 after the Labor Government had been removed from office 328,705 people were unemployed.

The details of the picture I want to paint must be seen and understood with these facts in mind. The international economic environment as a whole is unfavourable. In European countries and in the United States gross domestic product is falling dramatically and on average it is now one per cent. As well, Australia has gone through a three-year drought. The weekly wage rises for adult males are about 11 per cent and for females about 12.5 per cent. Technical experts expected this to have a significant effect on Australia. It has not done so. There is also an inbuilt inflationary cost pressure because of the rises in male and female wages and the very small increases in productivity. Male wages are rising at well over 10 per cent for the relevant part of the year and female wages are rising by 12 per cent.

I turn now to the fundamental indicators of changes of economic policy and the progress that is ensured to a large extent as a result of those changes. Final demand-that is consumer demand-and particularly consumption expenditure at current prices has risen from $16,000m in June 1979 to $18,700m in September 1980. Household disposable income, which is very important, has risen from $19,300m in September 1979 to $22,000m in September 1980. An illustration of this is the increase in production. When looking at the December production figures issued by the Bureau of Statistics Digest; one must at least be satisfied with what has been achieved. Yesterday we heard a report from the Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd that the steelwork's normal production levels had increased. Output from Port Kembla rose from 450,000 tonnes in June to 462,000 tonnes-4,000 tonnes above the previous record set in 1976. Bass Stait production was restored to the normal level of 6.7 million barrels a day. These are all remarkable performances and they illustrate in very clear and precise terms the extent to which government policies are being achieved. It puts to shame the guesses made by leaders of the Labor Party, including the shadow Treasurer when speaking in the Budget debate last year. I make no comment on that because I hope that one of my colleagues will refer to the matter. I feel I should concentrate on other matters.

The economy and, with it the prospects of the people, will inevitably improve unless trade unionists, led by economic illiterates and the radical trade union leaders, continue their destructive practices. These men are prepared to sacrifice the interests of their members in an attempt to achieve their delusions of grandeur and trade union muscle. They want to force employers and the Government to agree to union control over management and corporate industrial practice. Let us examine the dynamics of the developments that are now proceeding in Australia. Since 1977-78, and under the compulsion of facts, we have found for the third time that Australia is as well endowed as it has ever been. In fact, it is a leader in the world, particularly when taking into account the population of Australia. I refer to three great dynamic periods in Australia. Firstly, we had the dynamic period of wool production. Then we had the discovery of iron ore. Now we have energy resources and essential supplements available which will ensure big and permanent rises in production and exports.

As has been pointed out today due to devaluation and the cost advantage that we have derived internationally our manufacturing industries are heavily engaged in exports as well. Equally important is the fact that since 1973 when the Arabs and other petroleum producers decided to push up the price of crude oil, the importing countries had to absorb the inflationary impact of crude oil price roses and had to try to offset the associated balance of payments difficulties. Alternative sources had to be found. Australia had them. The demand for energy resources and the quick response of Australian industry created the foundation on which our current and growing prosperity is based. To prepare the way for further growth in these high productivity industries it is essential, in the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), that it will be an important policy objective to continue to restrain public expenditure so as to provide scope for personal tax reductions by reducing the burden of taxation. In 1981 we must reduce or eliminate government expenditure in those areas which belong to another age and concentrate efforts on industrial and mining areas which have the greatest productivity potential. As well, we need a sensible tariff policy. We also have to avoid duplication between Commonwealth and State authorities and to abolish those quasi-autonomous national government organisations which are no longer necessary, such as the Prices Justification Tribunal and the Industrial Relations Bureau. Government interference and attempts to restrain market factors must also be eliminated.

I have long favoured giving equal priority to inflation, national economic growth, employment and the reduction of personal income tax, including the substitution of increases in the wholesale tax and a service tax for personal tax reductions. I think we will better achieve the results we want to achieve by 'supply side' economics rather than by sticking with Keynesianism. These are the methods adopted by President Reagan in the United States of America. We have a good model. President Reagan is stimulating production, not demand, and reducing business and personal tax whilst relying on Budget cuts and tight money policy to rein in inflation. He has called for tax cuts totalling $A47 billion in 1982 and for a reduction in government expenditure of $A49 billion in that year. Keynesian doctrine which is based on generating demand by cutting taxes and raising public expenditure has been abandoned. As well, there has been a bonanza growth in tax revenue. According to the Australian Statistician's financial statement for the seven months of 1980-81, overall taxation will be up by 14.8 per cent on last year and net pay-as-you-earn tax receipts will be one per cent above the full year estimate of 13.8 per cent. Then, of course, there are increases in sales tax, company tax and excise duty. The crude oil levy will be $42m higher than it was estimated. I believe that it would be much higher but for strikes which cost about $300m. The levy has grown to $3,400m for the seven months of this financial year compared with $2,900m last year.

On the deficit side, tax receipts from farmers will be down, as will the collections from provisional tax. I believe that the matters I have mentioned form the basis for considering in great detail tax reductions on personal incomes when the next Budget is being framed. It is also argued that one of the reasons why personal tax cannot be reduced is that the tax yield from the oil levy will fall dramatically from 1985 onwards. I do not think a persuasive case has been made out for this. The missing link is that those preparing the Government's estimates forget the efforts being made to achieve extra extraction, the development of existing fields, the production from new fields, the building of new platforms and scientific development. It must not be forgotten that the free enterprise system will respond positively to incentives-the higher the better. The idea of introducing a resource rent tax does not fit in with such a concept.

Table 3 of the Parliamentary Library base paper No. 10 of 1980 estimates what the levy receipts on crude oil will be up to 1987. Before looking at those figures it should be known that the Budget estimate for this financial year is $3,157m. As I have said, it will be exceeded by $42m. I point out to honourable members that the figures contained in the Parliamentary Library table are considered by the corporations in the crude oil trade to be a very good basis on which to begin discussion. It is estimated that the levy receipts in 1985 will be about $2,520m. Later estimates made in the industry indicate that the figure certainly would be much higher-that it would be close to $2,820m or $2,920m-and that instead of tapering off very rapidly the amounts in 1986 and 1987 could well be a little higher than the 1985 figure. In other words, real difficulties should not arise until the end of 1987. Much can happen in the meantime. Results would be better if 'down time' losses were reduced.

I would now like to refer to the imposition of an indirect tax of a retail or wholesale kind. I do not think the inflation cost of that would be as serious as has been estimated. It has been estimated that a one per cent reduction in all marginal rates would cost the Treasury this year $600m. At 5 per cent it would be $3,000m and might be as high as $3,500m. It is said that the replacement of revenue lost due to an income tax reduction by the imposition of a wholesale tax would have the effect of increasing the consumer price index by 5 per cent or more. I have grave doubts for these reasons: The increase in the wholesale tax would have a one-off effect. That has to be remembered. Under present conditions a considerable percentage of indirect taxes would be spread over two or three years. Also, any increase in costs can be absorbed as productivity grows over those two or three years. Further, in the case of the wholesale tax, because it is the corporation that pays before actual sales take place in the retail stores there is every prospect that they would be able to absorb some of the increased costs.

I must also say that I was disappointed when the Government decided not to adjust the tax burden between direct and indirect taxes by reducing personal income tax and balancing the loss of revenue by extending the wholesale tax as well as introducing a services tax. It has been said that it is better to reduce taxes close to an election. I have my doubts about that because I believe that people vote according to the degree of their perception of the improvement in their own living standards. This can be achieved by one, two or three reductions over a three-year period. Continued improvement in the economy would also increase expectations of reduced taxes which over time would increase in a compound way. This would be of particular political importance. If we can do it when conditions are difficult, why can we not do it when they are as good as they are today?

I conclude: In an economic and financial sense the country has done a 'U' turn in a remarkably successful but drawn-out way as a result of our own efforts. To the thoughtful politician this means that now is the time to be thinking about the future. We must now set out medium and long term goals. Government and business resilience and adaptation to meet changing conditions are essential. We should also remove those obstructions and constraints which protect the obsolete established institutions, outdated conventions and excessive bureaucratic control. What we need is courage and determination. Australians will respond to policies based upon incentives of the kind mentioned in the Governor-General's Speech. Our motto should be: Give Australian taxpayers a better go with taxation.
Sitting suspended from 5.55 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: — Before calling the honourable member for Hindmarsh, I inform the House that the honourable member is about to make his maiden speech. I request that the traditional courtesy be extended to him. I call the honourable member for Hindmarsh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved to the Address-in-Reply motion. I am sure that all new members to this House have had an experience similar to mine. One is overawed and has a feeling of humility upon realising that one is a member of the Federal Parliament of Australia. Mr Deputy Speaker, I assure you and all honourable members that this realisation will have a far greater impact and lasting effect upon me as someone who has adopted Australia as my home. I am an Australian by choice and settled in Australia in 1958 having emigrated from Scotland. I love Australia and its people. My grandfather came to the port of Fremantle in a sailing ship in 1912. Unfortunately he spent only three years in Australia. My immediate family consists of two daughters, a son and two stepsons. I have two grandchildren and two more on the way. I have in my wife Michiko-who is here tonight-a friend, a companion and an unpaid social secretary. Michiko came from Japan some 25 years ago. I am the second eldest son of a family of eight. I am very fortunate in having most of my family and my cousins, uncles, and aunts here in Australia. My father was a coal miner who, at the age of 14, went down the pits. He vowed that none of his sons would go down the pits and that vow has been fulfilled.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, through you, I thank Mr Speaker for the course conducted here for the new members of Parliament. I give thanks for assistance received from various departmental heads and public servants, the Library staff and all those people who have helped the new members. I give thanks especially to Gordon Pike who is a person who needs to be mentioned and thought of more often.

My electorate of Hindmarsh was previously represented by the honourable Clyde Cameron. My task to follow in Clyde's footsteps is quite formidable. Clyde Cameron will long be remembered in this House. I have noted that Clyde was granted an extension of time when delivering his maiden speech some 31 years ago and, further, that Standing Orders were suspended on the occasion of his last speech. That is only part of the mark that Clyde has made. I believe Clyde was the greatest Minister in the Whitlam Government. He was fearless in fighting for those things in which he passionately believed.
