The Australian Trade Union Training Authority and the Clyde Cameron College stand as a testimony and tribute to his work.

In representing the electorate of Hindmarsh I have had the most rewarding experience of working with many wonderful people. I must mention some of those people for they are the workers in the community whose praises are seldom sung. I refer to people like Sam Johnson from Brompton whose whole life has been devoted to serving the community and John Dillon, another person who hides his light under a bushel. I mention Harry and Elsie Dennis. Harry was one of the original Rats of Tobruk. He is still out in the comunity fighting for that better life in which we all believe. I mention Jim Toohey-formerly Senator Toohey-and likewise ex-Senator Arnold Drury. Those people and many others too numerous to mention have participated in the work of the community. I am sure that they will continue in their struggle to make the electorate of Hindmarsh an even better place in which to live and to bring up children.

I wish to bring to the attention of this House a number of issues which have caused me and my constituents a great deal of concern. I have mentioned previously the Adelaide Airport and I have given notice that that will be an issue which I will continue to pursue. I wish now to pursue another matter which goes beyond the boundaries of Hindmarsh, the States and even Australia. I submit that this is a matter that affects all people in all lands. It is the very question of the survival of the species-the survival of the human race. It is the question whether we in Australia join, promote or encourage the nuclear industry and proliferate the nuclear arms race. I hope I will be given an opportunity at a later date to debate the wider implications of the nuclear cycle. In the time available to me tonight I wish to relate what is happening to the people living in my electorate of Hindmarsh.

The Thebarton suburb in the electorate of Hindmarsh has been inflicted with the plant of Australian Mineral Development Laboratories known as AMDEL. This organisation has been in operation since the early 1950s. Honourable members should bear in mind that this is mainly a residential area. Late in 1959, the Commonwealth Government, the South Australian Government and the mining industry became sponsors of the laboratories. Various changes were made to the sep-up of the laboratories and, in 1978, additional changes were made to allow the laboratories to develop as a market-oriented corporation. Included in the work carried out at the AMDEL plant at Thebarton is the testing of uranium core samples from South Australia, from other States and other countries.

Concern has been expressed for some time over the AMDEL uranium operation. On 31 March 1980, the Thebarton pilot plant and Frewville site-which is a sample preparation area-were inspected by Mr D. J. Hamilton, a scientific officer employed by the South Australian Health Commission. No radiation measurements were made at either site as the State Health Commission did not possess the appropriate instrumentation. The Hamilton report, as it is now known, was extremely critical of a number of procedures in operation at the AMDEL plant. The logging in of samples was not carried out as laid down by the regulations. Certain precautions are supposed to be adopted when uranium ore is handled. The Hamilton report stated that it has not been the practice to prepare written statements describing the precautions to be adopted or to distribute the statement to all the workmen involved although the preparation and distribution of such a statement is required by regulation 79 (b) and (c). On the question of the monitoring of personnel, the report stated that the entire staff had been supplied with film badges to monitor exposure to external gamma ray and X-ray radiation. The Australian Radiation Laboratory which supplies a particular film badge service said that the calibration of the film badges for uranium ore is very difficult and large inaccuracies-both over and under estimations-can occur.

An improved badge service called the TLD-thermoluminescent dosimetry-system has been brought into being. It should be borne in mind that this report was made in March 1980. At that time they did not have proper coverage for the workers. The Hamilton report goes on to say that film badges only indicate exposures to external gamma radiation but internal alpha emitters, that is, radon daughters and dusts, are a more important hazard when uranium ores are being handled. I point out that the South Australian Government endeavoured to cover up and bury this report. Fortunately, there were public servants who had enough conscience to make sure that the report got out. On the question of environmental monitoring, the report states that a gamma radiation monitor and a radon measuring system were the only monitoring instruments it was planned to have available at Thebarton; that uranium ore can be expected to contain all the radioactive daughters of uranium and that therefore radiation exposures to all three types of radiation-alpha, beta and gamma-from a number of radionuclides via several different exposure pathways can be expected when uranium ore is being handled. The report also points out the failure to mark drums containing radioactive material with the radiation hazard symbol, as is required under the regulations. In conclusion, the Hamilton report states:

The handling of uranium ores is a potentially hazardous operation. Provided that strict precautions are adopted and rigidly adhered to at all times, the risks involved can be kept extremely small. However, this result can only be achieved if the organisation involved displays a strong positive attitude towards minimising the risks associated with the activity. Such an attitude was not in evidence at the time of the inspection.

Monitoring is required to demonstrate conclusively that all the potential risks (both occupational and environmental) are known and are very small. AMDEL's responsibilities in the environment area are particularly important as both its sites are located in residential areas.

I again point out that the Hamilton report was made following inspections in March last year. The State Health Minister has played down the report. Indeed, it was very difficult to get acknowledgement that the report existed.

I wish now to deal with a subsequent report made by the health surveyor to the Thebarton Council, again dealing with the problems of the Australian Mineral Development Laboratories. The Council has been deeply concerned for some time about the operations and the health risks emanating from the AMDEL plant. Less than 10 metres from this plant are homes, and the fence that joins the residents' homes is a common fence with AMDEL. One can almost put a hand through and touch the drums that contain the core samples and tailings. The Council, after approaching the company, AMDEL, in an effort to deal with the problems being raised by residents, including concern over possible radiation hazards, considered a report from its health surveyor. Some very important aspects of that report should be made known.

The Thebarton Council was called on to consider its possible fate should it not declare Thebarton a nuclear free zone. Sample readings were taken of ore in drums and in sampling trays of yellowcake in plastic drums and in a glass jar, and of other radioactive materials, including pitchblende. These were the inspections that the surveyor undertook. Whilst the readings were within prescribed international levels, the laboratory's assistant radiation safety officer only agreed to go before the Council to answer questions provided that he was advised in writing of those questions and provided that the questions would not entail making statements on Government policy. Where is the protection for the people? Where has the community's interest been looked after? It was pointed out by the Thebarton Council that many councils in Adelaide and Melbourne, and also in Western Australia, I believe, have declared nuclear free zones in their areas and have forbidden the storage of nuclear materials. Concern was expressed that should other councils with similar circumstances to Thebarton successfully police their nuclear free zones, then it was possible that AMDEL at Thebarton could become a dumping ground for radioactive materials. To protect against this possibility, Thebarton Council suggested to its residents that they should consider the area becoming nuclear free.

A number of points were raised by the health inspector, and they are extremely important because they show the beginning of the whole nuclear cycle which I hope to have time to touch on tonight. On the subject of the crushing of the ore samples, the health inspector's report stated that whilst AMDEL provides a suction system at the face of each crusher, some of the radon gas may escape to the atmosphere and be carried from the vicinity of the plant. On the subject of tailings spillage he said that during the processing radioactive material may be spilt onto the floor and eventually washed into the plughole. In relation to equipment decontamination, the question arises as to how the equipment used in the process is decontaminated and how the associated decontamination wastes are collected and stored. While I am on the subject, I should point out that of the 12 boilermakers and welders who worked in the Radium Hill mine seven have died from cancer. One died in 1960 at the age of 35 and the seventh person died last year at the age of 65.

Dealing with tailings storage, and this is one of the key issues at that site, whilst AMDEL is handling only approximately 20 tonnes maximum ore at any one time, research indicates that some 3,700 litres of liquid waste per tonne are generated in the process, all of it chemically toxic and radioactive. This means that in producing 20 kilograms of yellowcake from 20 tonnes of ore, 74,000 litres of tailings are produced. If stored in 205-litre containers, the tailings produced would amount to approximately 360 drums. As these tailings are also acid or alkaline by nature some etching of the containers with resultant leakages could cause the release of radon gas if the tailings are stored for some time.

This somewhat detailed outline of the AMDEL operation has been necessary in order to show just how callous and uncaring the mining industry and governments that support it can be. It has to be remembered that we are talking about a mineral laboratory processing uranium and other radioactive materials right in a residential area. There are residents-my constitutents-on three sides of this chemical, mineral laboratory. I make it clear that so long as I represent the seat of Hindmarsh my primary responsibility will be to the people and not to the mining interests, the multinationals, or any other exploiters of the people of the Federal seat of Hindmarsh.

In Thebarton we have an establishment in a residential area pumping out radon gas and radioactive dust, and pumping radioactive tailings into the ground, contaminating the land, the water and the people. I have spent some time in the Thebarton AMDEL location going from door to door to speak with my constituents. I have been informed by people in the immediate vicinity about two deaths from cancer or leukaemia, and in the past few months the death of a child, three cases of possible skin cancer, two serious cases of chest and breathing complaints, nine complaints of constant eye irriations, and numerous complaints of sore throats. This is an area containing approximately 36 homes.

My constituents have called by petition for a medical team to go into the area to do a survey and conduct examinations in order to assess the magnitude of the problem. So far, the State Health Minister, Mrs Adamson, has ignored these calls. She also declined an invitation from an invalid pensioner, who lives about 30 metres from the plant, to live with her for a week, with free board, just to find out what it is like. Mrs Adamson said that she was too busy. The struggle of the people of Thebarton to have the chemical factory closed and the area cleaned up is a struggle that may take some time. I have made a pledge to the people to struggle with them until the filthy, radioactive, foul-smelling chemical and mineral laboratory is out of the district.

Mr Deputy Speaker, because of lack of time I want to touch just briefly on one other issue which goes beyond that of Thebarton, which is only the tip of the iceberg. If honourable members recall, in the debate in Australia on uranium there was talk about our having to mine and export uranium to gain export earnings. We were told about the various jobs that would be created. That is stage one. As this Government would have it, stage two is the uranium enrichment process. We are under way with the enrichment process. I draw the attention of all honourable members to a publication called Compendium of Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Projects. Page after page relates to the non-breeder nuclear program in which this Government is involved. I have to finish now, Mr Deputy Speaker. I thank you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention to the lack of courtesy displayed by Government members. Opposition members attended in the chamber when new Government members made their maiden speeches. Obviously, Government members are boycotting the maiden speeches of Opposition members.

—Order! There is no point of order. I draw the attention of the House to the fact that the honourable member for Lyne is about to make his maiden speech. I ask that the traditional courtesies of the House be extended to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. I appreciate the fact that delivering a maiden speech in any parliament is a most important event in the life of a member of parliament. I join with other honourable members who have congratulated those new members who have made their maiden speeches to this House. We appreciate that this is our initiation into the parliamentary field. Undoubtedly, all of us have a deep appreciation of our responsibilities in the future. First of all, I express my appreciation to the people of the Lyne electorate who elected me to represent them for the forthcoming parliamentary term. I also say thank you to my campaign director and to all those people, numbering over 500, who provided assistance throughout the electorate on election day. I say to them that I greatly appreciate the responsibility they have placed on me.

SPEECH.PARA: I especially wish to say something about my predecessor, Mr Philip Lucock, who represented the electorate of Lyne for 28 years. Ever since I arrived here, all the servants of the Parliament, from the most junior to the most senior, have spoken most favourably of Mr Lucock. I am very pleased to hear that. He sends his regards to all of them. Mr Lucock served the electors of Lyne most conscientiously over the years. He certainly did a tremendous amount for the development of that electorate. Moreover, he did a tremendous amount for Australia and the Parliament. He represented us at the United Nations and elsewhere, as well as being Deputy Speaker of the Parliament for over 12 years.

I think some honourable members are aware that I served as a member of the New South Wales Parliament for a 14 1/2-year term. Prior to that I served an 8-year term in local government. I sometimes wonder whether it is an advantage to serve within a parliament or council before reaching the Federal parliamentary field. I suppose I have never had any great ambition to serve in the Federal House, but one appreciates the responsibility he has been given. I certainly think that the experience one can gain within the local government field and within a State parliament leads one to know one's responsibilities and to have a better understanding of our parliamentary system.

I am a great believer in our parliamentary system and in our three tier system of government within Australia. I emphasise right here and now how important it is that the three tiers of government within Australia accept their true responsibilities. I have been alarmed, as I know many members of this House have been alarmed, over the years when I have seen one of the tiers of government moving into the field of responsibility of another tier of government. I am a great believer in the work performed by and the responsibility held by the States. I see the national Parliament as the body responsible for controlling the national scheme. Whenever we can pass down responsibility it is our duty to do so in order to ensure not only that the taxpayers' dollar is properly spent but also that we gain the maximum development and progress to which we believe we are entitled in this young country of ours.

I belong to the National Country Party, a party which was formed more than 60 years ago to represent the rural areas of Australia. I suppose the reason the party was formed at that time by the old Farmers and Settlers Association still exists. There is still that great need, it may be greater today, for us to be represented within the parliaments of the Commonwealth and the States in coalition with the Liberal Party of Australia in order to emphasise the importance of primary industry and the problems we face in the country areas of the State. I am pleased to be a member of the National Country Party. I am pleased to say that we have, particularly in the Federal coalition and in the New South Wales parliamentary National Country Party, of which I was a member, a very happy and very close association with anti-socialist policies which are so important to us.

I appreciate that over the years since the formation of our party our responsibilities as a party have greatly changed. They have changed, to some degree, from policies with an emphasis on primary industry to policies which embrace the tourist industry, country industry, aspects of the life of people who retire in country towns and our responsibility to the aged. Through our policies we have contributed to increasing the population and improving the status of rural areas of Australia. We must keep fully abreast of our responsibilities in that direction as a party. I want to say something about agriculture. When I speak about my party, I am led to say this: Over the years it has emerged that we have an ever increasing responsibility to ensure that the economy of agriculture is sound, to ensure that the people involved in the various avenues of agriculture-the dairy farmer, the fruit man, the grazier, the grain man and others-given their investments and in the interests of the happiness of their families, are allowed to take a real place in the future economy of this nation.

I emphasise a fact which I believe underlies the whole field of agriculture: Australia, although it is a large and dry continent, has a true responsibility to help to feed the people of the countries which need the products we produce. We should never overlook that fact. We must condition our future thinking on agriculture to include that fact. We want to compete on world markets. I commend the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) and the Government for carefully looking at the effect on our markets of the European Economic Community. How worrying it is to see that the EEC member countries are heavily subsidising their farmers and increasing production. When they do not require the produce of those farms, they will dump it on markets around the world in competition with our products. It is most important that we appreciate that fact. I believe the Government is very aware of that and has adopted measures which will play an important part in what happens in the future.

I will never apologise in this House or elsewhere for the support I give to primary producer support schemes. We must never forget the principle of providing support schemes for primary producers because they are subject to the elements. They are subject to climatic and market conditions. It is most important that, in order to maintain their prosperity, we never forget that it is the duty of governments to ensure that primary producers receive the finance and the moral support they require when the going is bad. I am one who believes in orderly marketing. I believe that whenever the opportunity presents itself, either the Commonwealth or the States should set up the necessary statutory authorities to permit orderly marketing of a product. I believe it is most important that when a marketing authority, or whatever it is called, is set up its representation is basically producer oriented. It is the Government's policy and wish that it should provide the legislation to enable the authority itself to care for its maintenance and running of the industry.

I draw the attention of the House to a matter that has concerned me for many years, that is farm ownership. Today we have many younger people within the farming community. I know it has been stated by the producer organisations that the average age of a farmer is 55 to 57 years. When we consider the attractions of industry and commerce within this country and the high investment involved in getting on to the farm, including the purchase of real estate, stock and plant, we realise that we have a responsibility to come up with a scheme of land settlement. In this way a young man who was not necessarily a farmer's son but who qualified would have the opportunity of owning his own property. I do not believe that this is a true Commonwealth responsibility. I lay the responsibility fairly and squarely at the feet of the States. Some of the States have already made a move towards such a scheme. But as we are supposed to be holding the purse strings we should give any assistance we can to encourage a State to set up a land bank scheme such as the Canadian scheme. I believe this is a very worthy scheme. We have a great respect for the family farm. In the long term it is the family farm-Mum, Dad and the kids-which will make the farming industry survive. It is important that we recognise the high investment that farmers make. I commend the numerous farming bodies throughout Australia that are representative of the farming industries. We appreciate the work they have done for agriculture and their industries over the years gone by. I assure them of support in the future.

In lowering the cost of production there is nothing more important than water conservation. In recent days and only this evening we have heard discussions about the pollution of the River Murray. Let us realise that six-sevenths of the water of New South Wales flows in to the River Murray system. The River Murray is partially a worn out stream. It is now receiving attention from the Commonwealth and the States with the general desalination of some of the areas concerned. Perhaps water has been wasted in the past. However, I will not enter that field although I will enter the general discussion about future conservation works throughout Australia. As a primary producing country we must ensure that adequate funds are made available for overall programs to assist the States to develop their water conservation schemes. I come from a coastal electorate. This is the first occasion within the last year that any authority has wanted to tap the watershed of the Manning River catchment area. The water that will be diverted from the Barnard River into the Newcastle area and the Hunter Valley will basically be used for industry. We have no riparian rights. We do not expect to have them but we want to ensure the future growth of agriculture which will be necessary to meet the domestic requirements in this area of Australia with its increasing population. There must be an overall program that will ensure that the people who are living there and the agricultural industries in the area are well cared for.

I now refer to the natural resources of Australia. I suppose that this is a subject on the lips of each individual. It is a matter that concerns us. The honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) warned us of the dangers of development to health. I do not know whether he wants to do away with unemployment. If we carried out his policy nobody would have a job. It is entertaining to hear some Opposition members talk. People are wondering what is the future of natural resources in Australia and what are our responsibilities to provide countries with the energy and other resources that are so important to them. I believe we have a great responsibility. We must bear in mind the environmental and other factors which may curtail some future development. I am pleased that at least 50 per cent of investment in natural resources development will be held, we hope, by Australians. This is not an easy thing to forecast. The economy of this nation must be very sound. Australians themselves have to be in a position to be able to invest their money in the encouragement of these industries if they are to be Australian-owned. It is important that inflation comes down and that we pursue the policies of the Government at present in order that the country's economy can be sound and the average Australian person has an opportunity to invest in the industry in his country that he is so keen to expand. The honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Tambling) is sitting beside me. What a responsibility we have as a nation to develop the north of Australia. Almost half the population of this country lives in Melbourne and Sydney. Surely we can do something-we have to-to encourage people to go where the work is in the north of Australia, not only to develop the natural resources but also to assist in the actual defence and long term progress of Australia.

I now refer to our road system. Coming from a rural electorate I believe that there is nothing more important to us today than to ensure that we have proper and adequate lines of communication. I was pleased to hear the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) announce a $3,650m five-year program for roads within Australia. I issue one warning in this respect. In most of our country electorates classified roads are main roads or trunk roads. I believe that in the future these will be known as arterial roads. These are the roads that carry the bulk of the production from the farm to the market place or the factory. I believe that these roads are being starved of the funds they require in order to build up a proper network throughout the rural areas of Australia. I hope that under the new arrangements, which still have to be responded to by the States, the States will contribute adequate funds, along with the Commonwealth, to allow the proper development of these roads. Although local roads are tremendously important I am not talking about those roads. I am talking about the roads for which the average shire council in New South Wales would not receive any more than $300,000 a year for development and maintenance.

I also welcome the decision of the Minister and the Government that in future greater consideration will be given to the letting of our roadworks and bridgeworks by the contract system. I have seen a construction developing in my home town. In two months a firm has built a very large building which is nearly completed. The firm will be a going concern within three or four months of turning the first sod. I believe there is a lot of waste, not only in the local government field but also in the State field and, perhaps, in the enterprises conducted by this Government. We have to place a greater emphasis on contract work generally. I see that the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) is in the House this evening. I am pleased to see that once postal services move out of Redfern in New South Wales and 11 processing centres are established, many of the deliveries of that mail will be undertaken by the contract system. I believe that in many other areas where Government employees are used at present the work could be done by contract. We would get a better return for the dollar and would certainly make greater progress.

I regret that my time has almost expired. I wanted to say something concerning some important features, for the average Australian, of His Excellency's address, features which touched on the responsibility that the Government has, and is discharging, so far as the elderly, the disabled and the handicapped are concerned. This, of course, we recognise and in my own electorate progress in this respect has been most favourable. My electors, individually, are concerned most about the attitude of many of our left wing unions and workers. Why should their strikes, which interrupt airline and other important services, be allowed to hold people to ransom? The harmful effect of such action upon industry, commerce and farming is paramount in the mind of country dwellers. The very people who create this atmosphere are the union officials, who in fact hurt their own members as a result. No one can tell me that there is not behind it some major ulterior motive designed to reduce the standard of living of this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Before I call the honourable member for Ballarat, I remind the House that the honourable member is about to deliver his maiden speech. I ask that he be accorded the traditional courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, firstly, though I recognise somewhat belatedly, I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate you on your re-ection to your esteemed office of responsibility in this House.

SPEECH.PARA: I feel both proud and honoured to have been chosen by the voters of the electorate of Ballarat to represent them in this Parliament and I am very mindful of the responsibilities this entails. I thank them for their support, their confidence and their encouragement. I also wish to place on record my gratitude to those dedicated members and supporters of the Australian Labor Party, and to my wife and my children, who worked tirelessly with me and sacrificed so much during the recent election campaign. It is for me a great privilege to carry the political hopes and aspirations of 70,000 voters to the benches of this Parliament.

Also, in reflecting upon the history of the electorate of Ballarat, which incidentally was one of the foundation electorates of this Parliament, it is a humbling experience to contemplate the distinguished contribution of some of my predescessors. Of these, the name of Alfred Deakin, the first Federal member for Ballarat, comes to mind as one of this Parliament's greatest liberal reformers. Much that his government achieved in those early days, with the support of the Australian Labor Party, has stood the test of time. I also wish to pay particular tribute to Mr Reginald Pollard, who served the people of Ballarat, the Labor Party, this House and Australia with great distinction from 1937 to 1949. I am sure that Reg is delighted that Ballarat, which was in his time traditionally a Labor seat, has returned to the Labor fold after languishing for 25 years in the political wilderness.

I wish to refer also to two other famous sons of the Ballarat district who, although not parliamentary representatives of that district, became Labor Prime Ministers during times of great difficulty for our great nation. I speak, of course, of John Curtin from Creswick and James Scullin from Trawalla, who spent his early working days in the great city of Ballarat. It should also be remembered that it was on the gold diggings of Ballarat that the embryonic democratic aspirations of the miners led them to take up arms against a despotic colonial government. The outcome of that diggers' revolt at the Eureka Stockade was the first step in the gradual process of the democratisation of the institutions of government in the colonies which culminated in the constitutional conventions of the 1890s and Australian Federation.

Many of the cities and towns of my electorate owe their existence to the gold era. The opulent grandeur of so many of the beautiful mid-Victorian public and commercial buildings and private dwellings is a lasting reminder of the great wealth that was created during that mineral boom of more than a century ago. It is still possible to see some of the most beautiful Victorian streetscapes in Australia in those cities and towns. Yet, whilst gold was the basis upon which centres such as Avoca, Maryborough, Daylesford and Ballarat were established, the subsequent development of major rural and secondary industries provided jobs for their citizens on a continuing basis. Indeed, it can be said that the development of manufacturing industry in Ballarat was very much interconnected with the deep lead mining activity which followed the completion of the taking of alluvial gold. The need for sophisticated heavy machinery for mining, together with the rapidly expanding infrastructure development in the district, accelerated the expansion of a broad industrial base. It was this industrial expansion which led to future economic prosperity when unfortunately the remaining gold became too costly to recover.

However, in more recent times the impact of various economic forces, in particular the restructuring of industry in this country, has been keenly felt in the electorate of Ballarat. Five years of the economic policies of the Fraser Government have failed to curb the decline in much of this country's industrial activity. Nowhere are the effects of this decline felt more seriously than in established provincial and rural Australia. My electorate is no exception. The continued survival of many of the labour-intensive engineering and textile firms of Maryborough, Kyneton and Ballarat, which have served this country so well over the years, is constantly under threat because of this Government's failure to understand their special requirements.

I must remind the House that such industries are major sources of employment in my electorate. If dramatic proof of the impact of five years of Fraserism is required we need look no further than the most recent Commonwealth Employment Service figures for the Ballarat district. On 31 January 1981, 3,837 persons were registered as unemployed. That does not include all of the actual unemployed. The official figure represented 9.5 per cent of the total work force in the region. In the Maryborough district alone at that time 651 persons were unemployed.

Statistics do not tell the story of the social carnage of unemployment. Let us consider the pressures that high levels of unemployment have created in these provincial centres. Let us ponder for a moment the overwhelming sense of bewilderment and despair that is felt by so many of our young folk and family breadwinners. What cause for hope is there for those folk who are in the middle years and find themselves without a job and little prospect of getting one? It is nothing short of an obscenity that the Government should be even floating the notion of withdrawing the unemployment benefit from 16 and 17-year-olds when, through no fault of their own, so many of them cannot find jobs. Recently, when a job became available in Ballarat, more than 400 people applied for it. In a city where youth unemployment exceeds 20 per cent, the appallingly callous suggestion of removing unemployment benefits deserves the most trenchant condemnation. Today I received news that will bring no comfort to those who work so hard for the unemployed youth in Ballarat. I refer to a letter from the Minister for Employment-
Opposition members-Unemployment!

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what I would have thought. The letter from the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr Viner) indicates the truth behind the facade that obscures the real policies of this Government. The 1981 allocation to the Community Youth Support Scheme based in Ballarat has been reduced to the extent that one project officer will be dismissed. In 1980, the Victorian committee recommended a reduction in the number of project officers from seven to six. The Minister rejected this recommendation and maintained adequate funding to enable the project to continue its important work without interruption. That was very good. The work load in 1981 not only is similar in nature to that of 1980 but also has increased in volume. The ingredients in the story are the same, except one. I suggest the insincerity of this Government's concern for the welfare of the young unemployed can be well measured by a comparison between its decision in the election year 1980 and those taken in 1981.

SPEECH.PARA: What comfort was there for the unemployed in the Governor-General's Speech? There was very little indeed. Whilst Opposition members welcome any sign that the overall employment situation is improving, one can see that there is still a long way to go before we in the Ballarat electorate can become complacent. There are those who for motives they prefer not to disclose believe that these problems in the community will disappear if they ignore them or remain silent about them. However, I am a representative of a political party whose philosophy gives priority to the care of and concern for the less fortunately placed in our society. Therefore, it would be grossly negligent of me if I failed to draw the attention of this House to the existence of real difficulties in my electorate.

Along with the problems of the unemployed, there are also serious problems with regard to the availability of welfare housing. I know that this situation is not unique to the Ballarat area but, for those who are required to wait two years or more for a home, the problem is oppressive. They are often forced by their circumstances to live in substandard conditions. The Federal Government must accept its share of the blame. In real terms, this Government's spending on welfare housing for the current financial year is one-third of the amount allocated six years ago. In real net money terms, the payment to the States for housing has fallen from $515m in the financial year 1974-75 to $76m in 1980-81. Victoria now receives only one-third of the amount it was allocated six years ago. This provides no comfort for those in my electorate who are waiting for a Housing Commission home. That is why it constitutes one of the major problems that come to my office.

Honourable members have heard much from this Government about the economic bonanza that will flow from resource development. Today, electorates such as Ballarat are looking forward to the signs that the promised benefits of the much vaunted resource boom of the 1980s will be shared by all Australians rather than simply accrue to a few giant corporations, many of which owe no allegiance to this country. Of course, this presupposes that the resource boom will go ahead in the way in which the Government has indicated. If a further exacerbation of the difficulties faced by non-metropolitan secondary industries is to be avoided, it is encumbent upon this Government to provide a co-ordinated, balanced approach to resource development. However, on present indications this just does not seem likely. The track record of the Fraser Government has been one of continued neglect of the special needs of the great provincial cities and towns of this country. Expenditure on decentralisation assistance alone has been cut by 70 per cent in real terms since the financial year 1974-75. The current year's allocation is down 16 per cent even on 1979-80 figures. Furthermore, expenditure on urban and regional development has fallen from $205m in the financial year 1974-75 to only $65m this year. Unfortunately, the Governor-General's Speech did not contain any suggestion that there would be a change of direction by the Government, and so the tragic neglect will continue.

Despite this Government's intransigence, at least I can take heart at the efforts of so many individuals and organisations within my electorate to find solutions to the problems that we face. I am proud to be associated with the Ballarat Regional Employment Committee and its important subsidiary, the Ballarat Expansion Today-Tomorrow Committee. These two groups are dedicated to the task of finding new industrial opportunities for Ballarat, particularly in relation to resource development needs elsewhere. Such opportunities are vital for the continued viability of local industry and commerce, for the future expansion of employment and for the maintenance of the excellent lifestyle traditionally enjoyed by the people of my electorate. I am proud also to be associated with a group of Ballarat engineering firms which have formed themselves into a consortium known as the Ballarat Industrial Consortium. Its aim is to tender jointly for government and other local and overseas engineering contracts, sharing the work amongst the members according to the availability of production facilities and the size of the job. The consortium might well become a model of industrial co-operation to be emulated by cities in other parts of the country. There are also the railway unions in Ballarat that have fought valiantly to ensure the continued survival of the local railways workshop. Over the years, the workshop has provided jobs for thousands of Ballarat workers and has trained many skilled tradesmen.

Many people in my electorate recognise in a responsible fashion the effects of the social problems being faced, not only in Ballarat but elsewhere in Australia, such as high unemployment, inadequate welfare housing and of course the industrial malaise. My presence in this House is testimony to their concern. The voters of Ballarat expressed through the ballot box their belief in the relevance of the humane policies proposed by the Australian Labor Party during the recent election campaign. They expressed also their dissatisfaction with the status quo.

As I said at the outset, I am proud to be the representative in this place of the people of the Ballarat electorate, who have always displayed great independence and determination in facing up to periods of economic and social difficulty. In fact, if the people of my electorate had not taken initiatives and seized upon opportunities in the past, the problems of today would have been much greater. For example, the natural and historical resources of the region have provided a base upon which a flourishing tourist industry has been developed. I am sure that most honourable members are aware of that, and I hope most of them have either visited, or will take advantage of a visit to, our fair city. However, further potential waits to be exploited, such as the mineral springs of Daylesford and Kyneton which, if carefully managed, could turn that area into a world class health resort. There is also a burgeoning vine growing industry around the towns of Avoca and Moonambel. The wines being produced in that area could well challenge the supremacy of the wines of the Hunter and Barossa valleys in a few short years.

I suggest that those honourable members trying to interject should come over and try them. The many initiatives that have been taken by the citizens of Ballarat are dramatic evidence of their willingness to help themselves in spite of the intransigence and the dogmatism of this Government. I suggest that those initiatives are deserving of the most sympathetic consideration by the Government and I hope that it will respond accordingly. It was only recently that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said that the benefits of the great development projects, which he envisages will be set in train over the next decade, should flow to all Australians. I call on the Prime Minister to spell out the means by which he intends his aspirations to be fulfilled for the benefit of all Australia. The concerned, responsible citizens across the length and breadth of my electorate, who are prepared to sacrifice much to help themselves, eagerly await the Prime Minister's response. However, I fear that the present economic policies being so doggedly pursued by this Government, at variance with the real needs of the electorate of Ballarat and of Australia, unfortunately will be continued to be pursued.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tuckey) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALKER.NAME: Mr VINER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs)
