TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for O'Connor, I remind the House that this will be the honourable member's maiden speech. Honourable members are requested to extend to him the tradition courtesies. I call the honourable member for O'Connor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The subject of industrial relations has attracted a number of speeches and comments during this Address-in-Reply debate. After 25 years of diverse activity as an employer in the industries of earth moving and trucking, pastoral farming, hotels and holidays, I feel I am unique among some of those speakers, having had to live by the system rather than from it. As an opening comment, I philosophise for a moment. Today we are very much into renewable resources such as the sun, wind and tide. Many people believe that they will be the salvation of the universe, but they overlook nature's tendency to balance. Nature has supplied these resources to maintain life on earth. There is insufficient to cater for extravagance. The renewable resource which can provide greatly extended benefits is that of personal endeavour. The people of Japan, through personal endeavour, overcome severe shortages of most natural and renewable resources. Historically the Romans had it and lost it. More recently the British decided that they did not need it and currently the Americans, after a short experience of doing without it, are planning to bring it back into fashion. Personal endeavour is unique amongst renewable resources and when coupled with democracy it returns the benefits to the provider. Industrial relations is to me the business of developing this prized renewable resource.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a brief look at the reality of industrial life in Australia. Historically, life was not too good for the worker. Many of our original immigrants arrived in Australia as a result of English legislation passed in 1799, which outlawed workers acting in combination to seek wage increases or to go on strike. Possibly due to the resulting six months chained in the bowels of a sailing ship, few of these immigrants resumed their interest in labour relations on arrival in Australia. They apparently became more addicted to then popular pastimes of wenching and drinking. A prominant figure in labour relations has suggested that if present day emigrants from that same country turned their minds to this pursuit instead of that of shop steward, many man hours and millions of dollars in wages might be saved. The 1890s saw relatively the most bloody era in Australian industrial history. Both the fledgeling unions and the employers emerged bearing deep and unhealed wounds. It was not surprising, therefore, that with the support from both unions and employers, this Parliament saw as one of its original and most urgent tasks, the preparation of legislation to resolve industrial disputes. In 1904 it passed the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.

I think it worth repeating the reasoning behind this legislation. It was passed at that time with good will from both sides of the House, as a substitute for the strike weapon. It did not and does not include any reference to the present eleventh commandment-the right to strike. The intention was that it be the sunset legislation for industrial militancy. We might ask why legislation originally so well conceived by wise men of genuine grass roots experience has failed us. The answers are easy to find. As has just occurred in Poland, many early industrial leaders were workers who stepped from the ranks to lead when the need arose. Many of these men were selfless individuals quite happy to retire into obscurity when they believed industrial justice was achieved.

The union movement has since become a carreer service. Careers must have the opportunity for advancement and for advancement one must be in a growth industry. The union industry is singularly lacking in obvious consumer demand, so growth must therefore be generated by convincing the consumer that he needs you. The recipe is simple: Maintain dissatisfaction. When the membership starts to realise that all those pay increases for which they struck have resulted in higher taxes and no more purchasing power then the union says that the direction must be changed and the members must be involved in the uranium debate or demarcation disputes. When the union finds they are not really interested in that, then it tells them they are overworked and need more leisure time. There is a new honourable member on the other side of this House who believes that quotations from foreign sources give weight to any argument. Let us therefore read what Paul Johnson, a noted British left wing academic, said in his article 'Trade Unionism is Killing Socialism-The English Experience'. He said:

Above all, the economic organisation of society, the way in which wealth is invested, and rewards distributed, to all of us who are its members, should have become the function of democratic governments.

But this is not what has happened. The unions have refused to recognise the limits of their historical role. They have not only rejected the idea of a progressive abdication, and the shift of their social and economic function to the political process, but they have flatly declined to allow the smallest diminution of their power to press the sectional interests they represent.

Indeed they have steadily, ruthlessly and indiscriminately sought to increase that power. In recent years, and in particular in the last five years, they have exhausted or beaten down any opposition and have finally succeeded in making themselves the arbiters of the British economy. This has not come about as part of some deeply laid and carefully considered plan. It is not part of a plan at all.

It has been, essentially, a series of accidents. Huge unions each pursuing wage claims at any cost, having successfully smashed other elements in the State-governments, political parties, private industry, nationalised boards-now find themselves amid the wreckage of a deserted battlefield. The undoubted victors.
They did not plan the victory-they do not know what to do with it now they have got it. Dazed and bewildered they are like medieval peasants who have burnt down the lord's manor.
He stated further:

What next? They have no idea as they did not think ahead to this sort of situation, and indeed are not equipped by function or experience to embark on positive and constructive thinking. That is not their job! Here we come to the heart of the matter. The trade union is a product of 19th century capitalism. It is part of that system. Against powerful, highly-organised and ruthless capitalist forces, it had an essential even noble part to play. But when those forces are disarmed, when they are in headlong retreat-indeed howling for mercy-the union has no function to perform.

I come back to leisure as expressed at present by the 35-hour week campaign. How the work force can enjoy an additional day's leisure per fortnight on the same wages is beyond me. They needed a 17.5 per cent loading to finance an extra week's annual leave. So what is so good about leisure and what is so bad about work? The opposition demands the fulfilment of work for the unemployed. The unions demand more leisure for the employed. The average Australian worker, after allocating long service leave on an annual basis gets, 152 days of leisure a year, much more than workers in any other country. Nevertheless he pays a high price for it.

The union movement which demands all this leisure on his behalf, has established, to its satisfaction at least, that leisure can be enjoyed only on weekends or at night time, other than, of course, if one is enjoying a public holiday, long service leave, annual leave or a sickie. I am told that it has something to do with access to organised sport. Consequently, the unions demand complicated and outlandish penalty rates for work performed by those who work during these official leisure periods.

Such ideology completely ignores the thousands of people who would happily exchange weekday work for work at evening or weekends. Their reasons might be that they enjoy daylight recreation, dislike overcrowded resorts and facilities, enjoy mid-week organised sport or dislike having to take sickies to enjoy mid-week organised sport et cetera. Leisure and industry costs would drop substantially if penalty rates were removed and facilities or plant properly utilised. The unions have decided we have reached a stage in our development which was achieved by the Romans just before they were overrun from the north. It is called the bread and circus syndrome.

Few of us doubt that our resources of personal endeavour do not stand up to world competition. So how can we live so well? We finance this bread and circus act by digging holes in the ground. Members of the Opposition complain of the sellout of natural resources. When will they realise that each and every one of those holes in the ground represents the price we must pay for the leisure that so many Australians demand, both on and off the job.

There is a solution to this crazy leisure push. If it is genuinely the belief of the union movement that the efforts of its membership demands additional leisure, let that membership face up to the reality of world competition. I call for immediate tariff trade-offs for all 35-hour week settlements whether or not the industry concerned receives protection. By such action at least those still working 40 hours or producing exportable commodities will get the benefit of cheaper goods. I am well aware that the original industries which will gain the 35-hour week do not receive protection and such across the board reductions would endanger jobs in other areas. We might then discover whether the union movement knows the meaning of the word brother. Let us face it: High on the list of soft spots for the 35-hour week campaign are the motor vehicle and agricultural machinery industries. When will the flow on get to clothing and footwear?

I mentioned the failure of the arbitration system. What good is an arbitration system for which one side has lost complete respect and the other any trust in its ability to function according to its charter? The principle function of the arbitration system in today's labour market is to legalise and enforce that otherwise illegal practice of resale price maintenance. It is handy for continuing evidence of the union secretary's dedication by being the vehicle for constant applications for new awards and wage increases. It is staffed and attended almost entirely by men whose contact with the real everyday problems of managing or working in business or industry is so remote as to be ludicrous. It allows one side to operate in the jungle while it demands that the other side stays out on the plain. If honourable members want an example of how far the system has drifted from the intentions of our forefathers in 1904 I ask them to consider section 40 of the current Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act, unchanged since that date. It states:
(1) In the hearing and determination of an industrial dispute or in any other proceedings before the court, the court (commission) . . .
(c) the Commission shall act according to equity, good conscience and the substantial merits of the case . . .

Yet the system today bows constantly to industrial expediency. Judgments are based not on how much the workers should get but how much they will take. This was exemplified when Sir John Moore, in his December 1978 4.3 percent national wage case statement, stated:

We agree that if the industrial effects of doing so could be ignored, no increase at all in award wages, would result in a greater restraint in costs and price. However, we don't believe that industrial considerations and their attendant cost implications can be ignored.

The highly expensive and publicised national wage case is played out every six months by, as I have said, a group of people least suited for the task. When the show is over the decision is invariably reserved. The following day or so members of the Press start predicting the likely wage rise. They do not do this by means of the much celebrated leak. They do not have to. The journalists does in five minutes what the court process takes some very costly weeks to achieve. He has a look at the consumer price index and discounts it by about 15 per cent to 20 per cent. He does what a group of workers and employers could achieve in half a day if they sat down together with good will.

The cost to the Federal Government to fund the arbitration system is estimated for 1980-81 at $5.74m. The States spend approximately a further $12.4m totalling, say, $18m. Because this system has totally lost the goodwill which was present at its birth and, consequently, no longer meets the purpose of its passing this House, I recommend its total disbandment and a refund of that money to our taxpayers. It is improper to have this Act on the statute book while the right to strike is still the principal industrial tool. The provisions of our universally applied common and criminal laws are sufficient to handle the legal aspects of industrial relations. If employers would take any advice from me they would also dismantle their present hierarchy. Its continuing participation in the present day farce is evidence of the need for new blood.

To date I have criticised the system without supplying solutions. I may appear to have been kind to the employers for their role in our modern day Comedy of Errors but I do not intend to be. I have now led us to a situation where we have not arbitration procedure and no supplicants at that altar. Presumably that leaves both sides with the opportunity to go into the jungle or out onto the plain. The choice would be theirs. As a solution I am impressed with the Swedish system of collective bargaining and labour relations as it operated in the early 1970s. The Australian and, more particularly, the Australian union organisers' idea of collective bargaining is that a large number of unions collect together to confront an individual employer. During the resulting industrial action it is often normal for that employer's competitors to smugly observe his troubles while running around offering to take the work he would normally receive. These same competitors achieve industrial harmony through sweetheart deals registered through a tame arbitration system. This allows those wage increases to be included in their rise and fall clause of work contracts and so flow on to suffering clients. That is not collective bargaining; that is selective bargaining. Collective bargaining must be at industry level and must be conducted by competent, experienced and intelligent people. The Swedish national employer body, the SAF, and the Swedish national employee body, the LO, appear to have those qualities. Both have exacting discipline over and control of their members. Both have strike funds created by levy to compensate members affected by industrial action. Most importantly, both reserve and effectively use the right to approve independently negotiated agreements or local strikes.

The intervention of the SAF and the LO in industrial disputes or negotiations removes the parochial issues and ensures the matter is judged on its merits and with due consideration to its national consequences. Imagine the consternation of some of our more militant unionists if, after starting a strike, they were told by the employer that he was off to the Gold Coast to spend his strike compensation while they negotiated with a competent and independent industry group. No wonder the Swedish Information Service could state in 1975 in its 'Facts on Sweden Sheet':

One would expect a system of central and nationwide negotiations like the Swedish one to be predisposed to open conflicts. But as far as private enterprise is concerned the annals have to go back to 1954 to find a conflict involving a national union. Since 1956 the year when central negotiations started, the parties have not even had to threaten industrial action except on two occasions. It is common to explain this unusual stability in terms of a 'power-balance' theory. The fact that both LO and SAF are so tightly knit and well disciplined and also well funded renders industrial action on a limited scale a rather inept way of settling conflcts.
I like the use of the word 'inept'. It appears that even public servants negotiate with the employers federation in industrial matters.

Might I emphasise here that the system I refer to is my understanding of that which functioned in 1975. I am not aware of recent developments, nor do I care about them. The system that I have referred to sounds fine to me. Both sides are out on the plain. Could it work in Australia? I believe it could, provided some surgery was conducted. The surgery necessary is the transplant of some bone from the heads of our union leaders to the spines of our employers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is perhaps a pity that the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) is not the Minister for Industrial Relations. If he were the resultant debates in this House could be very enlightening. The resultant distress in the community could perhaps teach the honourable member a thing or two about industrial affairs because the honourable member seems to be back in the dim, dark ages when he speaks on this subject. I think honourable members on this side of the House should be complimented for the restraint they showed in not interjecting during that maiden speech.
—Order! Might I just say that I have taken advice and can confirm that in fact this is not the honourable member's maiden speech.
—That is quite right. I invite those honourable members who would like to interject to feel free to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent). In particular, I support his remarks on unemployment and on family life. I was expecting the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar) to be in the chair. However, as he is not, I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to convey to him my appreciation of the role he played in the seminar that was held for new members. Although, technically, I am not a new member I attended the two-day seminar. I think it was one of the best things produced by the staff of this Parliament for a long time. So often new members came into this place with no knowledge whatever of procedure. The staff were painstaking in their efforts to make sure that we understood everything that happens.

I was pleased to hear the Governor-General say in his Speech to the Parliament that his Government had a commitment to social security and welfare measures which will strengthen the family and, through it, the social fabric of this country. He went on to say that his Government cared deeply about the quality of life in Australia. These two statements, taken in conjunction with several other statements in the Speech, reflect a care and concern for the unemployed, for Aborigines, for welfare housing, for research and for a host of other social issues. This really represents an about-fact by a government not known throughout welfare circles for its humanity or understanding of social problems. However, I welcome the change of heart, even if so far it is only on paper.

Let us deal with some of the issues in the Speech. I refer firstly to the need to overcome unemployment in general and to stimulate the employment of youth. Everyone in this House and those listening to the debate will be well aware of the tremendous level of unemployment in this country throughout every age group. In fact, over the last five years unemployment has escalated at a rate that Australia has not seen since the last depression. The Government's answer to this and its answer to the enormous number of young unemployed is to initiate a debate within the community on the advisability of cutting off the dole for 16 and 17-year-olds. The reason given by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr Viner) was as follows:
For some young Australians, the present payment of unemployment benefits may act as a disincentive to continue in formal education or training or to seek work . . .
The Government has said that it will be examining this as a matter of urgency, which means to me and my colleagues that it will again make policy on the basis of expendiency rather than evidence.

This is the same Government which in 1976 stopped unemployment benefit for school leavers because, it said, some young people were collecting unemployment benefit and then returning to school. No evidence was ever given. The same Government in 1979 provided a mandatory penalty of between six and 12 weeks without unemployment benefit for people who turned down casual work because it was said that fruit growers could not get casual labour. Again, no evidence was ever given, nor was it ever emphasised by the Government that if one takes a week's casual work one has then to re-register with the Commonwealth Employment Service and one loses next week's pay.

TALK.START.PARA: —Six weeks?

—But one loses another week even if one takes the work. No study has been undertaken by the Government to show that there are disincentive effects in paying $5 a day to the young unemployed who, indeed, have to spend a fair amount of that money on fares in looking for work. No government report on education and unemployment, and there have been plenty, has ever recommended that the unemployment benefit for 16 and 17-year-olds should be scrapped. The clear fact is that there are not enough jobs to go around and the periods of unemployment among all age groups are getting longer.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government completely misunderstands the problem of unemployment and the quality of living if it believes that every family can continue to support its children at school for an extra year or so. Low income earners certainly cannot; one income families certainly cannot; and single supporting parents certainly cannot. How a breadwinner who is on unemployment benefit, which happens a lot these days, is supposed to continue to support young adults at school for an extra year is beyond my comprehension. No one has explained to me where the jobs are to come from at the end of that extra year. The fact is that the Government refuses to accept that there are not enough jobs to go around and this prating about a clear commitment to the youth of the country is a clear insult to the army of unemployed. This House should remember that the coalition parties, when in opposition, tagged the unemployed as 'dole bludgers'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.

—That was their opinion of them then. Members of the coalition tagged them every time they opened their mouths in this House. Honourable members opposite attempted to make the victims the guilty ones.
—It was never used on this side of the House. The only people who used the term were people on your side of the House.

—Those on the honourable member's side of the House do not change their mind very often. 'Dole bludgers' they were then. Did the honourable member for Dundas not hear the honourable member for Diamond Valley (Mr N. A. Brown) castigating them again last night?

SPEECH.PARA: The Governor-General also mentioned that this Government has a commitment to the improvement of Aboriginal health. This Government has a dismal record in the area of Aboriginal health-in fact, in the care and concern of Aborigines and Aboriginal land rights generally. It was pleasing to see that commitment mentioned in the Governor-General's Speech but, unfortunately, the Government's track record is so bad that I do not have much faith in its putting up any programs. The Government is great on rhetoric but short on action. I would suggest as a starter that some honourable members opposite look at the mortality rate of black infants and the mortality rate of white infants throughout Australia. If they do they will see how much need there is for more than just talking about the health of Aborigines.

It has been said that the Government also intends to do something about welfare housing. It will not do anything about welfare housing if the honourable member for Diamond Valley has his way. I would suggest that the first thing this Government should do is speak to its Liberal colleagues in Victoria and suggest to them that the hundreds of thousands of families in Victoria which have been waiting for housing commission homes for anything up to six years should be attended to. When I made my maiden speech in this House six years ago I mentioned then that I had people coming to me who were desperate, whose families were breaking up, who had to have their children made wards of the State because they could not get cheap housing. The list gets longer; the waiting time increases and the despair becomes greater. People on low incomes, one parent families and pensioners cannot afford the high rents prevalent in Victoria and, in fact, all over Australia.

In Victoria in particular we have had a continuing debate over past months about the funding of the Olympic Games. The Minister for Youth, Sport and Recreation, who used to be the Housing Minister, was so keen on posturing on and postulating about the Olympic Games that he did not have time to look at his other portfolio. The present Minister for Housing has very little interest in welfare housing. If Victoria can find the hundreds of millions of dollars necessary to float the Olympic Games in either 1988 or 1992, good luck to it. But, first, it should make provision for those people in need of welfare housing.

With this new found care and concern of the Government for the quality of life in Australia, I suggest it now has a look at those ex-servicewomen who are not eligible for a defence service home loan. It is a fairly small group of women. The servicewomen, who enlisted at the time of World War II, were ineligible, by virtue of their sex, to enlist for overseas service, however willing they might have been to do so. Honourable members should remember also that servicewomen in those days received only two-thirds of the pay received by servicemen of equivalent rank. Since 1972 it has been possible for women members of the forces to obtain a loan but still those women who volunteered to serve their country in time of war are not eligible. These ex-servicewomen are suffering an injustice. A great way in which to recognise the services that they so willingly gave in years gone by would be for this Government sincerely to fulfil its wish to show care and concern for the quality of life and make the ex-servicewomen of yesterday eligible for the defence service home loan.

Interestingly enough, in the Speech of the Governor-General I found reference to the Government's recognition and appreciation of the contribution which the Public Service as a whole makes to life in this country. I endorse that statement wholeheartedly. However, the recent actions of this Government do not reflect any care or appreciation of the Public Service. For the first time in 50 years a decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission will be overturned by government legislation. This reflects great discredit on the present Government.

I was surprised also to read in the Speech of the Governor-General that the Government will give greater support and improved facilities for research. I am sure that those people at Monash University who have been asking for increased funding on a continuing basis will share in my surprise as its repeated requests to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) have fallen on deaf ears. I urge the Government to recognise the need for planned funding on a continuing basis so that medical research programmers will know where they are going for a definite period. Otherwise the brain drain to overseas countries will continue to the loss of our country.

Last year this Government insisted that it had funded community health centres set up by the Australian Labor Party in the period 1972 to 1975 up to the level of the previous year. As no funds were added to cover inflation, the health centres all had to cope with a 10 per cent decrease in their funding. This is one area in which the Government can fulfil the words of the Governor-General because the worth of health centres has been well proven in the community. Their value to community life is an accepted fact. They are not expensive to run and, in the field of preventive health care, are extremely valuable.

May I dwell for a few minutes on the plight of those people in the community dependent on social security. Time after time we have had reports prepared by respected groups within the community which have pointed to how many people are living below the poverty line. Professor Ronald Henderson, whose report on poverty has been well swept under the carpet, has urged that attention be given to those people whose incomes are totally inadequate. In answer, this Government has come up with a new method of defining poverty in the belief that by giving poverty a new definition it will fold its tent and silently move away. Professor Henderson's poverty level is pretty austere. The problem has probably been understated rather than exaggerated. Almost every welfare agency in our community-whether it be a voluntary or government agency-has criticised the Government for its policies. Almost every supportive body has run out of money to subsidise urgent needs.

All my colleagues have shared my experiences of more and more desperate families calling for help. For the first time, the pensioners association, in its frustration, called upon its members to vote this Government out at the last election. Family life is being threatened by poverty. Young unemployed have no access to things like dental care. The young unemployed I met during the last election campaign were very revealing in what they thought of politicians in general. They said to me: 'If you had a war, you would find us very welcome. We would have value. But our teeth can rot in our heads for all you care'. If one is poor and needs a hearing aid, one should forget about it. There is about a 24 month waiting list by which time one might not even need one. When this Government speaks of care and compassion for those in need, that is about all it does. A one income family with four dependent children on an income of $160 a week is now $25.40 below the poverty line. A single parent pensioner with four dependent children will be $27.70 below the poverty line.

All official reports surveying families-not just those of the Australian Labor Party-have called for an increase in allowances for children, particularly those children in poor families. Again the pleas fall on deaf ears. Without a change in government policy, half a million children will inevitably suffer through poorer housing, poorer health, poorer education and poorer job opportunities. The social problems of the future caused by this Government's policies are enormous. The Government appears determined, despite the Speech of the Governor-General, to follow a policy of survival of the fittest.

I wish now to discuss what was said by the honourable member for Diamond Valley (Mr N. A. Brown) in the Address-in-Reply debate last night. Evidently he believes that we will destroy society if we do not make people stand on their two feet and rely on their initiative and self-help. He kept saying: 'Set people free to determine their own futures. Cut social security so that they do not rely on it, and abolish welfare housing.

TALK.START.PARA: —And education.

—And education. The ominous words contained in his speech were to give the help 'in case of need'. The question of who will determine that need is what worries me. I certainly would hate to have the honourable member for Diamond Valley sitting in judgment on me to determine the case of need, particularly as he appears to have two incomes. Apart from his job here, I understand that he appears in the Australian Industrial Court for and on behalf of employers. I do not know what he would know about poverty.
—And he earns $1,000 a day.

—Yes, a very good fee. One would need to have experienced poverty in order to know about it. I will be very surprised to learn that the honourable member has experienced poverty. As George Bernard Shaw once said: 'Great wealth insulates people from the ordinary, every day experiences of living'. I would not know why the honourable member for Diamond Valley wants to abolish welfare housing or social security. If a business is not going too well, one tries to change the management. One does not abolish the business. If social services need improving-not abolishing-increase the welfare housing. The honourable member spoke a lot about poverty. It puzzled me somewhat as to why he dealt so much with it but he seemed rather interested in getting rid of it-under the carpet perhaps. We can get rid of poverty. In order to get rid of poverty we will have to make substantial changes in our approach to such fundamental matters as land tenure, housing, education, health, legal services, taxation and public spending. Such changes will not be forthcoming until either the political majority becomes committed to the abolition of poverty or the underprivileged minorities acquire sufficient political power to change the system of social stratification. I do not see either of those things happening in the foreseeable future.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to the honourable member for Diamond Valley that any society based on the ideology of laissez-faire requires a deprived population which is allegedly unwilling to work or unwilling to work hard. That is where the dole bludger syndrome came from. Not only does the alleged moral inferiority of the poor reduce the moral pressure on the present political economy to eliminate poverty, but also welfare measures can be kept to a minimum if those who will benefit from them most can be described as 'lazy', 'spendthrift', 'dishonest' or 'dole bludger'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I too would like to extend my congratulations to the new members of this House who have made their maiden speeches. I believe that to a very great extent those speeches have been positive and that those members should be congratulated for the contribution they have made. I am sure that my colleagues wish them a happy experience in this Parliament. My mind goes back some five years to the time when I made my maiden speech. It is rather a traumatic event, an event during which one realises what a tremendous responsibility one has taken on by becoming a member of this place. I hope that all new members will respect that responsibility and make their appropriate contribution to the betterment of life in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking tonight to the Speech of His Excellency the Governor-General, I should like to refer to just two aspects of future development in Australia. The first is the development over the next few years of the electronic media and other services in Australia. In technical terms, Australia is very much at the crossroads. There are great changes to come during the 1980s-new services, new technology, and a whole range of new things that in many respects probably are beyond comprehension. Some of these new services have already been introduced, with varying degrees of success. For the past 50 years the development of radio and television in technical terms has been very much like Topsy-it just grow'd, to the extent that now we are virtually facing a crisis situation, especially in regard to the supplying of facilities and frequencies for the new services. In fact, the situation is so critical that even existing services are suffering in such important areas as Sydney and Melbourne.

Although a study of frequency allocations is presently being conducted, there is still doubt in my mind as to whether this study will be enough to overcome the already critical situation of which I speak. I say that because I do not really believe at this stage that we know in which direction we are truly going, or which way we want to go, in fact. In Australia we have never really had any major system planning in frequencies. Certainly, in terms of the programs and types of media the public want, I do not really think we have a clue exactly what its expectation is or what it really wants. The public has been conditioned over a period to a system which I believe is one of the best in the world. However, we still do not really know what the needs of the public are.

I make these statements in conjunction with my comments about the frequency problems because in many respects the two are closely interlocked. At the moment, for many purposes the spectrum is being allocated on guesswork, with no real consideration of what future needs or desires may be. The truth is that currently the frequency allocations for television are saturated on the VHF band. We have introduced FM radio, and now channels 3, 4 and 5 on that band look as though they will have to be vacated by television to permit the wider introduction of more FM radio. If that occurs, what will happen to those stations from the Australian Broadcasting Commission and the commercial sector in areas such as Newcastle which presently use those frequencies? That is only the beginning. We are talking about the introduction of supplementary licences for television stations. Where will those bands come from? What will happen if the Special Broadcasting Service is extended beyond Sydney and Melbourne? Is a public television system to be introduced? If so, how do we handle that? There is great merit in the introduction of a second ABC network or an educational television service. We do not know just what we will do about that either.

We have a problem with Channel 5A. It looks as though that has to be cleared so that international meteorological services will not suffer from interference. There is yet a further problem if air navigation distance measuring equipment services are to be removed from the broadcasting band. Already in Sydney and, I understand, Melbourne difficulty is being experienced by new FM radio stations in that there is already the problem of interference or potential interference with television reception on channels 9 and 10, mainly through the use of domestic high gain television antennae. The frequencies being allocated for FM broadcasting are in the 88 to 108 megahertz band.

Station 2SER is causing problems in Sydney; 3MBS is playing havoc with television reception in Melbourne. Transmitter towers are springing up in these cities, where no due consideration is given to mast sharing or better locations to minimise that interference. To add to that, the technical specifications given to the two commercial FM radio stations by the Department of Communications frankly are just not good enough for those stations in Sydney-2MMM and 2DAY-to meet the requirements of their licences. They just cannot get enough power to adequately cover their licensed area. There are repeated reports of poor reception or lack of reception, to such an extent that the viability of these stations certainly must be in question. If we are truthful, it will be the commercial stations that will establish the FM band as a proposition for high quality stereo radio in Australia. Why we waste FM on talk radio is just beyond my comprehension. The medium is for stereo music broadcasting; the talks should obviously be going to another band. Admittedly, in this respect Sydney is worse off than Melbourne because of its topography. In FM radio power is all important for quality reception, but to my knowledge nothing has been done to try to rectify the situation or even to find out just how bad that reception is. Action is certainly urgently needed.

We badly need a frequency allocation policy to cover all aspects of broadcasting from radio and television right through to two-way radio systems and even as far as the citizen band radio system. Surely we can conduct a full and meaningful study to find out what the public wants in terms of the media, what the expectations are, and combine this with the identification of a suitable frequency allocation policy. The two are very much interlocked. We have had previous studies of the system. Attempts have been made to find out what some sections of the public want, but frankly we still do not really know what the phrase 'in the public interest' is all about. If somebody can tell me what 'in the public interest' means, I would certainly be appreciative. This is really no criticism of this Government or any government of any political persuasion that may have gone before. But we have a system that has simply evolved, and if we do not sort out the mess right now we are headed for disaster in the future. The frequency spectrum is a very precious commodity which must be managed and used well. We do not have that at the moment.

The second area to which I would like to turn my attention tonight is the development of airlines and aviation in Australia. Yesterday in this House the report of the Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares was tabled. I do not necessarily want to canvass that document completely at this stage, but I would like to turn my attention to aviation and the changing nature of that industry, and again flag moves that can well be made to Australia's great advantage. Commercial aviation in Australia, both domestic and international, has been one of the most protected industries in this country. In many respects these policies have worked well for Australia. However, times are certainly changing and this industry is undergoing dramatic changes around the world. The Holcroft report recognises the advantages of deregulation, and there is ample proof, despite what many of the local sceptics may say, of the advantages that deregulation or restricted deregulation can bring. Whilst not advocating a complete open skies policy for Australia, there is obviously a great deal of merit in loosening up the present Australian system, domestically and internationally.

I think we should look at what deregulation is all about. It is not about throwing safety standards overboard, about treating passengers to cattle truck conditions, and the other terrors that are constantly being propounded by the established aviation gurus in Australia. It is simply about aviation efficiency and the provision of the most economic fares for the travelling public, who are the real pawns in the aviation game. It is about the right aircraft for the right routes. It is not necessarily about subsidies or cross-subsidisation of services. I know that the critics will say that deregulation in the United States of America has been a disaster. Frankly, I believe that aviation in the United States would have been in a much worse state had it not moved to deregulation in 1977. There have been very great changes in the structure of US aviation and those changes are still going on. Despite the skyrocketing fuel prices, the US travelling public is getting a much better deal through special fares than we are. The fact that scheduled fares are about the same as ours is not really relevant. In the deregulated regime an entirely new system has developed. Innovative pricing structures now rule supreme. When we consider that nearly 90 per cent of airline passengers in the United States travel on special fares, it is just not right to try to compare our established air fare regime with that which exists in the United States. The Australian public owns more than 65 per cent of scheduled aviation operations on trunk routes in Australia. I believe that the shareholders of Trans-Australia Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd have the right to want a better deal in those companies in which they supposedly are shareholders.

International aviation is at a most interesting stage. An examination of that development in terms of deregulation, especially in the case of Great Britain, is most interesting. Great Britain has gone to a system of limited deregulation. Both the United States of America and Britain have led the way in opening up air travel to the populace. Despite the forecasts of disaster by the experts, the carriers and passengers alike have benefited greatly. For example, the London-Miami route was forecast to be the greatest disaster in aviation history when an additional carrier came on to the route offering fares at 50 per cent of the established pricing structure. However, in 12 months, from April last year, it is estimated that the traffic has grown by a massive 118 per cent. That is happening with three carriers offering innovative fares. In fact, the aircraft of all the carriers are full. All are much more profitable. Miami and London both have benefited in terms of tourist expenditure and now a fourth carrier is being welcomed to the route to handle the traffic. I mention the Miami-London route because the traffic on that route is similar to the volume of traffic between London and Australia. But there are other routes involving similar volumes which could be mentioned.

Since airline industry deregulation, in a 12-month period from last year, the volume of traffic on the London to Los Angeles route went up 177,073 passengers. The carriers on that route are profitable. There has been an increase of 60 per cent in traffic in one year. Last year on the London-New York route there was an increase in volume of traffic of 29 per cent after deregulation. Now five million Britons annually take package holidays overseas. That has happened since their limited deregulation regime was introduced. Because of our policies and admittedly the distance involved our share of that five million package holidays is the massive total of 2,000 holidays. At a recent public hearing held by the British Civil Aviation Authority, British Airways, one of the established, protected carriers on that route, admitted in public that it allocates 20 seats a week on 10 Boeing 747 services for package holidays to Australia. What a farce, what a sham, what a disgrace!

The Europeans and the Americans are travelling further now for their package holidays. That should give heart to all of us. Many of them are coming as far as Bali, which is about one and a half hours away from some of the major holiday resorts of Australia. I suggest that Australia's problem in gaining international traffic at the moment is no longer the tyranny of distance but rather the tyranny of the high air fares. Already 161,174 Britons travel to Australia to visit friends and relatives and for business purposes. They seem to take the distance in their stride. In 1979, 323,404 Australian went to Britain. The potential of that market certainly is there. Can we possibly imagine what a contribution could be made to the tourist industry, to the Australian economy and, as the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child) mentioned, the employment potential in this country if we had an open air fare regime? Add the 10 per cent growth rate on that route, which has applied for so many years now it is not funny, to the stimulation factor which increased competition would bring-it is estimated by experts in Britain to be 30 per cent-and the advantages for all Australians are blatantly obvious.

Another international aviation review is scheduled for this year. Let us hope that all options are canvassed, especially in regard to the loosening up of Australia's civil aviation arrangements. Certainly, a number of public statements have been made by the Chairman of Qantas asking for the right to compete in the market place. I believe that those moves should be welcomed. I am sure that Qantas realises that it would benefit most of all from that form of deregulation of fares. Qantas would be the greatest beneficiary, but the Australian travelling public would benefit too. Obviously they have a preference to travel with Qantas but, like travellers everywhere, they are cost conscious. Frankly, who can blame them for shopping around to get the best deal? Yet we see the amazing spectacle of ticket inspectors and prosecutions when all people are trying to do is simply get value for money. I do not think that that is right. If other airlines, whose fixed costs, frankly, are the same as those of Qantas, can offer cheaper fares there must be something wrong with the system.

The morality of the present air fare regime must be in question. People talk of orderly marketing, but the experience in most areas of business, including aviation overseas, is to let the market place find its own level, which it will do and quickly, bringing great benefits to everyone, particularly to the carriers and the travelling public. The International Civil Aviation Policy regime is dead, thank goodness. Let us now get our house in order as soon as possible because we can do that quite simply, as I have outlined. Let us not discriminate against Australians who wish to travel overseas. Certainly, let us not discriminate against visitors who legitimately want to come here and who legitimately want to spend their money in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Governor-General's Speech, which we are debating tonight, alluded briefly to Australia's defence preparedness and held out the promise-yet another promise-that defence expenditure would increase to about 3 per cent of gross domestic product, this time by 1984-85. Let me state at the outset that, despite the Government's rhetoric on defence, defence expenditure as a percentage of GDP has remained constant at 2.6 per cent for the past five years and is precisely the same as the level reached during the Labor Government's term of office. The Fraser Government's pronouncements on defence since 1975 have been a catalogue of hollow phrases and empty gestures of omissions and remissions. Before I itemise that catalogue I, as the last Minister for Defence in the Labor Government, want to set the record straight and to lay to rest once and for all the lie created and perpetuated by the Fraser Government that the Labor Government neglected defence and, in particular, ran down expenditure on new equipment.

SPEECH.PARA: All honourable members who have some knowledge of defence will recognise that there are long lead times between the decision to purchase equipment and the delivery of that equipment. The case of the F111 is a notorious example. The F111s were ordered with a great flourish in 1963, an election year, and they were not delivered until 1974, some 11 years later. It is important also to recognise that actual expenditure on major items of equipment can be spread over many Budgets. The main expenditure reflected in Budget outlays might not come for four of five years after the decision is made. Therefore, in analysing a current Budget, in effect we are looking at the consequences of decisions made four of five years before, not the decisions made in the current Budget year. That is precisely what happened to the Labor Government in its early Budgets. There had been a steady drop in actual expenditure on new equipment and stores from 1968-69 onwards. For a large part of the period from 1968-69 to 1972-73 the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) was Minister for Defence and the present Minister for Defence was Minister for the Navy. We set out to change that situation and we all now know the results. The Fraser Government for the past five years has been the beneficiary of the initiatives in defence taken by the Labor Government during the years 1972-75. The Labor Government initiated the purchase of two guided missile frigates. The present Government ordered another two. I congratulate it on this decision but it was hardly a brilliant initiative. It followed precisely what the Labor Government had laid out. We ordered 15 patrol boats to replace the Attack class. We ordered 87 Leopard tanks. The Fraser Government increased that order by 14 but, regrettably, I think that about 20 are still in mothballs. We ordered eight P3C Orion aircraft. The Government added another two to the order-hardly a challenging initiative. We ordered 12 C130 Hercules medium range transport aircraft. We ordered the HMAS Tobruk, the amphibious heavy lift ship. This was the Labor Party's equipment program in the period from 1972 to 1975. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. As an example, I announced the decision in 1975 to acquire 15 patrol boats. The first expenditure related to the purchase did not appear in any Budget until 1976-77. The major outlay did not appear until some years later in 1979-80. The nature of defence equipment purchases is such that the impact on the Budget comes in terms of progress payments. The progress payments on the patrol boats may well not be finalised for another four or five years. In short, this Government has been parading in borrowed clothes. The increased defence expenditure on new equipment in recent Budgets has been largely because of the initiative taken by the Labor Government in the period from 1972 to 1975.

SPEECH.PARA: It was not only in the well thought out initiatives in new equipment that the Labor Party made an outstanding and unrivalled contribution to Australia's defence preparedness. Critics of the status of Australia's defence should keep in mind that during the last 30 years the Labor Party has been in government for only three. Yet in those three years fundamental changes were made in defence policy and administration. I will give some of the context of the problems in defence administration that we, as a Labor Government, faced in 1972 and 1973. Vietnam marked the end of a particular kind of commitment that had determined Australia's defence thinking since the end of World War II. The defence authorities in the post-war period were preoccupied with immediate operational tasks associated with Korea, the Malaya emergency, and the South East Asian Treaty Organisation's confrontation and Vietnam. As in the world wars Australian responsibility was to mount expeditionary forces which were slotted into the combat forces of our principal allies and were under their command. Our force structure, procurement programs and training were determined by and fashioned to those commitments. In short, it was a derivative defence policy in which the major co-ordinates were determined for us by our allies.

The situation changed radically with the United Kingdom withdrawal east of Suez and the disengagement of the United States land forces in South East Asia. The Guam doctrine spelt out clearly that the United States expected its allies to handle with their own resources threats of a regional nature which were within their own capacity to resist. In this new setting Australia is required to pursue its own security interests by its own efforts more than was previously required. Intrinsic in this approach is that any future combat operations are much more likely to be in the Australian vicinity than in some forward theatre and our three Services are much more likely to be operating together rather than individually in support of an ally. The Labor Government clearly discerned this change. The aim of the reorganisation of the Services departments initiated by my predecessor, Lance Barnard, and passed into legislation during my term as Minister for Defence was to provide the administrative machinery for developing and implementing a self-reliant defence policy. Honourable members may recall that the Liberal Party in opposition was mindlessly opposed to the reorganisation. I was therefore delighted to read an unsolicited compliment from the Minister for Defence in his statement on 25 March 1980. He said:

The Defence administration in Australia was subjected in the 1970s to the most profound reorganisation in its history. I want it to be entirely clear that on the whole the Government is satisfied with the results.

I am sure that my predecessor, Lance Barnard, who took the initiative for the reorganisation, would be surprised but nonetheless appreciative, of this belated but handsome tribute. There were other outstanding achievements of the Labor Government administration in defence such as the establishment of the Natural Disasters Organisation, the introduction of a new Defence Force retirement scheme and a much belated upgrading of the pay and conditions of our servicemen. It was a remarkable period of intense and fruitful activity with which I was very happy to be associated. The Fraser Government has paid us the ultimate compliment of not changing the direction. Where it has fallen down is in its procrastination, its go-stop administration and in not keeping the very promises that it has made.

I think the Liberal-National Country Party Government's first mistake, which was no doubt prompted by its attitude that defence is more a public relations exercise than a serious national responsibility, was to depart from normal practice in announcing the target figures for the total five-year defence program. That is precisely what it did in the November 1976 White Paper. The White Paper was essentially similar to the program that had been approved by the Labor Government when in office. What the Fraser Government failed to realise was that five-year rolling defence programs are essentially a planning instrument. They are not and should not be seen as a definite commitment to purchase. As projects come up through the program to a Year 1 decision changes can be made, and usually are. I pointed this out at the time in an article in the Pacific Defence Reporter, as follows:
. . . by the time recommendations come up for decision-
And it could be to a Labor Minister for Defence-
a different perception of requirements may emerge.
But it was not until a year later, in his statement of 22 September 1977, that the Minister was forced to recognise this elementary fact when he observed:

. . . the issues with which defence policy is concerned are not static. They are constantly developing and we must keep them under continuing review and ensure that our defence planning is responsive.

However, the Minister asserted that the White Paper of 1976 remains the basic document, the basic reference for discussion of our national defence, and in that context I would like to examine one or two issues.

The paper proposed to increase expenditure on defence facilities-on airfields, naval and air bases, housing and so on, from 6.2 per cent of total defence expenditure in 1975-76 to more than 7 per cent in 1980-81. That was not a particularly daunting task, but the results have been disastrous. The Department of Defence has been good enough to make the comparative figures public.
