That is, instead or rising to 7 per cent in 1980-81 as promised, in fact it fell to 4.03 per cent, much less than the 6.2 per cent figure in Labor's last Budget. The table that the House has kindly given me permission to incorporate in Hansard also provides an interesting commentary on the Liberal Government's professed interest in defence co-operation. On 19 February of last year the Prime Minister stated that he believed:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that the abiding security interests that we share with our regional neighbours call for continuing consultation and co-operation in the defence field.
The Minister for Defence subsequently proclaimed:
. . . that policy has been pursued with vigour.

The evidence shows otherwise. At constant 1979 prices, the Labor Government devoted, in its last Budget, $45m to defence co-operation. During the last five years there has been a significant drop in defence co-operation expenditure. In 1980-81 it has falled to the level of $36m. We have become accustomed to this Government's flowery promises and subsequent retractions. It has left an ever-widening trail of broken promises but, regrettably for Australia, it is in the area of defence that the Fraser Government's penchant for broken promises is particularly evident. I can assure the House that the Labor Party will continue to monitor the Government's defence policy to ensure that its performance matches its promises and that Australia's security interests are adequately safeguarded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have today a great variety of addresses by honourable members in response to the Governor-General's Speech, including a number of maiden speakers whom I take this opportunity to congratulate, as well as the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child), who made her first speech following her return to the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: As a point of departure, I wish to refer to the speech of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden). Predictably, he found fault with just about anything and everything that the Government has done, but the thrust of his speech to which I would particularly take exception was the suggestion that, broadly speaking, ordinary Australians have been neglected, have not been well served, by this Government. That is just plain wrong. Australia, and the majority of Australians, are in pretty good shape and prospects for the near and longer term are bright indeed.

There are, of course, difficulties and problems to be overcome. I have in mind particularly the continuing high level of recorded unemployment and, in a different context, the increasing incidence of strikes and industrial action. Yet the strength and the performance of the Australian economy, which is a basic pre-condition for the well-being of the Australian people, cannot be gainsaid. That strength and performance is attributable in significant measures to the policies of this Liberal-National Country Party Government, policies which it has carried through resolutely, policies which, as the Governor-General's Speech put it, 'are designed to work for the well-being of all Australians'-that is the keynote-'and to develop a society which maximises the rewards of individual effort and initiative, and which also respects the rights of individuals to shape their own lives'.

One of the best indicators of the economic health of Australia is the growth in employment over the last year, the number of new jobs that have been generated by getting the basics of the economy right through sound policies-getting inflation down, restoring competitiveness and encouraging and applauding reasonable growth in profits. During 1980 total employment has been consistently 150,000 to 200,000 higher than in the corresponding period of 1979, an increase of 2.5 to 3 per cent, the order of growth to which we were accustomed in the 1950s and 1960s. We are talking of real additional jobs generated-I use that word deliberately-by the dynamics of a sound economy and appropriate policies, not jobs 'created' by a big spending program such as has been espoused by the Australian Labor Party, a program which, in fact, would be counter-productive. Indeed it would end up destroying as many jobs as it might initially create.

It is no coincidence that in a recent issue of the Australian Financial Review, of 29 January, there were two headings, one referring to the fact that economic activity and business is now the best that it had been for many years and the other announcing an increase of only 2.1 per cent in the consumer price index for December, the lowest for a December quarter since 1972, giving a 9.3 per cent price increase for 1980-well below the 12.4 per cent average of the countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, a fact which was also reported in the same issue. I repeat, those two reports are by no means a coincidence. It is a basic, fundamental proposition, yet one that the Labor Party will not accept, or affects not to accept, that the anti-inflation stance of this Government has been and remains central, not so much as an end in itself but as a means to an end-the achievement of increased activity, employment and growth. It is a central fact that inflation itself is the major cause of unemployment, the major underminer of growth. One fights inflation, not in preference to reducing unemployment, as Labor Party supporters would try to suggest, but in order to reduce unemployment-by the growth of jobs on a lasting basis. To quote the Governor-General's Speech, there is no realistic alternative.

I wish now to emphasise that this growth in jobs will continue, with the great boost to Australian development that is now under way, the so-called resources boom, the term used by the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren) in this debate a short while ago. I put 'resources boom' in quotation marks because there is something of a tendency to see it as a thing apart, whereas this surge of new development, which has been nurtured and encouraged by this Government's policies, should be seen as central and integral to the strength, the dynamic, the growth in activity and jobs, in the Australian economy today. 'Resources boom' is not a good term. In the minds of many it has overtones of stock exchange fever and the like.

TALK.START.PARA: —It goes far beyond resources.

—It goes much beyond. We are talking about a great new era in Australia's growth and development, centred on our massive energy resources, especially coal but also shale and crude oil-I am confident of that-uranium, and so on. One might speak of an energy rush comparable in dimensions and thrust to the gold rush period of the 1850s which made possible the first great period of prosperity and growth in Australia. It was an age in which Australia became recognised as a land of great opportunity for everyone. Indeed, in an energy hungry world where the advanced industrial countries must change away from dependence on oil, Australia's massive reserves of coal and other energy sources places it in the box seat of history. I hope that all Australians, and especially the youth of Australia, can catch something of the meaning, the vision, of what it is all about. It means not only higher living standards for all Australians, but also what we do with our resources will affect the lives of countless millions of people overseas, lifting their hopes and expectations, improving the lives of people all around the world, including particularly those in the developing countries.

SPEECH.PARA: I referred a moment ago to higher living standards for all Australians. That is the key note. The resources boom is not a thing apart; it is not just about a variety of big projects or, as many seem to think, big profits for big multinational or transnational-or whatever the in word is-companies. Yet, you get that sort of thinking. It is the stock in trade view of the Australian Labor Party that somehow in all this Australians are being exploited, that there is great benefit to the parties or companies immediately involved but Australia and Australians generally are not getting the benefits. Whilst the Labor Party likes to promote that sort of thinking, it is simply not the truth. It is just plain wrong; it is wrong-headed. The development-exploitation if we like in its proper sense-of Australia's great energy and other resources benefit all Australians, not just those immediately involved. Indeed, it is a key thrust of the Government's policies and its firmest determination that the development of Australia's great energy and other resources benefit all Australians.

Thus it should be noted that 46 per cent of every dollar of company profits goes direct to the Government to be used for the benefit of all Australians. In respect of the mining industry the figure, including resource-type imposts, is 53.7 per cent of every dollar of profit. It goes to the Government for disbursement in the interests of all Australians. This direct benefit, as well as dividends accruing to Australian ownership, is only the first part of the story. Next there are the new jobs, towns, railways and wharves and so on associated directly with the construction phase of new projects. There is also a spinoff in jobs in Melbourne, Sydney and elsewhere for manufactured structures, machinery, et cetera, for the new projects. That means more jobs, real jobs, for Australians. There is the permanent expanded employment base in industries which are viable in the highly competitive world of today. That reduces, although it does not eliminate, our dependence for employment on, for example, the motor industry where it is desperately difficult to sustain a competitive industry. Witness the position in the United States where the losses of the big three last year were of the order of $4 billion.

Next, there are the exports, including the sale of coal, in due course liquid natural gas from the North-West Shelf, bauxite, but also now, increasingly, the immensely more valuable aluminium. Exports benefit all Australians, for without exports to pay for needed imports no economy could work at the level of activity required to maintain high employment. In short, it all adds up to a strong economy which is the envy of the world, higher living standards for all Australians and for countless millions overseas, a natural growth in tax revenue to provide needed government services and lower tax rates. That is what this era of growth and development that we have entered is all about.

Having referred to exports, I conclude by saying that there are those around who, confronted with the wonderful prospect of greater growth in export earnings, see it as an embarrassment of riches. They get worried and talk about the Dutch disease or, alternatively, they preach a doctrine that says we should spend up much bigger on cheaper consumer imports. Rather, I believe it is important that we should continue traditionally to import capital-we need to do that because of the magnitude and lumpiness of many of our new developments and their need for associated technology and know-how-but at the same time, let us become exporters of capital and use the bonanza of export receipts, if there is one, to acquire assets. We want Australia, Australians and Australian companies to acquire assets both in terms of buying overseas and in terms of buying back assets here. It is the old phrase about buying back the farm, although there is much more than the farm. We have seen this week Caltex Oil (Australia) Pty Ltd announce that it will make provision for a public float and Australian ownership in part of its Australian operation. Let Australian individuals and institutions take up that. In recent years the Broken Hill Pty Co Ltd has acquired the Peabody Coal Company. It has acquired the Burmah Oil Australia Ltd stake in the North-West Shelf project. A bit of muscle is sorely needed there with the tough Japanese negotiators they are facing. Australian companies are establishing factories overseas to mesh with their Australian operations, to produce more efficiently.

All these things involve making payments overseas. Paying money overseas has the same effect as buying imports. If one is afraid of too much money from exports-and what an attitude that is-there is plenty to do with it. Let us have even more policies to promote the building of Australian ownership of assets in Australia-assets previously owned by overseas interests as well as assets in overseas countries, the earnings from which will benefit future generations-our children and their children. I tend to get short with people who, confronted with this prospect of great growth in export earnings see it as I said a moment ago, as an embarrassment of riches rather than thinking of building up assets and passing on the gains to our children. That thinking, I believe, is on a par with the Opposition's line on petrol prices-keep the petrol prices low, use it profligately, and to heck with our children; let them worry about it when the time comes. That is its attitude. The policy to promote this growth is an integral part of this Government's overall policy and so, as I observe that it is nearly time to adjourn this debate, I will conclude on the note on which I started: The policies of this Government are designed to work for the wellbeing of all Australians. That is the Government's commitment; that is the Government's resolve.
Debate (on motion by Mr Wallis) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Issue of Passports-Immigration-Pensions-Closure of Engineering Firm-Training School for Unemployed-Taxation-Azaria Chamberlain Case

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Hodgman) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) is not present in the chamber tonight because I wanted to draw his attention to the problems that are being encountered in the Melbourne Passports Office. I have received a number of complaints from my constituents who find that they are having a tremendous battle to get passports. The section is grossly understaffed and no doubt this is the result of the deliberate policy and the mania of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) for setting unrealistic staff ceilings. In that section only one supervisor attends to 14 or 15 people who are often lined up trying to get passports. He has to go away and verify some of the details as well as answer the telephone; so the people in the office can wait anything up to an hour and a half to be dealt with.

SPEECH.PARA: I know from personal observation that understaffing is suffered by the Commonwealth Employment Service and the Department of Social Security, because I have spent a day in each of those offices in my local area and I have seen that the stress the staff are working under is tremendous. Quite a number of people need their passports from the Passports Office in a hurry because they have made their bookings. I do not really think that staff anywhere, be they public servants or other employees, should have to work under such a tremendous strain. To test the delays, one day a member of my staff rang the Passports Office but the telephone was never answered. This is what is happening to the people applying for passports. They phone but they can get nothing done because the fellow on the counter does not have the time to answer the calls. So the people go to the office when their passports do not arrive. That means they will have a wait of another hour or so while the overworked fellow behind the counter tries to deal with everyone.

I am told, and unfortunately I cannot verify some of these assertions but I am sure the Minister can, that most passports are issued three weeks late and some are not ready for collection when the people are ready to leave to go overseas, which causes them a lot of worry and concern. Some people need their passports because they are travelling to Europe or somewhere else due to the illness of a parent or for other reasons and they have to get there in a hurry. I am also told that the Passports Office has a backlog of something like 6,000 passports. Unfortunately, I cannot check those figures, but the Minister can. I think that he should do so as quickly as possible both for the benefit of the hard working staff and for a very long suffering public.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falconer Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very disturbed to read a recent Press report of a statement apparently made by Miss Liliana Gasinskaya, the so-called 'red bikini girl', who was granted resident status in Australia in January 1979. Honourable members will recall that Miss Gasinskaya achieved notoriety after she jumped through a porthole of the Soviet vessel Leonid Sobinov and initially claimed political asylum in Australia. Her case was reviewed by the Determination of Refugee Status Committee or DORS Committee which determined that she fitted the definition of a refugee, and on that basis the then Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs quite properly granted her permanent residence in Australia. In the Sydney Morning Herald of 13 December last, the following sentence appears in a report of her discussion with another Soviet defector, Mr Victor Dudko:

SPEECH.PARA: Miss Gasinskaya, who jumped through the porthole of the cruise liner 'Leonid Sobinov' in Sydney Harbour two years ago, declared that she still had her Soviet citizenship and her Soviet passport and had been back to the USSR on holiday to see her parents.

The statement that she has recently returned to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics to visit her parents surely raises certain questions about her refugee status. The United Nations convention relating to the status of refugees defines a refugee as a person who is outside the country of his or her nationality and is unable to return to that country or is unwilling to return to that country owing to a well-founded fear of being persecuted. What then is the position of a person who, having claimed refugee status, is able to visit her home country at a later date apparently without any suggestion of persecution.

Let us examine some of the statements attributed to Miss Gasinskaya at the time her applications for political asylum and then refugee status were being considered. The Canberra Times of 17 January 1979 records the person who found her after her escape from the Soviet vessel as saying this:
She kept talking about how she hates Russia and was afraid to go back.
The Daily Telegraph of 18 January 1979 states:
Miss Gasinskaya has said she fears reprisals if she is handed back to Russian authorities.
She has told friends she has made since her arrival in Sydney she would rather die than return to Russia.
The Melbourne Age of 17 January 1979 quoted her as saying:
I hate Russia and I saw the ship as my only chance to leave the country.

Clearly she based her claim for refugee status on a fear that she would be subjected to some persecution if she returned to the Soviet Union. Since it appears that Miss Gasinskaya can travel in and out of the Soviet Union with impunity, I believe that the Government should review her refugee status and consider returning her to the Soviet Union. If events have gone too far for that to occur, then we should learn a lesson from this incident.

We must be wary of claims from people who use terms such as 'political asylum' and 'refugee status' to gain themselves sympathy when the fact is that they merely prefer to live in Australia. Many people have that preference and under our immigration laws we often are required to reject their applications. These cases of highly publicised defections of attractive people such as the 'red bikini girl' or ballet dancers only bring our immigration policies into disrepute and probably make it more difficult for us to pursue normal family reunion applications from east European countries.

We did not even score any ideological points with Miss Gasinskaya's defection as her expressed hatred of the Soviet Union seemed to stem more from a feeling that the shops in Russia were boring and that our beaches, as portrayed in magazines, were beautiful. As Michael Barnard pointed out in the Melbourne Age of 20 January 1979:

This may be all very flattering to us here, especially when liberally dashed with words such as 'freedom', but it is not a very penetrating indictment of the Soviet system as great Soviet human rightists like Dr Sakharov see it.

I think it is fair to say that while the Australian public supported the decision to allow Miss Gasinskaya to stay in January 1979, it would now welcome an opportunity to be rid of her and would certainly support the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) taking a very sceptical attitude towards such people in the future.
Incidentally, while looking through the Press reports of the incident, I came across one statement which has proved to be prophetic. A report in the Canberra Times of 18 January 1979 says this:
The Captain of the Leonid Sovinov described Miss Gasinskaya yesterday as a bad worker who had caused trouble.
In an interview before the ship sailed from Melbourne to Adelaide, Captain Constantin Nikitin said she would prove 'a real pain in the neck for Australia'.
Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not usually quote Soviet authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the attention of the House the plight of women under 50 years of age who lose eligibility for a Class B widow's pension and supporting mother's benefit when their children cease to be dependants. A group of these women in my electorate has formed an association and is seeking a simple change in legislation to lower the age of eligibility for a Class B widow's pension from 50 to 40. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the detail of their submission.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
A PROPOSAL SUPPORTING THE LOWERING OF THE AGE OF ELIGIBILITY FOR WIDOWSCLASS B PENSION
Introduction

It is proposed that the age limit for the Widows Class B Pension be lowered to allow for the inclusion of women in the 40-50 year age bracket. At the present time widows or deserted wives under a certain age and without dependant children are expected to find employment.
Facts About Current Eligibility for Widows Pension and Supporting Parents Benefit
Widows Pension is divided into three categories:
Class A-a widow or deserted wife with a dependant child (dependant child-under 16 years, or a full-time student under 25 years).
Class B-a widow or deserted wife of 50 years of age with no dependant children.
Class C-payable for a period up to 26 weeks after death of spouse, to a widow under 50 years with no dependant children.
Supporting Parents Benefit applies to a sole parent who supports a child and who does not qualify for Widows Pension.

The Widows Pension and Supporting Parents Benefit supply a basic income of $61.05, with additional entitlement to fringe benefits which include, amongst other things, a Pensioner Health Benefits Card, rate rebates and discounts on telephone rental and transport.
What Does This Mean

1. A widow without dependant children, and who is under 50 years of age is not eligible for continuing pension (except under certain circumstances) and is forced to seek employment. Unemployment at the present time is high with skilled workers finding it difficult to obtain employment, and unskilled workers finding it even more difficult. The majority of widows in the 40-50 year age bracket belong to the latter section of job seekers. Many have devoted their whole lives to their families and do not have skills relevant to the present employment situation. Their future prospects of finding work are even worse than their present prospects, with increasing age and length out of the workforce being a deterrent to employers.

2. These women are forced to exist for lengthy periods of time on unemployment benefits. Unemployment benefit was not designed for long term usage and the low rate of payment plus work tests over a long period of time lead to a general decline in the physical and mental health, with the result that the women are being placed on sickness benefits. Sickness benefit however, was also designed for short term usage and is unable to provide security for the women.

3. The widow pensioners were financially better off on the Widows Pension and Supporting Parents Benefits than on either Unemployment or Sickness Benfits due to the fringe benefits that are not applicable to persons on the latter two benefits. This, plus the security of knowing they would receive an income for some time in the future gave the widows some sense of confidence in the future. The present state of financial insecurity, and the inability to cope adequately on the benefit, is as mentioned previously, leading to great emotional strain which is resulting in physical and emotional decline.

4. The change from the pension to a benefit has even greater repercussions where the mother is attempting to retain a family home, and the child is either working or also on unemployment benefit. The change in benefit brings with it a change in status, and a change in identity, which can result in the family breaking up due to the child seeing and wanting a change of role for both parties, and the parent resisting this. Basically the shift in status and identity is related to loss of the ability to give financial support by the parent, and thus loss of ego and a change in self image and rebellion by the child to contribute equally to the upkeep of the home while also having to answer to, and obey, the parent. With equal payments towards upkeep of the home the child wants equal responsibility over his life and resists parental concern and any curbing of activities etc. As the whole relationship undergoes a change more strain and stress is inflicted upon an already stress packed situation.
What Can be Done

1. Legislative change could re-define the Class B Widows Pension to include women who are 40-50 years of age. The result would be a re-establishment of security and dignity, and hopefully the prevention of some family breakdown.

In re-defining the Class B Pension to include widows in the 40-50 year age bracket the Government would not actually be allocating more funds to be spent on social security but rather re-distributing it. The women who would be eligible for the re-defined Class B Pension are already receiving monies from social security in the guise of either unemployment benefits or sickness benefits. The Government would not have to set up an administering body for the proposal and it should entail less work in the long term as the re-defining of the Class B Pension would make the Class C Pension redundant.
The re-defining of the Class B Pension would result in security of income for the widows and the addition of fringe benefits, which is of great significance to a person on minimal income.

2. Many widows expressed a sincere desire to find employment and thus be independant of Government aid. It is not envisaged that the re-defining of the Class B Pension will greatly detract therefore from the number of mature women attempting to find employment. It is envisaged that with a more secure financial position these women will be able to apply for suitable positions with the degree of self esteem and confidence that makes them a more suitable proposition to employers.
3. It is also proposed that re-training schemes could be created to cater for the unskilled mature women who wishes to enter the workforce, thus, enhancing her ability to obtain employment.
Conclusions

Informal contact with the Department of Social Security has revealed that there is an increasing number of women entering this situation. As it is envisaged that the number of women in the situation, and the problems they face, will continue to increase rather than decrease we urge you to initiate some legislative action.

This proposal has been prepared by the 'Women In Search', which is a group of women in the situation depicted in this paper, being women under 50 years of age who lost entitlement to the Widows Pension or Supporting Parents Benefit when the youngest child turned 16 years.
As a result of recent publicity a number of other groups have indicated their support for 'Women In Search' and their cause. These groups are:
Civilian Widows Association.
Melville Business and Professional Womens Association.
Womens Federation-National Country Party.
S.W.A.G.-(Social Work Action Group).

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. If a woman loses her status as a supporter of dependants after turning 45 she can secure a widow's pension. But if a woman loses that status before she is 45 years of age she must wait until she has turned 50 before she can secure a widow's pension. At present, such women in their forties have to go on unemployment benefit. This means that they lose security of income through having to face the work test. They also lose fringe benefits such as their pensioner health benefits card, rate rebates and discounts on telephone, rental and transport. They also lose about $8 a week in cash. These women have very little chance of finding work. They are reaching their forties and are women who, at the time they married, were actively discouraged from entering the work force. Hence they tend to be women without skills. They usually find themselves in competition, even when they are re-training with young women who are in a similar situation but who are more attractive to employers.

SPEECH.PARA: The necessity of making fortnightly visits to the Commonwealth Employment Service office to be interviewed by employment officers concerning their efforts to find work and to apply for jobs they know they have no chance of getting places great strain on them. Over a period, the stress often causes a decline in physical and mental health such that the women go on sickness benefit. When they are sufficiently recovered they go back to the same routine on the unemployment benefit and so the cycle continues until they turn 50. A change from the pension to the unemployment benefit has even greater repercussions when the mother is attempting to retain a family home and the child is either working or is on unemployment benefit. The change in benefit brings with it a change in identity which can result in the family's breaking up owing to the child's seeking and wanting a change of role for both parties and the parent's resisting this trend.

The Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) has, on occasions, in reply to this group-there has been correspondence between them-expressed the view that the needs of those on social security benefits must be balanced with the willingness of the taxpayer to pay more. In this particular instance the reality of the situation is that the taxpayer does not have to pay a great deal more to continue to support women on the widow's pension as opposed to their receiving the unemployment benefit. If the employment situation were such that the women could find work then the Minister would have a case but the situation is that it does not seem likely in the very near future and certainly not in the life of this Government, that they will find themselves in that fortunate situation.

The existence of the Class B widow's pension for a widow or deserted wife of 50 years of age indicates that successive governments have recognised the situation of older women in this position. While women in their forties may be relatively more employable than women in their fifties, their chances of actually finding work are remote. Informal contact with the Department of Social Security has revealed that there is an increasing number of women in this category. The problems these women face are major and can have lasting effects. I urge the Minister to undertake the simple legislative remedial action of lowering the age of eligibility for a Class B widow's pension from 50 to 40 years of age. At least the Minister should consider special provisions whereby women in this category retain pensioner cards entitling them to benefits. It cannot remotely be argued that this change would be a major charge on the Commonwealth because the benefit obtained by rebate often relate to State, local government and private services.

Finally I should like to draw attention to a further anomally. The Family Law Act no longer recognises blame and, therefore desertion. The relevant section of this Act concerning desertees does, however, do so. A woman deserted is entitled to the benefits that I have already outlined. A woman who deserts is not entitled to the benefit beyond the point of time when she ceases to support dependants. She must secure a divorce or when she reaches the age of 50 years or she is entitled to nothing. A variety of factors may determine a woman's decision to leave home and a variety of reasons may make her unwilling to seek a divorce. To retain in this Act a distinction in status between deserters and desertees which is no longer recognised in legislation.--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wallis Mr L.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —An article appeared on the front page of the Adelaide Advertiser this morning headed: 'Firm closing at Whyalla'. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: A Whyalla engineering company employing about 100 workers said yesterday it would begin to phase out its operations and close the plant by early 1982.
The company is NEI Engineering which, under various names, has been in Whyalla for 27 years.
It makes steam condensers, feed heaters, heat exchangers and pressure vessels.

All of these, of course, would be involved in any thermal power station. As the article stated this firm has been in Whyalla for 27 years. It is a branch of the A.C. Parsons group in Great Britain. It has played a significant part in Whyalla and it will be a blow to that city if this firm closes. It employs more than 100 people who are all very highly skilled in their particular trades. I think that something should be done either by the State government or this Government to keep this firm in operation. The employees are to be retrenched between now and the end of this year or early next year. The only alternative employment in Whyalla is with the Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd and a few other small firms. The fact that this firm is to close certainly makes it more difficult to overcome the employment situation in Whyalla. It is a highly specialised industry. As I mentioned earlier, its products are connected with thermal power stations. The article to which I referred mentioned feed heaters, heat exchangers, pressure vessels and so on. All these things are used in the power industry. The divisional managing director of the firm is quoted in the article as stating:

We are finding ourselves in the position where we are not receiving sufficient work in this field to keep the business going and we have come to the conclusion that, on future projections, there is no point in carrying on . . .
We will wind down the factory from tomorrow onwards.

Just 45 to 50 miles away from this plant at Port Augusta a new 500 megawatt power station is being built. In this country we talk about the resources boom. Surely one of the major factors of the resources boom will be the production of power. Yet here we have a firm that makes the gear so that the thermal power houses can be established. This firm is to close down because of a lack of orders. I think it will be a backward step for this country if the State government, which is responsible for the powerhouse that is being built at Port Augusta, does not see that sufficient orders are given to this firm to keep it going. I have visited the place. I was a tradesman boilermaker. I have seen the extremely high quality of the workmanship in the factory. The workers can be proud of it and their industry enjoys a very high reputation.

As I have mentioned, it is about time a government came to the assistance of the industry, particularly at Whyalla. The decision to close Whyalla shipyard was made three or four years ago. Despite promises of the Government representatives who had discussions with the people at Whyalla and said that they would assist the retention of the Whyalla shipyards, those shipyards were eventually closed. The Government members came back to Canberra and voted for exactly the opposite of what they told the people of Whyalla they would do. The people of Whyalla, of course, felt very let down.

We know that 'decentralisation' is a word that is bandied about but does not have much recognition given to it. I think it is about time that recognition was given to it especially in a highly skilled area on which this country will greatly depend if the resources boom that we hear about takes place. If a firm such as this closes, the material, et cetera, will have to come from either Japan or West Germany. I think it is up to the Commonwealth Government, in consultation with the State Government, to ensure that this firm stays in operation to provide Australia with very necessary equipment. It is capable of doing so. It has the skill. Its product is up to overseas standards. I am sure that if the governments can give the industry some assistance it will not be lost to Whyalla and those hundred employees at Whyalla will not lose their jobs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday I had the opportunity to open a course at the Wollongong Technical College involving a training scheme for 10 unemployed young women who had been out of work for at least four months. They began a training scheme arranged by a section of the Wollongong Chamber of Manufactures representing the textile industry. People from this section of private enterprise had got together and requested the Government to participate in a scheme which would involve the training of these young people so that they would be able to play a full role in the work force. They also guaranteed jobs to the 10 young women involved on the successful completion of their course at the Wollongong Technical College. The Government provided approximately $3,000 towards this venture, this money being assistance to both the running of the course and the payment of the National Employment and Training Scheme allowances to the participants.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the first time that this has been done in New South Wales. I believe that it was also done in South Australia recently. I hope that it will be a precursor of many other schemes in which private enterprise initiates and joins the Federal Government in providing real opportunities for unemployed people to participate fully in the work force. What cheered me up was the fact that the Federal Government responded in such a positive way to this request by private enterprise. I was glad to assist in the decision, by this Government, to provide this funding. I hope this kind of scheme will be part of the present funding arrangements that the Federal Government has introduced. As the House knows, this funding applies to both the secondary school system and the technical college system in the Commonwealth.

Unfortunately, in New South Wales in particular, and I believe in other States as well, the State governments have failed to participate in the transition training program. Certainly, in my electorate at least one high school in an area with a high level of unemployment advises me that its school to work transition program has been diminished this year despite the fact that Federal Government has increased the amount of money available for the school to work transition program. There has been no diminution whatsoever in the amount of real funding that the New South Wales Government is getting. Yet, as I understand it, the Dapto High School in my electorate-certainly an area which needs a great deal of assistance-is being required to cut back on its transition course funding. Nonetheless, it will be able to maintain some kind of course this year.

It seems to me very unfortunate that the State governments have not accepted the invitation of the Federal Government to participate in this magnificent program, which I believe is doing the right thing to provide job opportunities for many young people who, frankly, have been wrongly directed in their school activities. It is not simply a question of trying to pass the blame to somewhere else. This Government is trying to do something positive to create a better situation for young people who cannot otherwise get jobs because they are not trained or prepared for full participation in the work force. That is why I was so glad to take part in a course which demonstrated that if young people do have the work skills there are jobs available for them from the employers in the area. As the employers themselves indicated, there is a lack of skilled young people. What the Government has done in this case, and what I hope it will do in many other cases, has been to get together with private enterprise and assist in the training of young people so that they can become useful members of the work force. I congratulate the textile manufacturers of the Wollongong region for their initiative. I certainly congratulate the Government for participating in this most worthwhile course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: — This evening I wish to draw to the attention of the House a problem that a number of my constituents will come up against later this year when they receive a tax bill from the Government. Many pensioners in my electorate, and indeed in Australia as a whole, will receive a Taxation Office bill this year which they will be unable to pay. They will have to ask the Commissioner of Taxation for time to pay. They will experience great personal problems in arranging to pay the money that they owe to the Australian Government. These people have taken the advice of the Department of Social Security in that they have been told that their pension benefits or pension fringe benefits will not be affected if they receive an income of up to $20 per week. These people believe that the Department of Social Security is the arbiter of most of the Government's policies in respect of matters relating to the pension. However, what those people do not realise and what some people in my electorate are coming to me about now is the fact that if they earn the $20 a week that the Department of Social Security says they can earn, at the end of this taxation year they will have to pay income tax on a proportion of that money.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to give the Parliament two examples of people in entirely different circumstances being caught in the Government's draconian tax net. A single pensioner receives $3,304 per annum. If this person earns the $20 a week that the Department of Social Security says he is allowed to earn, his total remuneration will be $4,344 per annum. The tax threshold in this country is $4,041 per annum. This means that this pensioner will have to pay tax on the final $303 of his income. As a result he will receive a tax bill of $96.96 in June this year.

A person who has money invested in a fixed deposit, a bank or some other institution that returns him an income of $20 per week will have to pay provisional tax. The Government's tax threshold for provisional tax as introduced in the last Budget is $1,000. So this person will have to pay provisional tax on his income earned over $1,000. A person who receives a return on his investment of $20 a week will have to pay tax of $99.96 this financial year. That is because the Department of Social Security is not advising people who are receiving pensions that they will be liable to pay income tax. For a government that has said on many occasions that it wants to encourage initiative and the people who are recipients of social security benefits to do something for themselves, it is very much mitigating against those people.

We have heard the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in recent days talk about the ways that those people on extremely high incomes will profit from some changes that the Government intends to make to the taxation laws. I think it is very pertinent that we should highlight in this Parliament the problem faced by people who are on the lowest levels of incomes in this country, the pensioners, who will be taxed this year by the Fraser Government. Where those people will find the $100 that they will have to pay at the end of this year I do not know. Those people do not know either. I think the Government should bring in retrospective legislation in this session of the Parliament to increase the non-taxable threshold for income tax purposes to $4,344 per annum so that those people are not put into that situation by the Treasury.

In conclusion I wish to say that I have written to the Treasurer on this matter on two occasions in recent weeks. I have not even received the courtesy of a reply. I might say that it is probably the attitude that the Treasurer and the Government have for the pensioners of this country who are the people who made this country what it is. The resources boom which the Government reckons we are all going to get rich from was brought about because of the hard work of those people in their working lives. I commend to the Government retrospective legislation in this session of the Parliament to raise the taxation threshold so that the people who receive pensions in this country and earn the $20 a week that the Department of Social Security says they are allowed to will not be taxed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to raise a matter that has caused a great deal of interest in this country and a great deal of comment. It concerns the celebrated dingo case at Ayers Rock. Firstly let me say that I was delighted to hear of the decision of the coroner. I was appalled at the innuendoes and the smear campaign that was waged against the Chamberlain family in the period leading up to the decision. I was appalled at some very intelligent people-they are friends of mine-who were prepared to believe the very worst about these people and not give them a fair hearing. I am delighted that the decision was given as it was.

SPEECH.PARA: I was camping in the same area a few weeks before that incident occurred, on 30 June. During the last evening we were there I was disturbed by a noise. I thought it was my two sons fighting in the next tent. I stuck my head out and found that a dingo had overturned a huge garbage can. As I stuck my head out the dingo ran away. I was also told by the national parks and wildlife people that the day before they had killed a dingo which had savaged a young boy of about nine years of age; that was the second case in the last 12 months.

I read the evidence very carefully. In my view it was absolutely impossible for anything to have occurred other than as was stated in the decision of the coroner. I believe is was impossible for any human being to have caused the injury to the child. Because it is difficult to answer the question it is not fair to accuse the Chamberlains of being participants in murdering their own child, which is what people have done. Finally, let me say that I am appalled at the coroner's suggestion that dingoes or animals of any description be destroyed in the parks. I have the greatest sympathy for the tragedy which the Chamberlains have suffered, but surely to God we are not going to commit the absurdity of banning wild animals from national parks. It is a bit like saying that one should go to Amboseli or Serengeti and take out all the lions, elephants and cheetahs. They are the very reason people go there. People have to be careful.

While we were in the Ayers Rock area the parks people said to us: 'Do not leave anything out. Dingoes are notorious scavengers. They will take cameras, bags and very large objects'. They warned us to pack everything away in our tent and bags so that the dingoes could not get at them. I think the coroner's suggestion is patently absurd. People must protect themselves and look after themselves when they go into national parks. Surely people go into the national parks to see the wildlife, flora and fauna, and what Australia has to offer.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! It being 11 p.m. the debate is interrupted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: Has action been taken to ensure that historic aircraft are not exported from Australia without authority, either (a) disassembled, (b) in component form, (c) as scrap or (d) as aluminium sheets or any variation thereof; if so, what action.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: See answer to Question No. 121.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Bureau of Customs Officers keep Mr Douglas Arnold of Blackbushe Air Service, Blackbushe Airport, Camberley, Surrey, UK, under surveillance in Australia on or about 29 November 1979.
(2) If so, did the Customs officers see Mr Arnold supervise or be present at the disassembly of an historic Messerschmidt 109.

(3) Was this the same Messerschmidt 109 for which an export licence has not been issued and which was seized by Bureau of Customs Officers when it was discovered in a container which held a Mustang aircraft.
(4) Did the Bureau of Customs make any attempt to question or apprehend Mr Arnold or the responsible personnel of the exporters, Fawcett Aviation; if so, what action was taken.

(5) Did the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, on or about February 1980, personally intervene and take charge of the matters relating to the investigation and possible legal action which could be taken against the parties involved in the unauthorised export of the Messerschmidt.
(6) What subsequent action (a) was taken or (b) is to be taken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Prosecution action is being taken against those involved in the alleged attempt to export the aircraft illegally. It is, therefore, inappropriate for me to comment on these matters.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the Messerschmidt Bf 109 being held by the Australian Bureau of Customs has been formally registered on the British Civil Aircraft Register as G-SMIT Messerschmidt Bf 109G and has been noted as Werke No. (Construction No.) 163824 in anticipation of import to the United Kingdom.
(2) Was the unauthorised export of this aircraft prevented.
(3) What action (a) has been taken or (b) is proposed to be taken to ensure that this historic aircraft is retained in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Prosecution action is being taken against those involved and it would therefore be inappropriate to comment.
(2) Yes.
(3) Disposal of the aircraft must await outcome of Court proceedings.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he state during a meeting with me in his office on Thursday, 27 November 1980, also attended by my secretary, Mr David Hinchliffe, and a senior official of his Department, Mr Howell Williams, that erosion and potential flooding problems associated with the development of a canal near Nudgee Beach, Queensland, incorporated in the Brisbane Airport Redevelopment Plan, could be overcome with stone pitching along the side of the canal.
(2) If so, did he undertake to instruct his Department to have the stone pitching carried out and when will the work commence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) During my discussions with Mrs Darling in my office on 27 November 1980, I stated that ultimately protection of the canal banks of the floodway at Brisbane Airport will be provided by the careful placement of mangroves, and the use of rock walls if appropriate. I also indicated that the Department of Housing and Construction would be examining whether there was a need for additional bank protection works to be carried out before the mangroves became established, and whether there were any other measures which should be taken to allay the concern being expressed by some local residents, particularly in regard to the narrow neck of land between the canal and Nudgee Creek.

(2) I instructed the Department to carry out such stone pitching work as it considered necessary in the vicinity of the critical narrow section of road between the canal and Beach Road. The extent and nature of these protective works was determined by the Department (Mr H. C. Williams, in particular). Construction of a length of approximately 100 metres of stone pitching, together with paving of the edge of the road to join the stone work was commenced on 15 December 1980 and completed on 24 December 1980.

I am advised that this work has proved to be most effective particularly during the recent cyclone-storm of 14-15 February 1981. The critical section of the banks was again looked at by Mr Williams on 23 February 1981. The Department will be further extending the rock protective work upstream by a length of approximately 50 metres to provide added bank stability. It is expected such work will commence in about the next two weeks.
I have also instructed the Department to constantly monitor bank erosion and this is being done with the aid of an advisory panel of expert engineers.
